story:
I tried to be normal once, it didn't take

Thank you for visiting this campaign! My name is Stephanie Svec and I'm an actor and writer living in Washington DC. I have written and will be performing a one woman show at the Capital Fringe Festival in DC this summer. This show is about the role of fear in my life and how it has motivated my behavior. Through vignettes, stand up comedy and song, I explore how I got to where I find myself again: afraid. But this time, the behavior it's motivating is my writing this show. And that's where you come in. I need your help to be able to pay all the people who helped me make ths happen. There are people who believed in my vision for this show and that I could do it. I want them and their work to be compensated as they should be. 

Here is the real impact of your money: I realized I hadn't fundraised and tried to do it all myself because I wasn't sure that a show about me was worth other people contributing. So when you contribute you are saying it's worth it.

I am asking to raise $1500 by July 13th. That is 150 people donating just $10 each. That's it! With this money, I will be able to pay my for my director, my stage manager, all my designers and for my marketing. With this money, I will not be losing money by creating and performing this show.

 

And if you cannot donate money, don't worry, I've been there! But please tell your friends about it too. Share this via email, Facebook and Twitter. And by all means, if you come to the show, please wait for me after so I can thank you personally. 

 

Thank you!!

story:
What have you always wanted to do, but were too afraid to try?
For Todd Charron, it was performing a wholly improvised one-man show. He organized the first annual Follow Your Fear Day, an event encouraging people to pursue their own dream projects, while sharing in the completion of his.

They say, “We do not regret the things we have done, but the things we do not do”, and yet, for most of us there is something we’ve left undone. The thing we’ve deferred, re-prioritized, tossed into the “someday/maybe” pile where it will sit and gather dust until it eventually ends up in the “too late now” pile. A dream never realized.

This summer, Todd Charron will be following his fear.

Will you join him?

Todd Charron is a Toronto sketch and improv performer, who created Follow Your Fear Day in 2012. This summer we want to make it bigger and better, with particpants for all over working to "follow their fear".

By contributing to this project you will help Todd launch Follow Your Fear Day across the country. Anyone can participate in Follow Your Fear Day, all you need to do is commit to doing something that you've always wanted to do, but maybe have never had the push to do.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $3000 to help fund the performance on August 24, 2013.  The funds will go towards everything we need to get this show off the ground - marketing, theatre space, lighting, sound, cookies for the guy running the light and sound. 

Contributors will be invited to "follow their fear" as part of the project. More details on how to get involved are available at www.followyourfearday.com 

The Impact

For most people there is something they've always wanted to do, that thing that we defer, re-prioritize, or push into the “someday/maybe” pile where it just sits and gathers dust until we eventually decide that its "too late" to ever do it.
 
What if there was something that gave people that push, that little bit of motivation they needed to stand up and do the thing that scares them? Thats what Follow Your Fear Day is all about - encouraging everyone to stand up and do the thing they've always wanted.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, spread the word about Follow Your Fear Day! We all have something that we've wanted to accomplish, so what better time than this summer to stand up and dust off those fears! And we want to hear all about them! Share your stories on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/followyourfearday
 
Use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out!

story:
The Play

Questions of the Heart is a play about gay Mormons, by a straight Mormon.  Ben Abbott spent months interviewing gay members of his faith and produced a one-man play in which he performed as the people he interviewed, taking their lines directly from the transcripts of his interviews.  The play explores the pain, the humor, and the contradictions of being both gay and Mormon.

In the two years since Ben first performed Questions of the Heart as a thesis production at UC Berkeley, so much has changed and shifted.  In this new version of the play, Ben inserts himself as a character into the action and the uncertainty.  If the first version of the play presents a problem, the new version asks how we deal with it. As Ben digs deep into his own heart, searching for answers to the contradictions, turning to his gay Mormon interviewees for help and guidance, he shares their stores by living them on stage. With empathy as the guiding light, he asks questions...which leads to greater understanding, and more and more questions.

Ben is working with Bloomington, Indiana director Mark Kamie to produce Questions of the Heart, and it has been accepted at the Cincinnati and Indianapolis Fringe Festivals!

How You Can Help!

It is a huge honor that Questions of the Heart has been accepted to these great festivals. When Ben first produced Questions of the Heart he had the production support of the Theater and Performance Studies department of UC Berkeley behind him, but now he needs your help to make it happen! With your donations we will be able to buy set pieces, props, and a costume. It will make it possible for us to travel to Cincinnati and Indianapolis, buy advertizing for the show, and print posters and pamphlets to promote it.

To show our gratitude for you generosity we have some fun and unique perks. If you give $25 we will include your name in the program, thanking you for making the show possible, and we will send you a copy as a thank-you note. If you give $50, we will also send you a beautiful, hang-on-the-wall-worthy show poster, designed by award-winning artists Denise and Dan Gasser (trust us, it's quite the conversation starter). For $100 you will receive all of the above as well as two professional production photos from the festival performance.

Long Term

Ultimately we think Questions of the Heart is a show that can and should be performed all over the country. We've designed this production with that goal specifically in mind which means that, production-wise, it is simple, streamlined, and easily transportable. By donating to this campaign, you will not only get Ben to the Fringe, but you will open the door for Questions of the Heart to be seen all over the country!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help! Please help us get the word out and let other people know about this campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

story:
Who Are WE? 

Melissa Aston is a member of the pioneering Therapeutic Clown Program at British Columbia’s Children’s Hospital in Vancouver, BC, and is a professionally trained clown. She brings caring fun to sick children and their families with sensitivity and foolishness. She has been training with this program since 2012, and is now a full member of the team, performing as the DisOrderly, Cosmo. This program was started in 1994 by the inimitable Paul Hooson (Doc Willikers, Funnybone Doctor), and joined 6 years ago by the awesome Sand Northrup (Fizzie the Fryzziotherapist). Our current project is to send Melissa on a 8 day professional development tour of similar programs in Toronto, Ontario, and Montreal, Quebec, to meet and network with other professionals in the field. We need your help. 

Our aim is to raise $750, to cover Melissa’s expenses for the journey. Without your help, this opportunity may not be possible. Luckily, the airfare and hosting has been covered, but all other expenses are out of pocket, so we are turning to the greater circus and arts-loving community out there. In exchange for your support, Melissa is offering a live clown performance for those in her community, clown scream outs,  a selection of signed clown thank you cards, and a small selection of hand made professional clown noses, with possibly more perks to come.  Your contribution will go a long way to helping her on this new journey, networking and connecting with other therapeutic clown professionals in Canada, and supporting the medical clown field in our endeavor to bring humour and fun to health care facilities in this growing profession.

This campaign is running for 2 weeks only, so please don't wait to get involved! 

What We Need - 

Travel Expenses Breakdown

  • Food $300+
  • Honorariums to offer Clowns who are housing Melissa. $200
  • Public Transit in Toronto, Ontario, and Quebec, Montreal $60
  • Miscellaneous Expenses - $200

* If there is any left over money, it will go into a fund being created for future Therapeutic Clown professional development. 

Perks!

  • Personal Meet and Greet! A clown visit by Cosmo if in Vancouver area, could be a performance or any type of presentation, if in Vancouver area, if not, a Skype workshop or clown visit.  
  • A good quality 20" unicycle! - For Greater Vancouver residents only! 
  • Small number of awesome professional hand made clown noses available, made by Melissa 
  • Clown Thank you cards, signed sealed and delivered by clowns... and Canada Post. 
  • Clown Scream Outs and more! 

Impact

This campaign will lead to networking with other canadian therapeutic clowns, to help grow the community of therapeutic clowns. I (Melissa) wil be learning and sharing with other more experienced professionals. The medical clown profession is growing world wide with programs in Canada, U.S.A., and Israel, to name a few.

I (Melissa) am very excited to be given the opportunity to meet other professionals in Canada. I will do my best to learn as much as I can to help me in my work here in Vancouver. Mostly it is about improving my work and interactions with the children and families at the BC Children's Hospital, which is already held to a high standard. 

Ways to Help

If you can't afford to contribute to the campaign and still want to help, just spread the word, link to this campaign, share on facebook, etc. It all helps. Thank you so much!

story:
Our Campaign!

Dance Off Central is the world's first online Dance Off arena. It's the first place where friends can enter into an online dance-off from any geographical location.

               Got a score to settle? Dance it out!  

And bring your friends in on it, ask them to vote on who has the best moves! People can also share, watch and comment on individual dance videos on the site.

We've built version 1.0 of the site and we absolutely love it!  We continue to work on the site and now we need your involvement to help develop a mobile app to tie in.  Users want to upload videos quickly, while they're out and about. We want to enable people to share their dancing as quickly and as smoothly as possible.

I, Michael Berge, have worked in hospitality and entertainment for over 20 years.  My job has always been to set the stage for people to have a good time.  My team and I have set a new stage, Dance Off Central, specifically to help engage individuals and groups to have fun with their friends!  The credentials of the team I'm working with are very impressive.  They have designed, coded, tested, created phenomonal UX and maintained scores of web apps.

 

We believe that dancing is good for both the dancer and the viewer. Whether aimed at artistry or just having fun, dancing is a joy to watch. And competing with someone in a dance-off is a hilarious and aerobic way to be entertained. More holistically, we recognize that dance is not a phase.  Dance is not a trend --- Dance is a part of every culture and is a communication that transcends language.  Dance is a part of life for all people on earth. Who would argue that dance isn't a necessary part of life? 

How you can help!

1. Share our story!

Share our IndieGogo Campaign on Facebook or via email, send it to anyone who you think may have an interest in our quest!  

2. Consider a Pledge

You can be invovled in getting this amazing app to market by making a pledge of any size!  This is a labor of love for a platform designed to bring smiles to peoples' faces.  Think of the smiles you'll be helping to create!

3.  Get involved on Danceoffcentral.com!

View videos, vote on current challenges and upload videos to get involved in the community!  You can challenge us, the developers of the site... we ALL have videos up there:)

 

Rewards for Your Participation!

Even though the ultimate goal of this campaign is to make a free app, we have put together some awesome perks for everyone!  Check out the perks on the right hand side of the page to see what tickles your fancy!

How the Funds will be Used

All funds from the Indiegogo Campaign will go into the buiding and publishing of the Dance Off Central app.  If we were to exceed our goal (dare to dream!) we would use the additional funds to build additional features into the app.  Although the app is going to be free, we'd like to pack it with as many goodies as our dollars will allow.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contribution, fear not!  Thanks for taking the time to hear our story.  Here are other ways anyone can help:

1) Share our story!  

Feel free to share this campaign with anyone you feel may have an interest!  Share via Facebook, via email, twitter, anywhere you'd like!

2) Check out Danceoffcentral.com and get involved!

story:
Our Story

Britton Buttrill and Dustin Brown first met at Oglethorpe University, as undergraduate students involved in student theater. Britton and Dustin worked together to produce Britton’s first one acts on Oglethorpe’s Lupton stage. After graduation, Britton has written both one acts and full length plays, which have received staged readings around Atlanta. In Britton’s latest play, Uffizi, an American couple trapped in a claustrophobic hotel room in Florence, Italy in the middle of December decides to take desperate measures in order to reconcile their deep sexual scars. Britton’s play was selected for the Winter 2012 Strawberry One Act Festival in New York and will have its World Premiere in New York City on March 4th. 

The Impact

Uffizi will be the first fully realized professional stage production of one of Britton Buttrill's scripts. Not only will it be Britton's first professional production, it will also be his first Off-Broadway playwriting credit. The winner of the festival will have the opportunity to have their work produced by the Riant Theatre Off-Broadway. This is a unique opportunity for Britton and gives him the chance to jump-start his career as a playwright.

For the cast and crew of Uffizi, this production will provide a professional New York credit, and for many of them this will be their New York debut. This is also an opportunity for these artists to work with an emerging playwright in order to develop a new script. 

Finally, Uffizi will represent emerging Atlanta artists to a New York audience at a major international one-act play festival. 

The Who & What

Britton Buttrill received his BA in English Literature from Oglethorpe University in 2011. Although he has considered himself a lifelong writer, he discovered an overwhelming passion for playwriting during his time at Oglethorpe, and through his experiences at Oglethorpe, he decided to pursue a life in the theatre. Through Oglethorpe’s theatre program, Britton was able to stage five of his plays, spurning his passion for playwriting. He was able to study with Alliance Theatre dramaturge Jennifer Hebblethwaite and Atlanta playwright Jim Grimsley. Oglethorpe also afforded him the opportunity to study playwriting at Oxford University through the Washington International Studies Council, and the University gave him the opportunity to direct a full production of Agnes of God on the Conant stage. Oglethorpe directly prepared Britton for a life in the professional theatre world through internships with both Fabrefaction Theatre Company and Georgia Shakespeare. Because of the skill-set learned through these internships, he was able to become a full Artistic Associate with Pinch n' Ouch Theatre after graduation. Since graduating, Britton won Horizon Theatre’s New South Young Playwright’s Festival and has since received professional staged readings at both Horizon Theatre and The Drive-By Theatre Project. As a professional, he has assistant directed Tape with Pinch n' Ouch Theatre and will be assistant directing RED at Theatrical Outfit. Uffizi will be Britton Buttrill’s first professional production, and his Off-Broadway premiere.

Dustin Brown has been directing since he was sixteen, starting with high school one act competitions in Chattanooga, TN. In selecting a college, Dustin was drawn to Oglethorpe University because of its small size and open approach to education. The freedom to create your own direction, allowed Dustin to focus his efforts on Directing and Producing plays. While at Oglethorpe, Dustin founded a community theater company in his home-town of Chattanooga and directed and produced his first full-length play, Neil Simon’s Barefoot in the Park. At Oglethorpe, Dustin was instrumental in founding the student production company Rehearsal Room C, which would come to dominate his collegiate experience. RRC received awards and accolades from the student body as well as the faculty, and gave Dustin the opportunity to direct the musical Bat Boy his junior year. Through RRC, Dustin developed an annual one act festival that brought student written, directed and performed plays to the OU community. It was through this festival that Dustin first met Britton, and directed his adaptation of Ernest Hemingway’s Hills Like White Elephants. After graduating from Oglethorpe in 2010, Dustin has remained active in Atlanta theatre, working as a director and lighting designer. 

The Strawberry One-Act Festival at the Riant Theatre is celebrating its 21st season. The brainchild of Artistic Director, Van Dirk Fisher, the Festival is a play competition in which the audience and the theatre's judges cast their votes to select the season’s best play.  Hundreds of plays from across the country are submitted for the competition, and once they reach New York, the plays move from the 1st Round to Semi-Finals and then Finals.  From the Finals the audience and judges select a winning play, and the playwright of the winning play receives the opportunity to have a full-length play developed by the Riant Theatre. Awards are also awarded for Best Director, Actor and Actress.  


What We Need

Our estimated budget for Uffizi is $5,000.00 from individual contributions. Fundraising for Uffizi will cover all of the traditional production elements for a performance, as well as the expense of travel relating to the festival. These include:

- Costs for set, costume and other design elements.

- Stipends for Cast and Crew.

- Flight expenses for essential Cast and Crew to NYC.

- Room and Board in NYC for the two-week run of the festival. 

In addition to our individual contributions campaign, we are working with other institutions to cut costs and secure other support. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help, but can't donate money:

- Tell your friends, spread the word, every little bit helps.

- Come see Uffizi, March 4th, 2012, 7 p.m. at the Hudson Guild Theatre, NY, NY.

- If you have any resources that you think could be of use, please call or e-mail Dustin Brown at (423) 364-7651 or d.j.brown6988@gmail.com

Britton and Dustin worked together to produce Britton’s first one acts on Oglethorpe’s Lupton stage. After graduation, Britton has written both one acts and full length plays, which have received staged readings around Atlanta. In Britton’s latest play, Uffizi, an American couple trapped in a claustrophobic hotel room in Florence, Italy in the middle of December decides to take desperate measures in order to reconcile their deep sexual scars. Britton’s play was selected for the Winter 2012 Strawberry One Act Festival in New York and will have its World Premiere in New York City on March 4th. 

The Impact
Uffizi will be the first fully realized professional stage production of one of Britton Buttrill's scripts. Not only will it be Britton's first professional production, it will also be his first Off-Broadway playwriting credit. The winner of the festival will have the opportunity to have their work produced by the Riant Theatre Off-Broadway. This is a unique opportunity for Britton and gives him the chance to jump-start his career as a playwright.
For the cast and crew of Uffizi, this production will provide a professional New York credit, and for many of them this will be their New York debut. This is also an opportunity for these artists to work with an emerging playwright in order to develop a new script. 
Finally, Uffizi will represent emerging Atlanta artists to a New York audience at a major international one-act play festival. 

The Who & What


Britton Buttrill received his BA in English Literature from Oglethorpe University in 2011. Although he has considered himself a lifelong writer, he discovered an overwhelming passion for playwriting during his time at Oglethorpe, and through his experiences at Oglethorpe, he decided to pursue a life in the theatre. Through Oglethorpe’s theatre program, Britton was able to stage five of his plays, spurning his passion for playwriting. He was able to study with Alliance Theatre dramaturge Jennifer Hebblethwaite and Atlanta playwright Jim Grimsley. Oglethorpe also afforded him the opportunity to study playwriting at Oxford University through the Washington International Studies Council, and the University gave him the opportunity to direct a full production of Agnes of God on the Conant stage. Oglethorpe directly prepared Britton for a life in the professional theatre world through internships with both Fabrefaction Theatre Company and Georgia Shakespeare. Because of the skill-set learned through these internships, he was able to become a full Artistic Associate with Pinch n' Ouch Theatre after graduation. Since graduating, Britton won Horizon Theatre’s New South Young Playwright’s Festival and has since received professional staged readings at both Horizon Theatre and The Drive-By Theatre Project. As a professional, he has assistant directed Tape with Pinch n' Ouch Theatre and will be assistant directing RED at Theatrical Outfit. Uffizi will be Britton Buttrill’s first professional production, and his Off-Broadway premiere.
Dustin Brown has been directing since he was sixteen, starting with high school one act competitions in Chattanooga, TN. In selecting a college, Dustin was drawn to Oglethorpe University because of its small size and open approach to education. The freedom to create your own direction, allowed Dustin to focus his efforts on Directing and Producing plays. While at Oglethorpe, Dustin founded a community theater company in his home-town of Chattanooga and directed and produced his first full-length play, Neil Simon’s Barefoot in the Park. At Oglethorpe, Dustin was instrumental in founding the student production company Rehearsal Room C, which would come to dominate his collegiate experience. RRC received awards and accolades from the student body as well as the faculty, and gave Dustin the opportunity to direct the musical Bat Boy his junior year. Through RRC, Dustin developed an annual one act festival that brought student written, directed and performed plays to the OU community. It was through this festival that Dustin first met Britton, and directed his adaptation of Ernest Hemingway’s Hills Like White Elephants. After graduating from Oglethorpe in 2010, Dustin has remained active in Atlanta theatre, working as a director and lighting designer. 
The Strawberry One-Act Festival at the Riant Theatre is celebrating its 21st season. The brainchild of Artistic Director, Van Dirk Fisher, the Festival is a play competition in which the audience and the theatre's judges cast their votes to select the season’s best play.  Hundreds of plays from across the country are submitted for the competition, and once they reach New York, the plays move from the 1st Round to Semi-Finals and then Finals.  From the Finals the audience and judges select a winning play, and the playwright of the winning play receives the opportunity to have a full-length play developed by the Riant Theatre. Awards are also awarded for Best Director, Actor and Actress.  



What We Need


Our estimated budget for Uffizi is $5,000.00 from individual contributions. Fundraising for Uffizi will cover all of the traditional production elements for a performance, as well as the expense of travel relating to the festival. These include:
- Costs for set, costume and other design elements.
- Stipends for Cast and Crew.
- Flight expenses for essential Cast and Crew to NYC.
- Room and Board in NYC for the two-week run of the festival. 
In addition to our individual contributions campaign, we are working with other institutions to cut costs and secure other support. 


Other Ways You Can Help



If you want to help, but can't donate money:
- Tell your friends, spread the word, every little bit helps.
- Come see Uffizi, March 4th, 2012, 7 p.m. at the Hudson Guild Theatre, NY, NY.
- If you have any resources that you think could be of use, please call or e-mail Dustin Brown at (423) 364-7651 or d.j.brown6988@gmail.com

story:
GREETINGS TO ALL,

My writing partner and cherished friend, Stanley Jay Gelber and I are tremendously grateful that you have chosen us as possible benefactors of your generosity. We thank you in advance!

Stan and I have been in the creative arts collectively for 110 years. For six of those years, we've been writing and refining LORD TOM, the Musical, with our goal to see it produced on Broadway. You can help us get there!  Below is a little bit about each of us so that you know who we are in the creative arts world.  Now let us introduce you to LORD TOM, the Musical.

HERE'S TO THE HEROES!

LORD TOM, the Musical is the story of TOM, our hero, and his community of family and friends. TOM is at once human and mythic: fashioned on one of the most unforgettable men in American literature, the heroic character of TOM in Harriet Beecher Stowe's seminal novel Uncle Tom's Cabin (UTC). UTC sold 300,000 thousand copies in 1852, occasioning Putnam's Magazine to declare: "Never since books were first printed has the success of Uncle Tom's Cabin been equaled; the history of literature contains nothing parallel to it nor approaching it."

UTC is a masterpiece of social reform which helped end slavery, start the Civil War, and change the course of our nation's history. Indeed, Abraham Lincoln is quoted as saying to Harriet Beecher Stowe, "So this is the little lady who wrote the novel that made this great war."

Throughout Broadway history, rich, epic novels like Uncle Tom's Cabin have been converted from the page to the stage, translating eloquently into the musical theatre idiom and earning long, illustrious and successful runs on Broadway. They include Les Miserables, The Phantom of the Opera, The Secret Garden, Lost in the Stars, Ragtime, Showboat, among others.

We believe LORD TOM, the Musical--the phoenix rising out of UTC--will do the same. Broadway is ready for LORD TOM, the Musical. It gives a voice to the voiceless in today's world. It reminds us that we are all responsible for preserving and protecting our individual and collective freedom. It reminds us to live together united, with compassion and forgiveness and mutual regard for our differences, knowing that together we make up a more diverse, unique and irreplaceable family of man than apart. It reminds us that at our core we are all the same!

Music speaks to all people. Now is the time for this message to be rekindled through the music and story of LORD TOM, the Musical.

SUCCESSFUL TRACK RECORD:

Thanks to contributors like you, last November LORD TOM, the Musical funded a CD of 12 song selections from the score of 25 songs, and mounted an informal, in-house reading with a cast of stellar Broadway performers. In this reading, we read the book and sang the score together for the first time! And guess what? People laughed and people cried and they gave the cast a standing ovation at the end of Act 2, because they were so moved by the subject matter. We were thrilled and encouraged! We now enter Phase Two of our fund raising efforts.

PHASE TWO

In order to mount LORD TOM on Broadway, we need seasoned producers who know how to raise millions of dollars. So, we have to get these producers into a theatre to watch our staged reading, in order to commit to optioning our project for a Broadway production.

So, we are fund raising to self-produce two consecutive Actors Equity Approved public staged readings with the same Broadway cast and a seasoned director, we will hire. We have hired a general manager to oversee expenses and handle the daily nuts and bolts of the business end of Phase Two. We still need to pay the balance for the theatre, hire the director, pay the musical director, the casting director, the graphic designer, pay the studio for the rehearsals, pay the actors and there's more! This requires thousands of dollars to achieve: $22,500.00 to be exact. Here's our Budget.

THE FUNDING WE NEED AND WHAT IT BUYS

LORD TOM, THE MUSICAL BUDGET FOR TWO STAGED READINGS IN NEW YORK CITY, MAY 20 & 21 AT THE PETER JAY SHARP THEATRE ON THEATRE ROW

$9500.00............Creative Team (Director, Musical Director, Casting Director)

$2950.00............Actors and Production Stage Manager and Assistant Stage Manager

$3500.00............Legal and General Manager

$4500.00............Rehearsal & Performance Hall, Chairs, Music stands, Piano tuning

$1050.00............Scripts, CD tapes, Presentation Programs

$1000.00............Insurance, Payroll processing

IMPACT

LORD TOM, the Musical is a new American musical that meets American history in a progressive, game-changing way.  Its inspirational story has never been done as a book musical with an original score in either the 20th or 21st century.

Its themes are legion and legendary - the triumph of kindness over hatred, of joy over horror, of family over disengagement, of unity over division, and of freedom over bondage.

It touches our senses and enriches our lives through its 21st century depiction of Stowe's big time iconic characters. TOM, our protagonist, is a bold, charismatic, human...struggling to return to his family...with a selfless spirit...and a humanity which is striking!

LORD TOM, the Musical is a platform for illuminating the issues that people still contend with in our society and our world today, such as:

Education of the oppressed

Evolution of freedom

Equal rights for all in a colorblind world

Our protagonist gives his life to insure the freedom of others, much like Coalhouse Walker in Ragtime, Kim in Miss Saigon, and real-life heroes Martin Luther King, Jr. in Memphis, TN, and the school principal at Sandy Hook.

LORD TOM, the Musical is a true and very classic American story in which is rooted the selfless spirit of man. It honors the principles upon which our country was founded: liberty and justice for all.

You will cry with joy and laugh with tears as you identify with its iconic and human characters.

And, you will love the rewards: which include the opportunity to see LORD TOM, the Musical on the Broadway stage!  All contributors will be listed as a "theater angel" in all of our promotional materials, as we diligently move forward toward reaching our next objective--the mounting of LORD TOM, the Musical on Broadway!

Please make the difference by insuring that LORD TOM, the Musical LIVES to tell the story that empowers all of us! Your contribution empowers YOU to empower US to empower MANKIND one person and performance at a time.

JOIN US NOW ON OUR LORD TOM JOURNEY!

OUR LOVING THANKS!    

YOUR LORD TOM TEAM

 

Stanley Jay Gelber, composer/lyricist, has appeared on the Billboard charts with songs recorded by such artists as Elvis Presley, Tom Jones, The Mills Brothers, The Ray Charles Singers, Shani Wallis, Frankie Laine, and others.  He has held the position of staff writer and Associate Professional Manager at the United Artists Music Publishing Co. & Metromedia Music.  He has written commercial jingles for such clients as Hersheys (Reese's Peanut Butter Cups) KFC, Revlon Rich Girl (CLIO Award) and ABC-TV (That Special Feeling) sung by Maureen McGovern.  He is represented Off-Broadway with Love and Let Love, a musicalization of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night, as well as in film with his lyrics for the title song, Circle Of Two, starring Richard Burton & Tatum O'Neal. He is a member of both ASCAP and The Dramatists Guild.

Kimberly Vaughn, writer, is Founder and Artistic Director of Kimberly Vaughn Performance Studio, NYC. Faculty: Circle in the Square Theater School; Adjunct Professor at Pace University and NYFA. Director: Edward J. Moore’s Drama Desk Award winning play The Sea Horse; The Lost Boy, at The Helen Hayes Theatre & The Queens Theatre in the Park;  co-directed w/ Ted Mann, Sondheim’s Saturday Night at Circle in The Square Theatre School; Mel Weiser’s Cry Tiger at Phoenix Little Theatre. Producer: Tony-Award nominated musical play Marlene starring Stan Phillips;  Tony-Award nominated Swinging On A Star; Hauptman starring Denis O’Hare; Performer: Broadway, Constance Wilde in the musical Dear Oscar; Regional roles, The Member Of The Wedding w/ Ethel Waters,Harvey w/ Shirley Booth &Tom Poston, and Applause w/ Dorothy Collins.  Affiliations:  The Broadway League, Stage Directors and Choreographers Society, League of Professional Theatre Women, AEA, SAG-AFTRA.  BS in Speech and Theatre, Northwestern University.  Kimberlyvaughnperformancestudio.com

story:
So, what is this show about? We're glad you asked!

No Show: A One Woman Show

 Woody Allen said "80% of success is showing up." Apparently, comedic actress, Jenn Dodd, missed the memo. It's the opening night of her one woman show; friends, family and industry are all ready and waiting to see what this comedy gal has to offer. With the pressure rising and a misguided director who's cut all the funny lines from her show, our leading lady is nowhere to be found and the stage crew has to scramble. What happens when the one women who's show it is, is a no-show? Comedy chameleon, Jenn Dodd, plays all of the characters in this quirky, fast-paced comedy of errors.
 

Who the heck is Jenn Dodd, anyway?

 Jenn Dodd is an Andy Kaufman Award finalist, character actress & writer who’s work focuses on the hilarity of everyday people. Since graduating from Circle in the Square Theatre School in New York City, Jenn has created over 50 original characters for her blog, Jenneral Assembly, as well as for stages and festivals all over the U.S. Her work has been featured in The Huffington Post, Mediaite and Crooks and Liars. She most recently joined the cast of the off-Broadway hit, The Gong Show LIVE, in which she plays multiple original characters. Jenn is a contributor for the websites Funny Not Slutty, Comedy Rants, Comediva & runs the character showcase Buttski & Glasscock's New Talent Blow Out at The PIT every month. She also makes her bed every morning and is really good at scrabble.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Launching a professional solo show is no easy (or inexpensive) task! There are many artits involved in this project putting their talents, time and energy to use; writers, producers, directors, editors, graphic designers, technicians, and a stage manager. Not to mention the theatre space which will house the show itself and tools it will take to insure a quality product.

 

Like what?

*Theatre Space

*Director

*Video Editor/Film Crew

*Rehearsal Space

*Stage Crew: Technician & Stage Manager

*Post Cards & Promotional Tools

*Props and Costumes

Hey, Jenn, what's in it for me?

Besides my undying devotion and the proud feeling that you are helping a artist take giant leaps forward? I'll tell you, friend! Among other things...

*Social media shout outs! (Twitter, Facebook & website)

*Signed show poster

*Thank you in the play bill

*Fun/funny/unique gifts made by my characters; poems, pine cone crafts, and drawings of fantasy creatures!

*Outgoing voice mail as your favorite Jenn Dodd character or celeb!

*Compilation DVD of my Jenneral Assembly sketches.

*Free tickets to the show

Author's Note

Realizing my first one woman show is a long-time dream of mine. I have developed these characters over the course of several years in comedy clubs and stages all over New York (and other cities). When the show opens this October, I will have devoted over a year working towards this specific script and project. My plan is to continue working on the show and ultimately travel with it. I just need a little boost to set this plan into action.

Other Ways You Can Help

So, you can't contribute, that's A-ok! Not to worry! There ARE ways you can help "No Show: A One Woman Show"!

*Share this page on social media. 

*Come to the show and laugh your patooties off!

*Check out JennDodd.org and tell your friends about all the funny-ha-ha's you see there!

story:
Short Summary

    Greetings, my name is Jeff Ingram and I am the Director of The New World Children's Theatre, a program of Standing Rock Cultural Arts (www.standingrock.net).  Each year, we put out a call for students to write, design, build sets, make posters, rehearse and perform an original theatrical production.  We are now in our twentieth year and the program has created 26 original plays.

     We decided to embark on a campaign to raise funds because we believe the New World Children's Theatre program is at the core of our mission To Build Community Through The Arts.  This program nurtures the spirit of creativity and allows children the opportunity to bring their ideas to the stage.  I received my degree in Theatre and French in 1987 from Ohio State University and have read many, many plays in my day.   The plays the kids write are among the best.  Although I never expected to be involved in Children's Theatre, I've found the experience to be as rewarding and enlightening as it is frustrating and absurd.  A little bit of money goes a long way with this program.  The sense of empowerment for the students in this group has long lasting effects and the productions build skills that most remember for th rest of their lives.

What We Need & What You Get

    We need $7,000.00 to make this project a success.  Our funding comes from many sources including The DuBois Family Foundation, The Christenson Foundation, local businesses, tuition from students, and private individuals.  But it's never enough to cover all the expenses. 

    We are hoping to raise $800 to pay for art supplies including paint, brushes, canvases for backdrops, as well as to help cover the fees for an art director and administrative personnel for this program.  For your contribution, you will receive:

$20  - two tickets to the performance in May

$30 - two tickets and listing in the program

$50 - all of the above and a t shirt of the production

$100 - 4 tickets to the performance, 2 t shirts, a listing in the program, a DVD of the performance, and a signed copy of the script

The Impact

     Your contribution has an enormous impact on the children in our community.  The children are our future.  When we give them the tools to become leaders, to become productive citizens working together toward a common goal, to respect each other and solve conflicts, to realize a dream from concept to implementation on stage, we offer them one of the best gifts you can give a child, self esteem and cooperative ideas.

     Several of our students have grown to become exceptional professionals in the performing arts.  Jessica Lee Mayfield is a nationally acclaimed recording artist and Anya Clingman just completed her MFA studies at Depaul University and is teaching theatre in Chicago.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, please spread the word and let people know about the campaign here at Indie Go Ggo or about our New World Children's Theatre program in general.  Spread the word!  http://www.standingrock.net/Performances.htm
Photos on Facebook.  http://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.373563213875.152940.371908693875&type=3
 
Thanks much!
 
Jeff Ingram/Director
New World Children's Theatre
257 N. Wate St.
Kent, OH  44240
330-673-4970
www.standingrock.net
story_txt:
Short Summary
    Greetings, my name is Jeff Ingram and I am the Director of The New World Children's Theatre, a program of Standing Rock Cultural Arts (www.standingrock.net).  Each year, we put out a call for students to write, design, build sets, make posters, rehearse and perform an original theatrical production.  We are now in our twentieth year and the program has created 26 original plays.     We decided to embark on a campaign to raise funds because we believe the New World Children's Theatre program is at the core of our mission To Build Community Through The Arts.  This program nurtures the spirit of creativity and allows children the opportunity to bring their ideas to the stage.  I received my degree in Theatre and French in 1987 from Ohio State University and have read many, many plays in my day.   The plays the kids write are among the best.  Although I never expected to be involved in Children's Theatre, I've found the experience to be as rewarding and enlightening as it is frustrating and absurd.  A little bit of money goes a long way with this program.  The sense of empowerment for the students in this group has long lasting effects and the productions build skills that most remember for th rest of their lives.
What We Need & What You Get


    We need $7,000.00 to make this project a success.  Our funding comes from many sources including The DuBois Family Foundation, The Christenson Foundation, local businesses, tuition from students, and private individuals.  But it's never enough to cover all the expenses. 
    We are hoping to raise $800 to pay for art supplies including paint, brushes, canvases for backdrops, as well as to help cover the fees for an art director and administrative personnel for this program.  For your contribution, you will receive:
$20  - two tickets to the performance in May
$30 - two tickets and listing in the program
$50 - all of the above and a t shirt of the production
$100 - 4 tickets to the performance, 2 t shirts, a listing in the program, a DVD of the performance, and a signed copy of the script


The Impact
     Your contribution has an enormous impact on the children in our community.  The children are our future.  When we give them the tools to become leaders, to become productive citizens working together toward a common goal, to respect each other and solve conflicts, to realize a dream from concept to implementation on stage, we offer them one of the best gifts you can give a child, self esteem and cooperative ideas.
     Several of our students have grown to become exceptional professionals in the performing arts.  Jessica Lee Mayfield is a nationally acclaimed recording artist and Anya Clingman just completed her MFA studies at Depaul University and is teaching theatre in Chicago.


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute, please spread the word and let people know about the campaign here at Indie Go Ggo or about our New World Children's Theatre program in general.  Spread the word!  http://www.standingrock.net/Performances.htm

Photos on Facebook.  http://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.373563213875.152940.371908693875&type=3

 
Thanks much!
 
Jeff Ingram/Director
New World Children's Theatre
257 N. Wate St.
Kent, OH  44240
330-673-4970
www.standingrock.net

story:
About Beautiful City Theatre:

Beautiful City Theatre is a non-profit organization that seeks to create and celebrate community through the sharing and exploration of theatre processes and performances.
 
For our first production, we are presenting Godspell, a rock musical that will be performed in Old Montreal's Centaur Theatre in January 2013. We will also be holding a Gala in honour of our supporters on Friday January 11, 2013 (to be held at the MAI: Montreal Arts Interculturels). 
 
Beautiful City Theatre was founded to create a space that challenges and enriches its participants’ understanding of relationships and humanity. Godspell embodies the essence of BCT as it explores and celebrates life, play, and the building of community.

What's the Cause:

In order to make this production possible, we need rehearsal space that is large enough to accommodate 13 cast members, 4 artistic leaders and 3 stage managers. In order for these creative minds to be able to work together and truly explore, they need space to roam free!

We are asking for the exact amount that we need for rehearsal space, which is $1921.45 (Indiegogo won't let us include the 45 cents... but don't worry, we've got it covered!)

Even with generous donations from our studios, we are still paying a minimum of $10/hour for the time we spend in rehearsal.

What We Can Offer:

For any donation over $10: Your name will appear in the program for Godspell (if desired). This buys us a whole wonderful hour of rehearsal, and we can't tell you how much we appreciate it.

$50: Poster signed by the entire cast.

$100: Two tickets to our Gala event.

$150: Two tickets to our Gala event and a signed poster by the entire cast.

$200: Two free tickets to the show and two tickets to our Gala event.

$250: Two free tickets to the show, two tickets to our Gala event, and a poster signed by the entire cast.

$500: Two free tickets to show, two tickets to our Gala event, a poster signed by the entire cast, and a personal song dedication to the donator at our Gala (song of your choice!).

$1921: All of the above, a bottle of wine to celebrate your generosity, a batch of freshly baked cookies for your warm heart, our undying love (better than a tax receipt!), a handmade pop-up card, and fulfillment of your New Year's resolution to donate to the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Any help at all is appreciated... and if you don't have the ability to offer financial support, there is still a way that you can help! If you have access to dance studios or rehearsal space, please contact us at info@beautifulcitytheatre.com

Thank you so much from all of us!

With love and gratitude,

The BCT Community

story:
Short Summary

Sci-Fi on the Rock is Newfoundland's largest science fiction convention and is entering its 7th year. We have a great selection of guests coming this year: Dominic Keating, Mike Dopud, Gary Jones, Dean Haglund and Ginny McQueen. Getting these folks out to St. John's, NL is costly. Flights, hotels, meals...it gets expensive! We want to keep offering some great guests, wonderful workshops, fantastic film festival, crazy costumes and other awesome events. In order to do so, we need YOUR help!
 
We want to offer a fun time and raise some needed funds before those guests get to St. John's. We've gotten the privilege of putting on Star Trek Live; The Trouble with Tribbles. We're doing this as a dramatic reading (meaning that costumes and props are involved as well as some great voice acting). We also have some additional surprises up our sleeves too!

What We Need & What You Get

Your support on this project will go towards:

  • Rental of AV equipment
  • Rental of performance space
  • Costumes, props, scripts, etc.

As part of the agreement with the school that is hosting our performance, the rental fees are going directly to the school's lunch program.

The Impact

The show is all about the celebration of science fiction, and the reach for something greater than ourselves. That is what we are trying to do with this show; help build our community of nerds, geeks, gamers, cosplayers, Trekkers and other fun and fantastic people. With your help, we'll be able to continue to provide a service to this community, and we can build on our success. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially. You can help us make a difference by:

  • Telling your friends about Sci-Fi on the Rock and Star Trek Live: The Trouble with Tribbles fundraiser
  • Using the Indiegogo share tools! Tweet! Facebook! Social Network!
  • Help us get the word out, and feel awesome doing it!

Location

The Trouble with Tribbles Show will be taking place on March 15 and 16 at 7pm at Beaconsfield Jr. High. We have some surprises planned, so come out for the evening and have a great time!

story:
The Orphans Feast

Hello!  We are The Monocle.  We are a performing arts ensemble from Kansas City, MO.  We are producers, composers, writers, singers, and actors who have joined together to create new musical and theatrical works.

We are preparing our debut production, an original musical theatre experience entitled “The Orphans Feast.”  Inspired by the meals shared by friends during the holidays, the story follows various characters as they pursue the meaning of family through music, comedy, drama, and time travel. It features original music and new takes on holiday classics by a live band with some of the best jazz players in the city. It also features zombies. What's not to love?

It will be playing at The Arts Asylum, 1000 E 9th St KCMO:

  • 11/30 - 8:00 pm
  • 12/1 - 7:00 pm and 10:00 pm
  • 12/2 - 2:00 pm

This play is the culmination of a year of planning and hard work. Our goal of creating a funny, beautiful, and compelling play is almost complete.  But we are missing one vital ingredient.

Money.

To stage the play at its full potential, we need to hire professional musicians, actors, and crew.  To allow these professionals to focus their time and talent on the production – rather than split their attention between this and a second or third job – we need to pay them fair, livable wages.

The only way we can do this is with your help.

 

How Much Does It Cost to Stage a Play? 

We have hired 11 professionals:

  • 5 actors
  • 4 musicians
  • 1 assistant director
  • 1 stage manager

Each professional will spend 88 hours working on this production:

  • 16 days of rehearsals x 3 hrs/day = 48 hrs
  • 4 days of tech and dress rehearsals x 6 hrs/day = 24 hrs
  • 4 shows x 4 hrs/show = 16 hrs

At only $10/hr, it will cost $880 for each of these professionals to appear in our show.

11 x $880 = $9,680

And then there are the part time professionals:

  • 6 part time actors
  • 1 part time prop maker
  • 1 part time costumer
  • 1 part time set builder
  • 1 lighting designer
  • 1 sound engineer 

But that's not all:

  • Space rental - theater and rehearsal space
  • Advertising - print flyers and buy ads.  Can we afford to hire a graphic designer or do we do it ourselves?  How does that decision impact the effectiveness of our advertising and our ticket sales?
  • Personnel - ushers, box office help, security. 

Our final budget for this show is just over $12,000.  If we sell 100 seats for all four shows, we will make $4000, leaving another $8000 that we have to cover.  And that's why we're turning to you.

 

What Do You Get For Helping Us?

We aren't asking you to give us your hard-earned money for free.  We would gratefully accept your hard-earned money for free, but that's not what this campaign is about.

This is about perks!  We have 10 levels of perks available, starting at only $5 and proceeding up to $500.  All of the donation levels include mention in our program.  All but one include a copy of our show poster, which features an image by Tyson Schroeder.  Most of our perks include tickets to the show.  Higher levels include invitations to the wrap party, post-show backstage passes, and even dinner or private concerts.

Finally, we are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)(3).  Contributions for the purposes of The Monocle are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 

What Impact Will Your Financial Contribution Have?

The Monocle was founded by four KC performing artists:

  • Nathan Granner - Producer, writer, and internationally know operatic tenor.  Appeared as one of the American Tenors on the Sony Masterworks imprint.  Produced "A Night With Virgil T" in conjunction with PBS at the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts in Kansas City.
  • Katie Gilchrist - producer, director, and nationally recognized actor.  Founding member and producer of The New Century Follies.  Actor in numerous Kansas City productions, including The Unicorn's staging of Everyday Rapture in it's post-Broadway national debut. 
  • Shay Estes - jazz, brazilian, and fado vocalist, arranger, and actor.  Leads her own jazz quartet, and performs with The People's Liberation Big Band and Snuff Jazz.  Founding member of Fado Novato and Mistura Fina.  Performs and arranges with The Barclay Martin Ensemble.
  • Christian Hankel - composer, producer, and performer.  Founding member and songwriter for Alacartoona and The Hillary Watts Riot.  Writer, producer, composer, and actor in "The Oil Boiler."  Scriptwriter and actor in Alacartoona's film "Night Is the Mirror," and stage play "Bought & Souled."  Actor and composer for "Sexing Hitler."

Over and over, we’ve seen first hand the power that music and theatre have to bring people of varying beliefs and backgrounds together, to celebrate, to laugh, to feel love and loss.  And over and over again, we’ve worked with amazing artists who pour their time and effort into scripts and songs, often with no more compensation than the love of creating good art.

We founded The Monocle with two goals in mind:  1.  to create a production team capable of staging full-length professional-grade works of theatre, musical theatre, and opera, and 2. to build a self-sustaining performing arts company that can provide artistically satisfying and fairly compensated work to performers.

Your financial contribution today will help us stage The Orphans Feast in a way that provides artistically satisfying, financially viable work for local performing artists.  It will also provide us with seed money to help The Monocle become a self-sustainable, artist-supporting performing arts production company.

Btw, if we don't make our goal, we do have a plan B.  We will trim back the cast to an appropriate number and minimalize props and sets.  It won't be easy to strip down our vision, but we'll put our producers' hats on, roll up our sleeves and make the hard decisions necessary to keep the show viable.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you are able to financially contribute to our cause, you can help in other very important ways:

  • Please spread the word about our fundraising campaign.  Email a link to this page to your friends and family.  Post a link on your facebook wall.  Tweet about the show.  Indiegogo has a set of share tools built in to the site that make it easy to spread the news on your social networks.  Anything you can do to make people aware of our campaign will help us immensely.
  • We need materials for building sets and props.  If you live in the KC area and you have building materials, paint, and/or fabric that you can donate, let us know at info@themonoclekc.com.
  • We need volunteers.  If you would be interested in being an usher (which could include work outside during the last week of November), contact us at info@themonoclekc.com.

 

THANK YOU!

story:
Shades of Truth Theatre was founded in 2003 to address the lack of truth telling in theatre and film related to the black experience. We offer new and veteran playwrights of color an opportunity to showcase their uncompromising voice.

Our mission, at Shades of Truth Theatre, is to inspire, inform and empower our audiences with shows that stimulate, agitate and activate.

 

We are currently in pre production for the following shows

  • After Midnight: King’s Powerful Rebuke of the Vietnam War
  • Black Wall Street
  • Rainy Day Blues -Alberta Hunter Younger Years
  • Peace Speaks- Letters of Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr.
  • Noble Lofton- Buffalo Soldier
  • I See Freedom- The Story of Harriet Tubman
  • Whistle in Mississippi: The Lynching of Emmett Till

 

We are also interested in developing new plays about the unsung heroes of the African American Experience included but not be limited to

  • Benjamin Banneker
  • Paul Robeson
  • Sojourner Truth
  • Nat Turner
  • Barbara Jordan
  • Shirley Chisholm
  • Denmark Vesey
  • Black Panthers
  • And many others who are not as well known

,

 As a true, grassroots organization, the company's intent is to continue to build relationships with local independent businesses and social organizations who understand the need for artistic expression. We also believe in collaborating with other theatre groups like Voza Rivers’/ New Heritage Theatre Group.

With your support Shades of Truth Theatre would like to re visit prisons and correctional facilities such as Rikers’ Island, Sing- Sing, and Eastern Corrections and other institutions that often struggle to bring positive programs such as ours to their populations.

 The funds raised in this campaign will be used toward:

  • Building portable sets to travel with
  • Upgrading costumes for all shows
  • Increasing budget for public relations and advertising
  • Covering cost for rehearsal and performance space
  • Actor compensation
  • Administrative Cost

          

On behalf of the Shades of Truth Theatre Family, we thank you in advance for your support. 

"Be the Change You Wish for the World"

                                                      Gandhi

 

Photo of Danny Glover with Michael Green courtesy of Afrikanspot.

Filmed and produced by A Delight Production © 2012 

Shoe Shine Boy Dance photo courtesy Hollis King

story:
OUR STORY

Theatre Crisis is putting up a new play called Little One on a shoestring budget at the SummerWorks Theatre Festival in Toronto, from August 4th to the 14th, 2011. 


The Play

Two adopted siblings grow up together in the affluent Ottawa of the late 90s. Claire and Aaron love each other with all their hearts. But for some people loving and destroying are the same thing... A stylish little lullaby-nightmare from the artists who brought you The Russian Play.


Our Collaborators 

Little One is written by Hannah Moscovitch (author of East of Berlin and The Russian Play, playwright in residence at Tarragon Theatre, nominated for the Governor General's Award & the international Susan Smith Blackburn Prize ) and directed/dramaturged by Natasha Mytnowych (director/dramaturg of The Russian Play, Associate Director of Programming for Canadian Stage, winner of the inaugural TACF Emerging Artist award).


Veteran performers Michelle Monteith (Buddies in Bad Times Theatre's Blasted, Soulpeppers' Waiting for the Parade, Theatre Crisis' tour of The Russian Play) and Joe Cobden, (Factory Theatre's 2011 remount of Zadie's Shoes, Necessary Angel's The Eco Show) star in Little One.  They're joined by Kaylie Lau on the toy piano... 


The stellar creative team includes award-winning lighting designer Kimberly Purtell (Stratford Festival's The Little Years, da da camera's Daniel MacIvor shows), award-winning set and costume designer Michael Gianfrancesco (Studio 180's Stuff Happens, Seven Seasons at the Stratford Festival), sound designer Eric Meadows (Nightwood Theatre's The List) and musical director Lily Ling (Studio 180's Our Class).  


OUR PLAN

We need to raise funds to pay our rehearsal bills, AND we'd especially love you to come out to opening night so we set up this online fundraising-thing to make that happen.  


WHAT YOU GET

Check out the perks section... The big thing is a ticket to our opening night at 8PM on Friday, August 5th, 2011, at Theatre Passe Muraille Mainspace. Come be the first ones to see our new play and celebrate with us by eating a big loot bag of all the candies and treats we loved the best when we were kids...candy nostalgia...mmmmmm...
story_txt:
OUR STORY

Theatre Crisis is putting up a new play called Little One on a shoestring budget at the SummerWorks Theatre Festival in Toronto, from August 4th to the 14th, 2011. 

The Play
Two adopted siblings grow up together in the affluent Ottawa of the late 90s. Claire and Aaron love each other with all their hearts. But for some people loving and destroying are the same thing... A stylish little lullaby-nightmare from the artists who brought you The Russian Play.

Our Collaborators 
Little One is written by Hannah Moscovitch (author of East of Berlin and The Russian Play, playwright in residence at Tarragon Theatre, nominated for the Governor General's Award & the international Susan Smith Blackburn Prize ) and directed/dramaturged by Natasha Mytnowych (director/dramaturg of The Russian Play, Associate Director of Programming for Canadian Stage, winner of the inaugural TACF Emerging Artist award).

Veteran performers Michelle Monteith (Buddies in Bad Times Theatre's Blasted, Soulpeppers' Waiting for the Parade, Theatre Crisis' tour of The Russian Play) and Joe Cobden, (Factory Theatre's 2011 remount of Zadie's Shoes, Necessary Angel's The Eco Show) star in Little One.  They're joined by Kaylie Lau on the toy piano... 

The stellar creative team includes award-winning lighting designer Kimberly Purtell (Stratford Festival's The Little Years, da da camera's Daniel MacIvor shows), award-winning set and costume designer Michael Gianfrancesco (Studio 180's Stuff Happens, Seven Seasons at the Stratford Festival), sound designer Eric Meadows (Nightwood Theatre's The List) and musical director Lily Ling (Studio 180's Our Class).  


OUR PLAN
We need to raise funds to pay our rehearsal bills, AND we'd especially love you to come out to opening night so we set up this online fundraising-thing to make that happen.  


WHAT YOU GET
Check out the perks section... The big thing is a ticket to our opening night at 8PM on Friday, August 5th, 2011, at Theatre Passe Muraille Mainspace. Come be the first ones to see our new play and celebrate with us by eating a big loot bag of all the candies and treats we loved the best when we were kids...candy nostalgia...mmmmmm...

story:
Our Story

The Ensemble Theatre Company of (TETCNY) is proud to be producing our first planned Professional Equity (LOA) production — John Gay's DIVERSIONS & DELIGHTS.

 

The play, about one of Oscar Wilde's last lectures in a small concert hall on the Rue de la Pepinier, in 1899, is at turns funny and touching. The story, which at times deals with societal intolerance, is not only reflective of the hypocrisies of Victorian England, but of our current cultural views today.

 

The Ensemble Theatre Company of seeks to bring great works that have been overlooked back to audiences, particularly those that reflect what is going on in today’s society. We also wish to be a place where people can learn their various crafts, as well as introduce new audiences to the enlightening effects of live theatre. Supporting us are such theatre luminaries as SIR DEREK JACOBI, BRIAN BEDFORD, BRIAN MURRAY, and ELI WALLACH, as well as Broadway producers JOHN HABER and RICK HOBARD.

 

The Impact

.

 

Help us create and reach others with art that has enriched our lives.


 

What We Need & What You Get

 

 

This first campaign is to raise $5,000 to pay for the rights to produce John Gay’s DIVERSIONS & DELIGHTS.

The show has not been done in NYC since 1978, and has rarely been performed since. It will be a real boon to present this work to a new generation of Theatergoers, as well as to those who saw the original production. The play, while quite funny, touches on issues of intolerance that also makes its message relevant and timely.

 


 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please repost this campaign on your Facebook, MySpace, blog and/or Twitter page and encourage others to do so.

Donation amounts do not have to be large — many small donations can help us reach our goal to bring quality independent theatre to NYC.

story:
A Ward Studio Company Production

bolding challenging audiences to bear more intimate witness to human events  


I Wish You A Boat was originally created in the Company’s New York Studio in 2005.  In 2006, it received two nominations for OUTSTANDING ACTING from New York Innovative Theatre Awards.  The show is currently being reworked with an international cast for performances in Philadelphia, Australia and Macedonia.  The company is known for its particular ability to perform with stark authenticity and an extraordinary esprit de corps.  Their productions have been described as "movies on stage," in reference to the intimacy of their settings and the honesty in the their performances.


Company Members

Cazz Bainbridge, Christopher Chung, Sophie Cole, Leah Costello, Petra Glieson,

Scott O'Halloran, Mel Orpen, Xavier O'Shannessy, Kliment Poposki,

Ryan Rickenbach, Eben Rojter, Linda Schapley, Gianmarco Soresi, Lena Taege





       &           


www.wardstudiocompany.com

story:
Help us in the home stretch of production for Birth/Rebirth, Blue Scorpion Dance Theater's summer residency.  We're working to raise $750 more to increase the salaries of our beautiful dancers.  

This is an expansion of last season's very successful "Feed the Dancer's" campaign where we were able to raise an extra $500 to pay our dancers as a bonus over their salary.  100% of your donations (whether we meet, fall short, or exceed our goal amount) will be paid directly to those whose hard work and dedication has made this project possible.  

Blue Scorpion Dance Theater is a Bay Area based, contemporary dance company founded with the mission of creating works that can meet, engage, and communicate with each audience member regardless of their previous experience seeing and interpreting dance, while promoting the growth and development of the next generation of dance makers and dance artists.  

Founded in 2010 under the name, niebieski (blue) dance theater, BSDT first took to the stage in February of 2011 at the Temescal Arts Center in Oakland, CA where they produced a suite of works choreographed by BSDT’s director, Frederick Gaudette.  In the fall of 2011, they went on to perform in DanceMission’s Fall Harvest, and at The Women’s Building’s annual event, Celebration of Craftswomen at Fort Mason.  

2012 is shaping up to be an exciting year for the company.  They have started an outreach program in collaboration with 2 bay area elementary schools.  They are being produced this summer as Resident Artists at The Garage/SF, and are producing a concert this winter featuring premieres by Mr. Gaudette, Jackie Goneconti, and Jillian Davis.  They’ve recently moved into their new home studio at the Salvation Army Ray and Joan Kroc Community Center where in addition to creating work for performance they’re teaching classes at the center and initiating a community outreach program serving the youth of San Francisco’s Tenderloin neighborhood.

BSDT is directed by Frederick Gaudette a local dance maker and dance artist who has performed both locally and nationally with Spectrum Dance Theater (Donald Byrd), Liss Fain Dance (Liss Fain), Oakland Ballet (Ronn Guidi), and others.  His choreography has been produced in San Francisco, CA, Oakland, CA, Redmond WA, and in Chelm, Poland where he works regularly with Estrada Dziecieca as a guest teacher/choreographer.  In addition to his work with BSDT Mr. Gaudette is also the Assistant Director/Ballet Master for LabayanDance/SF (Enrico Labayan).

You can learn more by visiting our website:  www.bluescorpiondance.org and keep in touch with us on Facebook:  www.facebook.com/BlueScorpionDance

story:
'The Five Of Us' presents 'Clear Head, Open Heart, Strong Body'. -
 A performance art benefit program for the Brimfield, MA tornado victims. 

What we want to do....
We have two distinctive missions with this project. One is to create a contemporary performance production which, once funded and developed will become a benefit performance for the Brimfield, MA tornado victims. The funds we raise will aid in the rebuilding of homes where the insurance does not cover the rebuild. 
 'Clear Head, Open Heart, Strong Body' is a mantra we apply to both skill set and life. This mantra motivates our dreams and hopes to reality. Our production is a journey through varying aspects of such dreams, given to the audience through the strength, grace and dexterity of circus arts, dance, theater and multimedia. This project should create awareness not only of the tragedy in Brimfield and the surrounding communities of Western MA, but awareness of the weather effects of global warming in our worldwide communities. It is for this pressing issue that this project must be sustainable and ongoing.
Our other mission aims at community renewal through Movement as Metaphorâ„¢. We believe that bringing children and adolescents together through production workshops in theater, circus arts, visual arts and dance plants a new seed of emotional connectivity and renewal much needed in a disaster struck community. Creating theatrical productions is in itself, creating strength in community through the creative process. The workshops are aimed at providing a healthy physical and emotional outlet for youths suffering from post traumatic stress symptoms. 

How we plan to do it...
Thus far our plans have evolved in several parts. The first being the development of Movement as Metaphor youth programs which have been in effect since 2008 in Brimfield and Western MA. This includes training in several forms of dance, acrobatics,circus arts, acting, body conditioning, team awareness and collaboration. The second part of this process is intertwining world class professional performance artists and arts in education professionals into the project to mentor the youth, and guide them through their creative process. In doing this we foster a positive example whilst providing support and inspiration. The next part of the process entails attending rehearsals, hands on studying of production in the fields of multimedia/design, costume design and construction, prop/set design, stage make-up, and rigging safety for aerial arts. This process occurs on a 7hr/day schedule for 4 weeks requiring studio time, safety equipment (such as crash mats), textiles and other supplies. Much of this we have, more of this we desperately need. 
Completing the creation of 'Clear head, Open Heart, Strong Body' relies (ofcourse)upon sufficient rehearsal space and time. The best way we can do this is by building a sustainable headquarters for the project which we have begun. Our space wishes to function as a sanctuary and support for emerging and established artists who are invested in devoting their talents to the Brimfield, MA tornado relief and renewal effort as well as for youth arts in education camps and workshops. For this to happen we need to furnish the space with appropriate safety equipment, rigging, acrobatic equipment and sprung dance flooring. 
                                                                   
                                                                What the money is for...
The merging and use of varieties of artistic disciplines presses for evolution within all of those forms individually. Bringing this process to aid in disaster relief is an exciting and purposeful endeavor. In order to create a sustainable project we incur a great amount of expense on rehearsal spaces. Bringing workshops and productions into disaster struck areas presents us with the challenge of housing the workshops and performances. We manage these obstacles in 2 ways. Our goal for Movement As Metaphorâ„¢ is to create a facility which workshop students can travel to, and our goal for production is to utilize that same space to create a flexible performance environment which can be site specific and easily transportable for any venue. In order for 'Clear head, Open Heart, Strong Body' to develop into a strong fundraising tool it must be capable of utilizing any space as performance space. An investment into furnishing workshop and rehearsal space is urgent.  
Safety equipment (crash mats etc)and rigging hardware for aerial acrobatics is an important responsibility. Safety equipment must be accessible at all times to all students.We are working with several platforms to create animated 2d and 3d projection as a film component to suit the score of 'Clear Head, Open Heart, Strong Body'  by the Kansas City based group Human Cropcircles. We also need to utilize the projector for the projection mapping component of our youth workshops. For the projection to maintain its opacity against our theater's lighting programs we need a 1080dpi 10,000+ lumen projector which we currently do not have. Portable sprung dance flooring is also a necessity, It allows us to bring dance classes safely to any location indoors or outdoors thus creating the flexibility necessary for our production and aiding our ability to bring workshops to those who do not have the ability to leave their areas.

With your help we will make the following investments; 
$3500.00/mo rental space for  'The Five Of Us' - 'Clear Head, Open Heart, Strong Body' and Movement as Metaphorâ„¢ project home base. 
$5000.00 for a portable dance flooring system 
http://www.harlequinfloors.com/us/en/products/s...
$1800.00 for two anti-skid mats (these mats do not slide out from underneath the student whilst training) http://www.gymsupply.com/anti-skidmats.aspx
$609.00 for carpeted mats http://www.gymsupply.com/carpetbondedfoam.aspx
$6000.00 - We are aiming to fund a rental for 3-4months. The msrp on this is $59000.00(in our wildest dreams)http://www.panasonic.com/business/projectors/d1...
$1589.00 Workstation for body conditioning - a necessity for strength and flexibility training. http://www.gymsupply.com/workstationstallbar12c...

Western MA has suffered six weather disasters in seven months, three tornados, two tropical storms and a snowstorm in late fall leaving most of the area resembling a pile of trash. Brimfield, MA was one of the hardest areas hit.

State officials say that reimbersements for the tornado damages and October storms could take up to a year despite efforts from congress to expedite the process. 

FranÃ§oise Vorangerâ€™s family lives in Brimfield, MA. It was once a place where the Hybrid Movement Company had a second home, nature and trees to retreat in for aerial and acrobatic training and gardens growing organic produce to sustain artists through long days of practice. A sanctuary. Brimfield is a part of our family and has played an instrumental role in our progress. In August 2011 FranÃ§oise, Jillian, Ronnie, Ziporah and Joanna said prayer for the land and the people of Brimfield.

Hence, the project title â€˜The five of usâ€™. 

This project seeks not only to rebuild homes, but to renew lives and refresh a hurting community. It begins with your donation. With your help we can heal a community together. 

The project promises to contribute 100% of funds raised through performance to the people through the Brimfield First Congregational Church. All donations to â€˜The five of usâ€™ are tax deductible. Please visit the project website here http://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=4929 

Team;
FranÃ§oise Voranger www.thehybridmovementcompany.net
Jillian St.Germain www.thehybridmovementcompany.net
Ronnie Thomas www.thehybridmovementcompany.net
Olga Karmansky www.OlgaK.com
Richard Hankes www.richardandashleighlive.com
Ashlee Montague www.ashleemontague.com
Sarah Brodsky
Viktor FrÃ¡nyÃ³ www.theaerialviktor.com
Tess Emerson
William Da Silva www.williamdasilva.com
Matthew Greenfield www.web.mac.com/matthew.greenfield87/iWeb/Site/...

story:
THANK YOU TO ALL 111 DONORS WHO MADE THIS CAMPAIGN SURPASS OUR INDIE GOGO GOAL! WE ARE SO GRATEFUL!

STILL WANT TO DONATE?

We are still accepting donations and every bit can help us as we actively try to raise the whole $30,000 needed produce this WORLD PREMIERE PRODUCTION!! The producting team is still going to honor the perks onlined on this page based on what level you give.

To give ONLINE please head to: www.blackenthebubble.com

To MAIL-IN a contibution please send a check or money order made out to: Liberation Theatre Company
Address: 1855 Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Blvd #1C New York, NY 10026

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope that you are inspired to join us in this movement., but even if you can’t, please spread the word!  Word-of-mouth is the best way to get people interested, but social media is also helps.  Please share this page on Facebook, Twitter, and through emails to anyone you think may be interested in helping.  With your help, we can reach far more people and you become a vital force behind our success.
