story:
Amanda Oie and Sean B. Cormack will present “Split Bill: World Premier Choreography” this fall season on September 28th, 29th at Velocity Dance Center, 1621 12th Ave., Seattle WA.

In “Split Bill: World Premier Choreography” Amanda and Sean will both be presenting new works including two self choreographed solo performances. Amanda Oie will use both Spanish and Modern dance influences in her solo performance and will be dancing to music specifically composed for the show.  Sean B. Cormack will be presenting a solo piece that taps into our connections with one another and with our society as a whole. Both choreographers will be presenting group pieces that allow the audience to explore the grace, strength and beauty that can be found in our everyday lives.

The evening’s program includes two group pieces, two solo pieces and two duets with an intermission.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $1,000 to:

  • Provide costuming and props for all of the pieces.
  • Pay our individual artists for thier time. (Dancers, Technical Director, and Musicians)
  • Finish paying for our venue for both nights. ($952 remaining)
  • Help pay for promotional materials (Postcards, Posters - $300)

When you give $5 you will get a personalized hand-written thank you note from the choreographers!

When you give $20 you will recieve a shout out in our program as well as our facebook page!

When you give $50 you will recieve 2 tickets to the night of your choice and front row seating! This is an AWESOME PERK!

When you give $100 you will get to have drinks/coffee with the choreographers and pick thier brains about the show!

You don't have to give a lot of money to be a supporter!

Even $5 or $10 will help get us one step closer to our goal!

If we don't reach our entire goal in time, we will use the funds that are raised to pay for our bill for the venue space.

By supporting local independent artists, you are helping to strengthen the seams our community as a whole.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • SPREAD THE WORD FOR US! TELL YOUR FRIENDS!
story_txt:
Amanda Oie and Sean B. Cormack will present “Split Bill: World Premier Choreography” this fall season on September 28th, 29th at Velocity Dance Center, 1621 12th Ave., Seattle WA.
In “Split Bill: World Premier Choreography” Amanda and Sean will both be presenting new works including two self choreographed solo performances. Amanda Oie will use both Spanish and Modern dance influences in her solo performance and will be dancing to music specifically composed for the show.  Sean B. Cormack will be presenting a solo piece that taps into our connections with one another and with our society as a whole. Both choreographers will be presenting group pieces that allow the audience to explore the grace, strength and beauty that can be found in our everyday lives.
The evening’s program includes two group pieces, two solo pieces and two duets with an intermission.

What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $1,000 to:

Provide costuming and props for all of the pieces.
Pay our individual artists for thier time. (Dancers, Technical Director, and Musicians)
Finish paying for our venue for both nights. ($952 remaining)
Help pay for promotional materials (Postcards, Posters - $300)

When you give $5 you will get a personalized hand-written thank you note from the choreographers!
When you give $20 you will recieve a shout out in our program as well as our facebook page!
When you give $50 you will recieve 2 tickets to the night of your choice and front row seating! This is an AWESOME PERK!

story:
What is Time Crawlers...?

The Time Crawlers Save the World began as Gina Stevensen's senior thesis project, produced by NYU/Tisch School of the Arts/Drama Department/Experimental Theatre Wing. Under the direction of Brooklyn-based theater artist Christopher Bowser, the play won first place at Manhattan Repertory Theatre’s LONG One Act Competition in March of 2012. The Time Crawlers Save the World will be seen next in conjunction with The Looking Glass space grant program at Looking Glass Theatre in NYC.

Jinx is a girl who loves words. When the apocalypse destroys the world, she escapes underground and buries herself in her dictionary, looking for a sign—but discovers time travel instead. Along with three supernerds and a talking cat, Jinx begins an adventure that will force her to face her own frightening future. This is a play about courage, adventure, and loss; a growing-up story for audiences young and old.

Who are the Time Crawlers?

Jinx // Gina Stevensen

Flux // Anna Elliott

Lawrence // Casey Deming

Gabe // Adam Donovan

Marie // Alyssa Block

Writer // Gina Stevensen

Director // Christopher Bowser

Promotional Design // Bailey Carr

Scenic, Costume, & Projection Design // Daniel Dabdoub

Lighting Design // Jonathan Cottle

Sound Design // Alex Thrailkill

Movement Coach // Cassandra Bowser

Stage Management // Liz Rogers

Photography // Videography Ernest Martin

What we need...

We are fortunate to have a space grant, but there are still many expenses involved in bringing this production to life.

Here's what your contribution could make possible

$10 pays for a prop 

$25 pays for printing materials such as scripts or posters or programs

$50 pays for costumes for one actor

$100 pays for two overhead projectors

$200 pays for the budget for scenic or lighting design

$500 pays for stipends for actors

I'm broke, but I still want to help...

Even $1 would mean you're helping save the world, but if now isn't the time to give for you, help us by spreading the word about our project and our goals!

And buy your ticket to come see our show this May!

Performances run Thursday through Saturday May 17-19th and Wednesday through Saturday May 23-26th. All performances are at 8pm at Looking Glass Theatre, 422 West 57th Street, downstairs, between 9th and 10th Ave. General admission tickets are $18, students and seniors $15.

Click here to buy tickets

story:
By contributing to this production you will be helping the newest crop of NYU Tisch Dramatic Writing MFA Film and TV writers launch their careers! 

This showcase will feature short, comedic, New York-themed scenes written by members of the Class of 2012, including Kaite Aymes, Yo Frank, John Marsh, Lily Mercer, Luisa Parnes, Donny Sheldon, Bianca Ursillo, Morgan Von Ancken, and Erin Wagoner.  Your contributions cover theater rental, professional actors, technical director, and publicity fees.  By supporting this project you will be providing this talented, diverse group of writers the extraordinary opportunity to jumpstart their careers by sharing their work with esteemed members of the entertainment industry!


Agents, producers, and directors will be treated to a pre-show cocktail hour and a full New York-style buffet after the show where they will be able to meet, mingle, and network with the writers.  This FREE, INDUSTRY ONLY event takes place on two nights, Sunday, October 21st and Monday, October 22nd at 7:00 PM at The Lost Studio, 130 South La Brea Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90036.  http://theloststudio.com/site  Ample street parking is available.

Your support is incredibly appreciated!

story:
UPDATE :: One of our performances has been awarded a matching grant.  "Watching Brief" will be supported by a Weisman Award (matching grant) which effectively doubles your contributions!

 

 

 

Pervious Embracing.

A year-long embodied adventure

Presenting movement layered with history, richness and sensation
Respecting all things awkward, daring and lively

Giving the audience rare proximity to the action
Offering insight through shifting perspectives
Unleashing the viewer as artist

Crafting performances that blend into the everyday
Blurring the boundaries of reality, time and place
Welcoming uncertainty, adaptability and humanity

Building community through experience

 

Be Moved.

MegLouise Dance has been crafting performance experiences for over a decade, but we are not your typical company.  We create movement events that uphold our ideal of embodied living. Our work challenges you to become more aware of your physical instincts and to appreciate the dynamics of the physical world surrounding your everyday.  These virtues inform our deeply personal, highly sensitized movement pieces.  Your financial contribution ensures that we can continue our work, reach out to new audiences and bring a beautiful dose of humanity to those who have forgotten what it feels like to be truly alive. This is your chance to get involved! 

MegLouise Dance has a successful track record of performance and installation.  The collective began in 2002 and has presented by invitation at the Junction Arts Festival in Toronto, DUMBO Dance Festival in New York, Cincinnati Fringe Festival and Ingenuity Festival in Ohio, to name only a few venues.  Learn about our work and past projects on our website www.meglouise.info.

 

More Specifically.

We are seeking your support for the 2013 MegLouise Dance season that wil include a collection of events and performances in loft spaces, dining rooms, galleries and other common dwellings.  All events will cater to an intentionally small gathering of guests (from 10 - 75 people) to maximize the impact of this delicate work. 

Every dollar you donate gets us closer to our goal.  Your contribution helps pay dancers for their time, sweat and expertise.  It also goes toward rehearsal space, equipment, costumes, advertising and insurance costs.  

Pervious Embracing 2013 Season

  • TOTAL EXPENSES = $12,000
  • $5,000 Performers Stipends ($100/ performance x 10 events x 5 performers)
  • $5,000 Shared Loft Space ($500/ month x 10 months)
  • $1,000 Production Expenses (costumes, lighting, video and sound)
  • $1,000 Marketing (print, web presence, email list-serve and other)

How will those expenses be covered?

  • $3,000 from Individual Supporters LIKE YOU!
  • $3,000 from Matching Grant *
  • $3,000 from Ticket Sales
  • $3,000 from Workshops & Services

Your gift keeps giving.  MegLouise Dance is seeking funding from private foundations and other organizations.  Those groups want to see that our supporters have invested in our success.  Show them how important our work is to you and watch your gift grow.

 

Do As Much As You Can.

You can support this work in so many ways.  In addition to donating, consider helping in other ways:

  • Tell Other People About Our Work
  • Share Our Request Page by Email, Facebook, Twitter. . .
  • Come to Our Events & Bring Others
  • Stay Involved by Signing Up for the ListServe

story:
Good Will for all!

Perhaps you, your family, and friends have built a decades-long tradition of Shakespeare-in-the-Parks.  Maybe you have yet seen only one (or none) of our performances.  No matter how many performances you have enjoyed, now is your opportunity to become a charter member of Friends of PAE and enjoy the benefits of membership.

PAE Past and Present

Our free Shakespeare-in-the-Parks has become a Portland summer tradition, reaching over 33,000 audience members during our last six seasons!  PAE has produced at least one Shakespearean play every summer for over forty years, making us one of the oldest continuously operating theatre companies in the city.  

PAE provides accesssible classical theatre

At Portland Actors Ensemble we bring financially accessible classical theater directly to Portland neighborhoods with two Shakespeare-in-the-Parks plays each year.  Each production features at least one sign-interpreted performance.  For many of our audience members, particularly families with children, our free productions may be their first or only theatre experience.

Shakespeare-in-the-Park is now as much a part of Portland summer as roses and sunshine! PAE enhances our community’s quality of life, offering live performances free of charge to all.  The power and beauty of William Shakespeare's work should be accessible to everyone.

Your contribution will help us to engage and retain the best local artists to provide consistently memorable productions.

Join Now!

Gifts are tax-deductible.  Friends and above will recieve a certificate in the mail which can be redeemed at any of our performances for a Shakespeare-in-the-Parks T-shirt.

Donate before June 2nd and be forever recognized as a charter member of Friends of PAE!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute funds, there are many other ways to help promote the mission of Portland Actors Ensemble:

  • Share this campaign via Facebook or Twitter, or using the share tools found on this site.
  • Volunteer to help at performances.  Email portlandactors@gmail.com to volunteer.
  • Get your workplace to sponsor PAE.
  • Spread the word about this campaign using email, Facebook and Twitter.
  • Help us advertise our performances in your community.  Become a Facebook friend of PortlandActorsEnsemble for news.
  • Become an advocate for the arts in your community.
  • Make sure that there is an audience tomorrow. Bring children and grandchildren to the performances.
Good Will for all!
Michael Godsey
Artistic Director, Portland Actors Ensemble

story:
In the world premiere of Frank Boudreaux's ...Other Elegant Lies, a raucous night at the theater is assured! 

As the audience enters the theater, they are swept into a highly exclusive (and comical) early-20th-century salon, led by Saint Fortune theater company. This lofty performance abruptly ends, however, as Lena and Maddie, our protagonists, attempt to crash the ‘Mens Only’ affair.

What follows is a bit of a theatrical circus: these impossibly smart and informed young women destroy Oxford's Bodley Library and escape to the woods where they create their own school, conducting outrageous experiments as teachers and pupils, both.

Maddie and Lena are desperate to succeed where ‘mankind’ (sic) has failed.  But even with their unique perspectives, an elegant explanation of the universe may still elude their grasp. 

WHAT WE NEED FROM YOU

... Everything That is the Case for Two Young Women ...
(help us pay our two actresses... and our designers!!!)

... On the Eve of The Great War ... 
(help us blow up our set every night!)

... Among Other Elegant Lies ...
(help us get makeup, props, costumes, lights, projections, and beer to make our theatrical lies a little more elegant!)


Then, COME JOIN US as 

EVERYTHING THAT IS THE CASE
FOR TWO YOUNG WOMEN
ON THE EVE OF THE GREAT WAR
AMONG OTHER ELEGANT LIES

premieres at the Incubator Arts Project

September 6th-9th, 11, 13th-16th @ 8pm

written and directed by
Frank Boudreaux

FEATURING
Winslow Corbett* and Megan Emery Gaffney*

THE CREATIVE TEAM

Production Design : Andreea Mincic
Costume Design : Emily King Brown
Lighting Design : Jeanette Yew
Sound Design : Juan Aboites
Choreographer : Katie-Rose McLaughlin
Video Engineer: Reid Farrington
Dramaturgical Support : Rachel Chavkin
Cinematographer : Marco Gualtieri
Stage Manager : Devorah Jaffe
Producer : Nora Deveau-Rosen
Production Consultant : John Henry Boudreaux
Production Manager : A.P. Andrews

Crew: Cat Crowley, Taylor Adamson

*appear courtesy of Actors Equity

STAY TUNED FOR MORE PRODUCTION UPDATES!

story:
Every ticket to this reading, and every donation you make extra, goes directly to funding our June production. Help us reach our goal! And read below to learn more about us and the project!

The next movement of Orchestra will be performed at: 

7PM on January 28, 2012
Manhattan Theatre Club Studios
311 West 43rd Street, 8th Floor

THE POINT

Orchestra is a play devoted to understanding life through the human voice and the individual experience. It is designed using a new form of writing that reflects life's fluidity. Created from each actor's speech pattern, each character in Orchestra is written to fit the individual artist.

THE PROCESS

Through an interview with the playwright, each character in Orchestra is crafted for the specific actor based on their thought patterns, diction, breath and expression. Over the next ten years, we aim to develop an ensemble the size of a symphony orchestra, filled with the unique voices of fifty-three individuals, the original musician count at the New York Philharmonic. With each new presentation of the script, our play evolves and expands.

Orchestra is a play written and rehearsed in a narrative form called a "score," one that charts the journeys of our characters like sheet music.  The score allows us to become infinitely more specific in what we want the audience to hear.  It displays the harmony and dissonance of these characters as the play progresses.  And most importantly, the score creates a common language - one that bridges the gap between playwright, director and actor.

 

THE PRODUCTION

On Monday January 28, we invite you to a reading of our 10-actor score. We will host an open discussion about the process and potential of Orchestra, and build from your feedback to make a production draft for our inaugural show in June 2013. 

THE PLAYERS

2013
ITO AGHAYERE / COCO MARIA BENOIT / RAFAEL BENOIT / WHITNEY DEARDEN / SARAH EISMANN / DANIELLE FAITELSON / SHANNON FILLION / KATE FLANAGAN / MELISSA GRAHAM / DAVE KLASKO / ADAM LUBITZ / BLAZE MANCILLAS / DANNY MITAROTONDO

story:
Having spent the majority of my life working and studying theater as a director, actor, writer, and producer, I have seen the opportunity to work on meaningful and quality projects quickly erode away.  Identifying this trend, it seemed time to do my part to reverse it, and to do it in a profound way.  So Herne's Oak Productions was established.  Herne's Oak Productions strives to strip away all affectation and spectacle that runs rampant in the theater and return to the simple pursuit of delving into the complex aspects of the human condition.  Drawing upon the talents of artists and performers from Long Island and the New York City area, together we will create events and performances that utilize the styles of classical, contemporary, and experimental theater, along with discovering some new styles along the way, that will challenge, enlighten, and engage audiences.  Herne's Oak Productions will bring theater back to its original and purest definition; of actors and audiences sharing in moments that are devoutly human and genuine.  Thereby fostering an environment of respect and accountability between artist and patron, actor and script, director and subject, we will show that theater will thrive on the sweat and tears of the dedicated.

 

So here's the deal, plain and simply, the money we raise goes towards our next productions.  If you can't donate a buck or two, PLEASE help spread the word about Herne's Oak.  We are a newly established company and yet with the two productions we have already done we have packed out the house for each and every performance.  I'm talkin' about hunting down spare chairs kinda packed.  If you do decide to donate, which we hope you do, then we have some perks for ya!  Enjoy!

P.S.- Please "Like" our Facebook fanpage: http://www.facebook.com/hernesoakproductions

P.P.S.- For updates on the show and company, also check out our website. http://www.hernesoakproductions.com/
story_txt:
Having spent the majority of my life working and studying theater as a director, actor, writer, and producer, I have seen the opportunity to work on meaningful and quality projects quickly erode away.  Identifying this trend, it seemed time to do my part to reverse it, and to do it in a profound way.  So Herne's Oak Productions was established.  Herne's Oak Productions strives to strip away all affectation and spectacle that runs rampant in the theater and return to the simple pursuit of delving into the complex aspects of the human condition.  Drawing upon the talents of artists and performers from Long Island and the New York City area, together we will create events and performances that utilize the styles of classical, contemporary, and experimental theater, along with discovering some new styles along the way, that will challenge, enlighten, and engage audiences.  Herne's Oak Productions will bring theater back to its original and purest definition; of actors and audiences sharing in moments that are devoutly human and genuine.  Thereby fostering an environment of respect and accountability between artist and patron, actor and script, director and subject, we will show that theater will thrive on the sweat and tears of the dedicated.
 
So here's the deal, plain and simply, the money we raise goes towards our next productions.  If you can't donate a buck or two, PLEASE help spread the word about Herne's Oak.  We are a newly established company and yet with the two productions we have already done we have packed out the house for each and every performance.  I'm talkin' about hunting down spare chairs kinda packed.  If you do decide to donate, which we hope you do, then we have some perks for ya!  Enjoy!
P.S.- Please "Like" our Facebook fanpage: http://www.facebook.com/hernesoakproductions
P.P.S.- For updates on the show and company, also check out our website. http://www.hernesoakproductions.com/

story:
Our Story

About three years ago, Anna found a nonfiction book at The Strand about a little-known woman robber in 1920s Brooklyn named Celia Cooney. Poor and pregnant, all Celia wanted was to get a little more money to give her baby a nicer life than she and her husband Ed could provide. Their solution: rob a grocery store. Of course, just one grocery store spiraled into two, then four, until they found themselves deeper than they intended.


Celia's story made such an impact on Anna that she pitched an idea to Britt: Anna would write book and lyrics, and Britt the music, for a musical adaptation. They started work on it, and eventually had enough material to apply to the New York International Fringe Festival - and got in! Now they need to fund their production to show everyone how wonderful Celia Cooney is.


The Impact

We are assembling a crack creative team to help us shape what is now just words and music on paper into a living, breathing musical. Theater is a collaborative medium, and we absolutely cannot do this without you guys, our producers!


What We Need

Putting on a show, even a little show like ours, takes money. And even a little bit helps. For example, $5 can pay for copies of the script. $20 from you could buy us an hour of rehearsal space in a studio. (We want our show to be great, so we're going to need plenty of those!) $150 could get us wigs for all our girls. $600 can cover the FringeNYC registration fee.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know you can't all give us $5000 or even $100. But if you donate $5 and then tell 5 friends to donate $5, well, that's like $25 more you're responsible for! Think of the possibilities! What we're saying is - tell your friends.

story:
Random Access Theatre is raising funds for our first full length production - "Highway Blue," an original piece written by the talented Caroline Prugh and directed by RAT Artistic Director Jennifer Sandella. We are working in conjunction with producer David Carpenter and Manhattan Shakespeare Project to bring this beautiful new work to life.

Off a dusty highway in the American Southwest, two gas pumps attempt to help a pair of star-crossed lovers reconcile their pasts and rekindle their love. This daring new musical play by Caroline Prugh provides an unexpected journey on the traditional road to finding perfect happiness and love everlasting.

David Carpenter in association with Random Access Theatre and Manhattan Shakespeare Project present: Highway Blue Written by Caroline Prugh
Musical Direction/Orchestration by Eli Zoller
Directed by Jennifer Sandella

Stage Manager: Alejandra Duque
ASM: Janette Valenzo
Set Design: Ashley Cusack
Costume Design: Wayne LeForm
Lighting Design: Abby Hoke-Brady
Marketing/Design: Ito Aghayere
Dramaturg: Ellen Joffred
MSP Producers: Sarah Eisman, Karly Fischer

Featuring: Bailey Means, Beth Kuhn, Jaime Hastings, Jonathon Grunert, Garen McRoberts*, Kari Ringer*
*denotes a member of actors equity

July 21, 22, 23, 27, 28, 29. 30 @8pm
July 23 @2pm
August, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6 @8pm
Tickets $18 For tickets and theater information please visit www.theplayerstheatre.com

Please also visit www.manhattanshakes.org and www.randomaccesstheatre.com

About Random Access Theatre: Random access is about working in the moment and choosing projects that drive and inspire rather than striving to fit into the box of a well rounded mission statement. We choose work that chooses us. We bring a fresh eye to the classics and explore new work as if it were a classic text. We change location constantly suiting the performance space to the piece, we use text, we devise, we revive and we create work that is uniquely our own stemming from the combined passions of each member. Each member of the group is encouraged to work in all areas of production; you never know what you truly love to do until you try your hand at doing it. We stand behind each other as we grow, learn, take shape, and reform. The theatre is an evolutionary process and we believe that our members, as artists, should be looked at in the same way.

story:
Short Summary

Technology is passing us by.....

For 20 years Cinematique of Daytona has been dedicated to screening the highest quality Independent and Foreign films available for the residents and visitors to Daytona Beach, Florida. 

After several re-locations, in Novovember 2010 we were able to open our first ever dedicated Art House Cinema.  It has been a fantastic achievement and addition to our community that has allowed us to show more films and programs than ever before.   

Since opening the doors, we have experienced some growing pains.  Although the building was newly renovated, much of our equipment was not.  In an effort to provide the highest quality theater experience and to celebrate our 20th anniversary, we would like to make upgrades to our theater projection and sound equipment, audience seating and ticketing, and make improvements to our Café service and selections. 

What We Need 

  

  • A New digital HD Cinema Projector
  • 7.1 digital surround sound system
  •  more couches and a row of arm chairs with side tables
  •  New Point of Sale box office and concession equipment
  •  Improved hallway and door system to limit the light and noise entering the theater when food is delivered

 

& What You Get

     

  • Movie Tickets
  • Private Theater Party
  • Outdoor Movie Party
  • Recognition and Thanks

 

The Impact

Show your support of Indie films! 

Don't let our theater join the many other Indepent movie theaters around the county that have been forced to close because they could not afford the theater upgrades they needed! With your help we will be sure to provide the highest quality film experience.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Keep the momentum going:  

  • Help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.  Post on your Face Book, invite your friends and fellow Independent Film Fans.
  • You can also  use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Tell Me About BITE THE APPLE

Cinderella is a past-her-prime trophy wife, Red Ridinghood lurks outside bars waiting for the wolf, and Snow White wants to kill her kids. Your favorite fairytale princesses are clearly beyond their “happily ever after,” which path do they take from here?

“Bite the Apple” is a new play by Linda Manning, being produced at the New York International Fringe Festival this August through our theatre company, The Other Mirror. We are thrilled to be spending our summer working with an amazing cast, creative team, and new Fringe friends, but cannot mount this production without your help.

What Will My Donation Provide?

Our goal with this campaign is to raise $2,500 – approximately half of our production’s entire budget. Here are some of the costs that your donation will be put towards:

-$850: Fringe Costs ($650 Fee, $100 Venue, $100 Load In/Out)

-$150: Audition Space 

-$1,000: Sets, Costumes, Sound, and Props (Physical Production Only)  

Tell Me About THE OTHER MIRROR

"The Other Mirror is the kind of theatrical company that is the lifeblood of contemporary theater. It’s young, energetic, creative and fearless, with none of the excesses that make theater irrelevant."      - Paulanne Simmons, NY Theatre Wire

The Other Mirror is a not-for-profit theatre company comprised of artists interested in exploring theatre through adaptation. We began our work with “Bite the Apple” through an adaptations workshop with The Director’s Company early in 2011. Our artistic director, Katherine Carter and playwright, Linda Manning continued workshopping the script in the year that followed. After a successful run of “Madame Bovary” through a residency with 3LD Art & Technology Center in December, the company decided to re-visit “Bite the Apple” with a staged reading at An Beal Bocht Café in the Bronx. It was following this reading that company members decided to submit the play to the Fringe Festival. We are honored to be included in this year’s selection of plays, and (through your generosity) are looking forward to bringing this production to fruition.  For more information on The Other Mirror, please visit www.theothermirrortheatre.com.

What if I can’t donate?

We at The Other Mirror understand that sometimes monetary donations are too much to ask for. If you would like to find out about other ways you can help support our production through publicity, volunteering, etc. please contact Amy (Producer) via e-mail at BiteTheAppleProd@gmail.com

story:
Who We Are

We are Dance Project SEQUENCE, Inc., a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization based in New York, NY, USA. The organization was established by and is run by a Japanese director and Japanese performing artists. We conduct varied cultural activities, including cultural courses for young children, in the organization's dance studio, the Arts Cure Center,


How This Project Was Born

When we looked at the children who were coming to our organization for the first time, we found that almost all of them were of Japanese descent, either born here or brought here when they were very young. We thought that these children, growing up in this society and culture, might eventually forget their own background, and might well have identity issues as they grow up. We wanted to give them a chance to experience their roots by using our own disciplines, the performing arts.  In this way we came upon the idea of a dance/theater/music production based on Japanese folk tales.  We wanted to include as many different people as possible who wished to join this project, and to include the children who take our classes.  In this way, everybody would be able to present what he or she is best at, at the same time that a Japanese folk tale unfolds. This is how the Arts Cure Folktale Project was born.


Our Projects

So far, we have presented two stories on stage, "Urashima Taro", about a young fisherman who saves a bullied turtle and then meets and falls in love with a princess of the deep sea, and "Kaguya-Hime", a mysterious, beautiful woman born out of a bamboo stalk on the earth who eventually goes back to her home on the moon.  In the course of creating each production, we were overwhelmed with the beauty of our folktales that we thought we knew so well. We realized that this project inspires not only children but also adults of all nationalities.

Our Issue

However, we have always had one serious issue: We never have enough money to cover the costs of the presentations. We need funds for theater rental, tech people, performers, staff members, props, costumes, and sets. The list is endless. Even though we have been funded by New York City, and the director and students financially support the project, we always have money issues. To improve the productions and bring them to more children and their parents, we seriously need support for the productions.  Also, we would like to stage other folktales.

We have set our current goal at $10,000, the minimum amount necessary for this kind of project. We will be very careful of how we spend what has been warmly offered to us. If we are fortunate enough to make more than our goal, we will be sure that anysurplus is paid to our guest performers, to our instructors who also perform in the production, tothe technicians, and to those who support the productions in invisible ways.  Even if we donot reach our goal, we will create the best presentationthatwecan from what we receive.

Varied Ways to Help Us

If you cannot help us with money, we can also use, and will be grateful for, any materials or volunteer labor that is offered. Please contact us to discuss further how you can become involved.  Also, please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word to your friends or just talk about us or forward e-mails about us to your friends. Anything could be a help to us!

Our next performance will be Sunday, June 21st, 2015.

Donate to us. Come to see us. Be part of us.

story:
What is The Bone House?

The Bone House is a spine-chilling, immersive theatrical experience written by Edmonton playwright Marty Chan and being produced by a new Calgary-based artistic collective called Apparition Theatre. We're running this show in the Motel Theatre from October 22nd through November 1st. 

The show takes the form of a lecture about serial killers, though as it progresses, it takes a series of progressively darker turns, and the audience finds themselves in the midst of what promises to be a scary night in the theatre. If you'd like to read more about the show, please visit our Facebook event page.

Why an Indiegogo Campaign?

This show is entirely centered around our ability to create a scary experience for the audience. In order to do this, it was important for us to produce the show in a small, intimate theatre where you're up close and personal with the performance. However, that choice also comes with limitations, as we can only sell about 40 tickets per performance.

In order to bring out all the scares, we require a slew of special effects and equipment, including specialized stage weapons, blood effects, night vision goggles and more - and these things are quite expensive. Our box office revenue alone won't provide what we need to successfully produce the show. 

As a new artistic collective, we're operating without any government funding or established revenue sources, and so we're seeking your support in order to help us create this unique theatrical experience for audiences in Calgary, while offering what we feel are some very exciting perks in the process.

What We Need & What You Get

We've set a fundraising goal of $1500.00, which will go toward the cost of the special effects used and the running costs of the show.

In exchange for your donation, we're able to provide our donors some special Bone House-related experiences, including admission to an exclusive, donors-only, behind-the-scenes presentation where we'll show off the special effects and equipment used in the show.

And if you really want to have some fun, we have perks which also include the opportunity to bring an unsuspecting friend with you to the show, where we'll include their name and other personal information in the show in a way that will really bring on the chills and will not soon be forgotten!

Who We Are

We're a team with a lot of past experience in producing independent theatre, and it's our hope that Apparition Theatre can create other great theatrical experiences for a variety of artists and audiences in the future.

Apparition Theatre currently consists of Simon Mallett, Mike Griffin, Olivia Brooks, Justin Michael Carriere, Mark Ikeda, Brianna Johnston and Tyler Longmire. We'd all be immensely grateful for your support of our project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about the show and our Indiegogo campaign. As a new collective, we don't have much of a marketing budget, so word of mouth is our best ally in order to have as many folks see the show as possible. Share our Facebook event page or direct people to our website at www.bonehouse.ca. We'd greatly appreciate your help in getting the word out there!

story:
HAVING TROUBLE DONATING? 

CLICK HERE to donate directly

Clinard Dance’s productions are the result of years of work, of sustained, collaborative inquiry into a huge range of ideas. This inquiry can take many forms but it always brings together people from a range of disciplines and different backgrounds. Our current piece, Chicago’s Watershed: A 156-Mile Choreography, premiered at the at University of Chicago’s Reva and David Logan Center for the Arts in the summer of 2014 after two years of research and development. 

We will remount the work in April, 2016 at University of Chicago’s Center in Beijing, and we’re asking your help to put Chicago’s Watershed... through one last phase of refinement.

In developing the work, Artistic Director Wendy Clinard took Stravinsky’s revolutionary The Rite of Spring as a starting point for an examination of the ebb and flow of life along the Chicago River. The music is presented in a stripped down form with an arrangement for four-hands performed by the EStrella Piano Duo and accompanied by Dmitry Samarov’s video-projected ink work. At the heart of the piece is Clinard’s unique style of American flamenco, presenting a rhythmic dialogue between the city, its inhabitants and the river.

From the 2014 premiere, the Company has a better understanding of possible design improvements, in conveying meaningful content and choreography, as well as better understand some technical challenges that must be overcome.

Your donation will help support:

  • Choreographic revisions- There are passages Clinard would like to update with a greater focus on the percussive flamenco footwork and improvisation

  • Updated video capture of Samarov’s ink painting- Creating new images and higher quality versions of several visual sequences in the piece

  • New flooring and costumes- White marley on the floor to support the black ink work as well as have costumes made specifically for the piece—we reused existing costumes in this iteration—to create a more contemporary feel.

  • Purchase three new black mantons (ornamental flamenco shawls) for the Bejing performances. The company does not have mantons of its own.

    Please donate to our campaign today to help us complete this project!Thank you for your support.

*Clinard Dance is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization. All donations are tax-deductible.

Please donate to our campaign today to help us complete this project!
Thank you for your support.
story_txt:
HAVING TROUBLE DONATING? CLICK HERE to donate directlyClinard Dance’s productions are the result of years of work, of sustained, collaborative inquiry into a huge range of ideas. This inquiry can take many forms but it always brings together people from a range of disciplines and different backgrounds. Our current piece, Chicago’s Watershed: A 156-Mile Choreography, premiered at the at University of Chicago’s Reva and David Logan Center for the Arts in the summer of 2014 after two years of research and development. We will remount the work in April, 2016 at University of Chicago’s Center in Beijing, and we’re asking your help to put Chicago’s Watershed... through one last phase of refinement.In developing the work, Artistic Director Wendy Clinard took Stravinsky’s revolutionary The Rite of Spring as a starting point for an examination of the ebb and flow of life along the Chicago River. The music is presented in a stripped down form with an arrangement for four-hands performed by the EStrella Piano Duo and accompanied by Dmitry Samarov’s video-projected ink work. At the heart of the piece is Clinard’s unique style of American flamenco, presenting a rhythmic dialogue between the city, its inhabitants and the river.From the 2014 premiere, the Company has a better understanding of possible design improvements, in conveying meaningful content and choreography, as well as better understand some technical challenges that must be overcome.Your donation will help support:
Choreographic revisions- There are passages Clinard would like to update with a greater focus on the percussive flamenco footwork and improvisation
Updated video capture of Samarov’s ink painting- Creating new images and higher quality versions of several visual sequences in the piece
New flooring and costumes- White marley on the floor to support the black ink work as well as have costumes made specifically for the piece—we reused existing costumes in this iteration—to create a more contemporary feel. 

Purchase three new black mantons (ornamental flamenco shawls) for the Bejing performances. The company does not have mantons of its own.Please donate to our campaign today to help us complete this project!Thank you for your support.
*Clinard Dance is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization. All donations are tax-deductible.
Please donate to our campaign today to help us complete this project!Thank you for your support.

story:
Award-winning theatre company Little Soldier Productions needs your support to make their third show: Derailed. We’ve always been ambitious, but with this show we want to change the world.

Hopefully. Maybe.

Using elements of physical theatre, storytelling, intimate confession and live music, ‘Derailed’ is about politics and rock & roll.

(Or maybe it's just about rock & roll)

This is not an advert. We're not campaigning for a political party. We're not sure what we think or what we want. There are strong convictions but no plan. Just yet.

The success of this campaign is vital to the show. Times are tough at the moment and having had several funding applications rejected purely due to high competition for funds, it’s now make or break for us. We’re due to open the show at new venue Home, Manchester on the 6th April. Even the smallest amount will help us to get there. Larger amounts will make sure we do it in true Little Soldier style.

About the company:

Who are we? If you have seen one of our shows you have probably met us in person before, during or after our shows and if not, please let us know! We would love to meet you! We are Patricia Rodriguez  and Merce Ribot, two actresses joined by producer Bridget Floyer. We love to present stories with humor and tragedy, with music and all sorts of tools that we might find in our very open - often crazy - working process. We get inspired from classic novels to new writing and in 2016 we wanted to challenge ourselves by making a show that would make a difference and why not? Since we were on it we thought let’s make one that will change the world.

We have performed extensively in the UK and internationally in Warsaw, Madrid and New York. We have been critically acclaimed by public and press, including The Stage, Time Out and Exeunt. Our previous show ‘You and Me’ was awarded an Argus Angel at the Brighton Fringe 2014 and ‘The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha’ received the Stage Award for Acting Excellence at the Edinburgh Fringe 2014.

So if you have come this far you might want to know HOW TO HELP US...

It’s not just about money (though right now, that’s important). Whether or not you feel able to donate, if you can spread the word on and off-line, that’s hugely valuable to us. And please: come and see the show!

SCRATCH: Battersea Arts Centre, Thu 24 March (link)

OPENING: Home, Manchester, Thu 7 - Sat 9 April

story:
Who we are. Why you should help. 

Thank you very much for taking the time to read a little more about who we are and what we are going to be able to accomplish with your contribution.

Peregrine Theatre Ensemble Founding Members

Adam Berry Executive Producer

 Ben Berry Artistic Director

 Tessa Bry Taylor Managing and Education Director

 

  • Peregrine Theatre Ensemble is a sponsored organization of the Provincetown Community Compact (PCC). Under PCC we are provided with a subsidiary 501(c)3 status and administrative services that enable our donors to make secure tax-deductible contributions.

 

  • Peregrine Theatre Ensemble is a professional performing arts company aiming to continue the tradition of quality theatre that has enriched the unique culture of Provincetown for decades. Our goal is to produce works that are developed through a dedicated artistic process and reflect a wide array of theatrical genres. We strive to cultivate and educate audiences of all ages through performance, workshops, and classes, and foster artistic relationships with other nonprofit organizations, resulting in increased sustainability for the Provincetown community. 

 

  • This campaign is extremely important because all of our funding comes directly from small donations. We cannot produce this amazing piece of theatre without your contribution and support. All of the money funded with this campaign goes directly to the production of this play.

 

  • This is Peregrine Theatre Ensembles' inaugural production. We have been working all summer performing other small productions and events to introduce our new company to the Cape Cod community. We premiered a play by Eugene O'Neill that was written in Provincetown in 1919 but had never been performed. In July we produced a concert called "Provincetown Musicals Through The Decades" where we celebrated musicals that many of our ensemble members participated in during the last 11 years. It was a thrilling success which remind the community just how talented its residents are. It also demonstrated the direction in which we would like to continue to go towards producing and performing dramatic and inspiring musicals. Now we have a chance to produce the play Blithe Spirit at the Julie Harris stage this October. It will be our first "real" production, performed Friday through Sunday for three weeks. It will finally give us a chance to show the world just what we can do with proper space, lighting, costumes and sets with some other best trained actors in the country. With your contribution this can happen, it will happen and you will have made it possible. 

What is our Budget? What is your reward?

Your contribution will fund:

  • Royalties $1,000
  • Theatre Rental Fees $5,000
  • Paying the Actors $4,000
  • Costume Designer $1,000 +
  • Lighting Designer $1,000 +
  • Set Designer $1,000 +
  • Advertisement $500
  • Equity Contract  $2,800
  • Design Materials $1,000
  • Costume Materials $500
  • Costume Rentals $500
  • Stage Manager $500
  • Miscellaneous 500 +

We are excited to have many different levels of contributions and amazing rewards that go along with each monetary amount. With most of our patron amounts you can customize your perk and choose between a "Paranormal Perk", where Adam Berry from the SYFY original series Ghost Hunters will sign and send a reward geared toward the TV series such as a T-shirt, an autographed picture or a personal Tweet from him or a "Theatrical Perk" which is an award more focused on the Peregrine Theatre Ensemble, such as tickets, t-shirts and exclusive access to a private rehearsal of Blithe Spirit. 

All of the funds that we raise will go to this production of Blithe Spirit. The "show must go on" but the final amount of contributions will determine how grand this production will be. So the more you donate, the more we receive and the more professional and polished our inaugural production will be.

Detailed list of rewards:

$10

I want to see production photos

For your contribution of $10 dollars you will have the privilege of knowing that you helped make this show possible. You really want to see those production photos that would not have been possible if you didn't make this donation! These photos will be posted on our website www.peregrinetheatre.com shortly after opening night! Enjoy!

Paranormal Perk $25

For your contribution of $25 dollars Adam will personally tweet or email a "Thank You" directed towards you! Please include your @twitter name or email so he can reach out to you!

Theatrical Perk $25

For your contribution of $25 dollars you will be emailed a special link to a trailer and bonus footage of our production of Blithe Spirit to show you what all of your support helped us accomplish.

Paranormal Perk $50

For your contribution of $50 dollars you will receive an autographed Ghost Hunter picture postcard. Also your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill.

Theatrical Perk $50

For your contribution of $50 dollars you will receive a combative inaugural Blithe Spirit production postcard signed by the Peregrine Theatre Ensemble founding members. Also your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill. 

Paranormal Perk $100

For a contribution of $100 dollars you will receive an "Evolution of Ghosts" T-shirt (which can be seen at www.adam-berry.com/merchandise.html) as well as an autographed Ghost Hunter picture postcard from Adam. Also your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill. 

Theatrical Perk $100

For your contribution of $100 dollars you will receive a "Peregrine Theatre Ensemble" T-shirt and a commemorative inaugural Blithe Spirit production postcard signed by the Peregrine Theatre Ensemble founding members. Also your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill.

Paranormal Perk $250 Tax Deductible

For your contribution of $250 dollars Adam will personally call you on the phone and thank you for your contribution and you can chat about your own ghostly experiences or ask questions. You will also receive an "Evolution of Ghosts" T-shirt, a signed Ghost Hunter picture postcard and an autographed headshot all from Adam. . Plus your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill.

Theatrical Perk $250 Tax Deductible

For your contribution of $250 dollars you will receive a Peregrine Theatre Ensemble T-shirt, a commemorative inaugural Blithe Spirit production postcard signed by the Peregrine Theatre founding members and two tickets to the VIP party at opening night of Blithe Spirit on October 4th. Also your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill. (VIP party tickets will be emailed separately and earlier than the other items)

$500 Tax Deductible

For your contribution of $500 dollars you will receive two tickets to a performance of Blithe Spirit on a date of your choosing. Plus you will receive a Peregrine Theatre Ensemble T-shirt, a commemorative inaugural Blithe Spirit production postcard signed by the Peregrine Theatre founding members and two tickets to the VIP party at opening night of Blithe Spirit October 4th. Also your name will be listed as a patron in the Blithe Spirit playbill. (Show tickets will be arranged prior to opening night and VIP party invitations will be emailed separately and earlier than the other items)

$1,000 Tax Deductible

Pay a Designer or an Actor’s Salary

For your generous contribution of $1,000 dollars you will have enabled the actor to make a small living doing what they love or enable that performer to go on stage fully clothed, in amazing light surrounded by an immaculate set.

To show our appreciation you will receive an invitation to attend a closed rehearsal with the cast to witness how it all comes together behind the scenes as well as 4 tickets to a Blithe Spirit performance date of your choice plus 4 tickets to the VIP party at opening night of Blithe Spirit on October 4. Along with these special items you will be mailed a Peregrine Theatre Ensemble T-shirt and a commemorative inaugural Blithe Spirit production postcard signed by the Peregrine Theatre founding members. Also your name will be listed as a Founding Sponsor in our Blithe Spirit playbill. (Closed rehearsal attendance and show tickets will be arranged prior to opening night as well as VIP party invitations will be emailed separately and earlier than the other items)

$5,000 Tax Deductible 

Pay the rental fee at the Julie Harris Stage and be listed as a Producer.

For your unbelievable donation of $5,000 dollars you will have secured the rental of the Julie Harris Stage, which enables us to actually perform Blithe Spirit! 

In return you will receive a private dinner with Adam Berry, Ben Berry and Tessa Bry Taylor, founding members of the Peregrine Theatre Ensemble, at a local restaurant on the Outer Cape. (Transportation and hotel not provided). Furthermore you will receive an invitation to attend a closed rehearsal with the cast to witness how it all comes together behind the scenes as well as 6 invitations to the final dress rehearsal on October 2nd. Plus you will be awarded 8 tickets to a Blithe Spirit performance date of your choice (can be split with multiple dates and given to friends for use) along with 8 tickets to the VIP party at opening night of Blithe Spirit on October 4th where you will be acknowledged as an honored guest. Along with these special items you will be mailed a Peregrine Theatre Ensemble T-shirt and a commemorative inaugural Blithe Spirit production postcard signed by the Peregrine Theatre founding members. Also your name will be listed as a Producer in our Blithe Spirit playbill. (Dinner with the founding members, closed rehearsal attendance and show tickets will be arranged prior to opening night as well as VIP party invitations will be emailed separately and earlier than the other items)

You.

As we have said this already but I will point it out again, YOU are the reason this project will succeed. You are the last character in this production because without your contribution Blithe Spirit will not be possible. We dedicate each and every performance to you and your generosity. 

Spread the word, please. 

Thank you in advance for your contribution. Now the next and final step is to share our campaign to your friends and family. Please email our link and info to those who you believe will be just as passionate about our show as you are. Post on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vimeo and other social media sites in which you participate to help get the word out! This is the most important thing you can do for us besides making a financial contribution. Retweet, share and support!

story:
Hello there! 

I am Steph Salts the creator of the project “Weee-Oooo, We You.” I have been in the professional dance world for about 8 years, working with Oakland Ballet, Utah Regional Ballet, Post:Ballet, and my current employer, Lustig Dance Theatre. These companies have given me the opportunity to perform a variety of work ranging from classical ballet to very contemporary and improvisational styles.

After many years of a budding interest in choreography, I have finally found my voice in this project. 

WOWY is a contemporary dance piece set to the music of Boston musician, Andrew Eckel. The music was the main inspiration of the piece because of it's vivid imagery found in his lyrics and melodies. Andrew performs with us live by singing and interacting with us as part of our story. Though WOWY is full of movement, it could be viewed as very theatrical and experimental. 

The piece follows two identical(ish) girls (Monica Gonzalez and myself) who find themselves traveling through a wonderland of sorts.They aren't sure that everything in this place can be assumed to be what it was where they came from. The mystery also lies in where the "twins" came from to begin with and how they interact with all the new people and objects that they meet along way.  

Though I am the main mind behind the work, WOWY thrives off of its highly collaborative creation process. I am so curious about this place myself, I keep asking my friends to get involved and help me discover and explore what it could mean for all of us. Which has been something amazing to see - a seed of my own idea turn into a reality for others. 

The video a the top of the page includes clips from our performance at the Green Building in Brooklyn last November. We have been privileged to perform several times around New York, had a showing in Boston on March 15, and now we have the invitation to premier our world, in full, at the San Francisco Conservatory of Dance in July! (We are pumped!) 

I am thrilled to have 10 dancers agree to commit to the expansion, plus Andrew Eckel. 7 of us will be flying from the east coast and we will join 4, SF based dancers to assemble our efforts. Piece by piece, my dreams are coming true! 

The support we raise will be used mainly to purchase plane tickets, but could also go towards costumes, studio rentals, and housing.

story:
On (a)Mantis

by Milica Ilić composer and librettist

The concept of this piece aims to give a different view on opera, offering a interesting thriller story, which is supposed to be closely followed by the audience. The music of the piece is accessible and flirting both with classical and popular musical traditions, but using all the possibilities of an operatic voice. It is written for a small ensemble which makes possible to make a sort of intimate atmosphere, allowing the audience to respond more directly and spontaneously to the piece. They should watch and enjoy this opera in a similar way as they would at home, watching their favorite TV series.  

Therefore, on one level this piece aims to combine the different elements of operatic and TV genres, in order to create a new theater format which can use the best of both worlds but also to expose, interpret and deconstruct the stereotypes connected to them.

The artistic team of this production consists of young singers, from different countries whose cultural differences also add to this project, making it even more interesting and fresh.

We need your help to make this project live!

Thank you!
*This production is supported by the City of Gent, Provincie Oost - Vlaanderen, and IOA, Gent.
story_txt:
On (a)Mantis
by Milica Ilić composer and
librettist
The concept of this piece
aims to give a different view on opera, offering a interesting thriller story,
which is supposed to be closely followed by the audience. The music of the
piece is accessible and flirting both with classical and popular musical
traditions, but using all the possibilities of an operatic voice. It is written
for a small ensemble which makes possible to make a sort of intimate
atmosphere, allowing the audience to respond more directly and spontaneously to
the piece. They should watch and enjoy this opera in a similar way as they
would at home, watching their favorite TV series.  
Therefore, on one level
this piece aims to combine the different elements of operatic and TV genres,
in order to create a new theater format which can use the best of both worlds
but also to expose, interpret and deconstruct the stereotypes connected to them.
The artistic team of this
production consists of young singers, from different countries whose cultural
differences also add to this project, making it even more interesting and
fresh.

story:
After our critically acclaimed maiden effort "Holiday in my Head" last year, Asylum Theatre is back in 2015 with Alfred Hitchcock's "The 39 Steps".

"The 39 Steps" is a blissfully funny mix of Alfred Hitchcock thriller and Monty Python buffoonery. It's a fast-paced hysterical whodunit for anyone who loves the magic of theatre!

Adapted by Patrick Barlow from the novel by John Buchan and inspired by the Alfred Hitchcock film, this two-time Tony and Olivier Award winning play is packed with laughs and over 100 zany characters played by four fearless actors.

This side-splittingly hilarious show follows the incredible adventures of our handsome hero, Richard Hannay, a man falsely accused of murder, as he encounters dastardly villains, double agents, and devastatingly beautiful women.

Ben Brantley of the The New York Times calls it "theatre at its finest" while The New York Post raves it is "inventively astonishing, riotous and marvelous!"

Directed by Asylum Theatres award-winning Artistic Director, Dean Lundquist, The 39 Steps features a brilliant international ensemble: Tim Garner (Holiday in my Head, The Boys in the Band, Take Me Out, Company), Paul Lucas (Holiday in my Head, Take Me Out, 251, The Joy of Solitude) and Victoria Mintey (A Singaporean in Paris, Fantastic Mr. Fox, Twelfth Night) with Andrew Mowatt (Holiday in my Head, Dear Nora, The Crucible).

We need to raise much more than our $500 goal to make up the difference from projected ticket sales and production expenses.

Some of our big ticket items are as follows:

Licensing fees: $4,000

Costumes: $1,000

Sets/Costumes: $1000

Please help us out and take advantage of some pretty cool perks!

story:
My goal:

My goal is to travel to London in August 2015 to train for a week at Dance Adventures, a contemporary dance intensive lead by some of the most innovative and inspiring choreographers today. 


My love affair with dance:

I was 8 years old when I took my first dance class. The first dance I learned and performed was cowgirl themed, it was silly and I loved it. This was nearly 13 years ago. I loved the way I felt when I danced. I loved people watching me dance. I loved the focus and freedom dance required. I loved how connected it made me with my body. Movement became my first language and my way of processing and interpreting the world. Dance made sense when everything else didn't. It held me together when I felt like falling apart. Dance was me and I was dance.


For many years I danced in my hometown's studio's student companies and performed regularly. I developed a passion for choreography and began creating dances for the annual student showcases. From those showcases I was offered several jobs teaching regular classes for local dance studios and opportunities to perform and choreograph for local professional dance companies - all when I was just 15 years old.

When I turned 16, I suffered from a herniated disc, which pressed onto my spinal cord, aggravating my sciatic nerve and causing searing pain down my right leg. I couldn't walk for several weeks, which meant dance was out of the question. Naturally, this immobility caused me to become depressed and angry. I had lost the thing that allowed me to connect with the world and myself. I had lost dance. I received a steroid shot in my spine to alleviate some of the inflammation and pain. But this was just the beginning of 5 long years of pain, struggle, with little to no dancing. With flare-ups and back spasms, my pain never seemed to let up. In fact, some days it was worse than ever. Dance, the thing that was me, was now a stranger and was actually causing me physical pain. 

"Patience with your body." That was my mantra. With patience and more patience, I began to heal. Slowly I started to dance again. Everyday I danced I felt the fire within me grow larger, my body grow stronger, my heart grow bigger, and my passion for dance become louder. Today, I am dancing. I am dancing whenever and where ever I can. I can not say I am 100% healed, but I am dancing. I take it slow and remember to thank my body constantly for being so strong. I see my dreams of dance bright and full and I want to chase that dream down. I want dance to be my future. Dance will be my future. 

This program focuses on contemporary dance specifically. It recruits some of the best and youngest teacher/choreographers today. Dance Adventures takes place in an intimate setting which explores movement in a supportive and creative way. This program is designed to inspire. This is an opportunity to dance and learn with up and coming talents. In addition to classes, I will experience London, a city full of performance art like dance, theatre, and music. Having never traveled in my life, the added bonus of being in a city so different from my own, while experiencing dance in such an intense setting, would be an absolute dream come true.\

Where your support goes:

Your support will help me in several different ways:

The biggest expense is airfare. Naturally, I want to find the best deal possible. On average, airfare from California to London costs between $800-$1250. Tips for finding cheap and safe flights helps out as well! Sharing travel tips and advice is just as helpful as donating. Support beyond finances is greatly appreciated!

Second is the cost of the intensive itself. The total cost of the intensive and purchase fees is $390.94 (£261.90) This covers all classes and some meals while I am in the intensive. To secure my spot, I will be put down a non refundable deposit of $77 (£55) which is taken out of the total cost. The remaining balance must be paid off but June 1st.

The remaining money raised will cover room and board, other necessaries while I am in London and a little cushion for unexpected events. 

The effect:

These kinds of trips and experiences are so incredibly important for a young artist. The chance to meet new people, explore a culture that is busting at the seams with art and dance, and dance with teachers and peers that will inspire for years after. Who wouldn't want to dance their heart out in a beautiful city?!

Can't donate? You can still help!

Donating is amazing, your generosity and belief in me is unreal, but that's not the only way you can help. Kind words and good vibes are just as appreciated! Connections to other people and opportunities are also amazing - maybe you're a cool person or know some cool people living in London that will open your/their home to me while I'm in the UK. Maybe you have the hook ups for cheap airfare. Or, maybe you pass this campaign onto a friend or share it on your social media- help get the word out! All forms of support- financial or good vibes- are appreciated!


THANK YOU

Thank you for giving me your time to share my love of dance. Thank you for donating. Thank you for the kind words. Thank you for your support and love. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
Every semester at NYU Tisch School of the Arts, students have the opportunity to propose a show to produce. When approved, the team gets the opportunity to put on a completely student-run show. 

As part of the Fall 2012 Gap season at the NYU Tisch School of the Arts, we are presenting Sarah Ruhl's Passion Play. 

 

the play

Imagine taking on the role of the most famous figure in history, year after year. In Passion Play, we see the pressures placed on communities throughout history as they attempt to reenact the Passion of Christ. 

A three act epic with deep historical roots, religious themes, political notes, and profound emotional capacity, Passion Play is a meaty text for both actors and designers. With eleven parts that travel through Elizabethan England, Hitler's Germany, and post-Vietnam America, the script lends itself to both challenging individual character work and strong ensemble-building.

We believe the best way to learn about theatre is by doing it. This fall, we will produce a challenging piece of theatre with a team comprised completely of students. 

"I don’t know if this country needs more religion or less of it. Seems to me everyone needs a good night’s sleep. That way we’d all wake up for real in the morning. It’s good to be awake. When you’re awake you can fight for what you believe in, no matter what costume you’re wearing."


the mission

Director's Note:

There are a number of reasons why I love Passion Play. I love the scale of it: three acts, roughly twenty scenes apiece, that span four hundred plus years of history. I love the language—how it’s poetic, poignant, contemporary, clever, and funny all at once. I love that there are rich historical backdrops, but the play isn’t about them; it’s about the people living within them. I love that Ruhl’s focus on the individual makes big ideas about the human condition seem easier to tackle. And I love that this play begs us to think about the pressures we put on ourselves. I find that I—and I think many people pursing the arts—feel constant pressure to live up to something, to amount to something, to work towards something, even when I don’t know what that something is. Where do these desired effects or ideals come from? I’d like to use this play to better understand the pressure that seems to dominate the lives of many of the people I know and love.

 

the need

In order to bring this production to fruition, the Passion Play team needs to raise $3000 by October 26th. We have to pay for production rights, lighting and sound equipment, publicity fees, costume pieces and scenic materials.

 

how YOU can help

You can contribute online or contact us at passionplaygap@gmail.com for other ways to donate.

Your contributions cover materials to build the set and props, lighting and sound equipment, costumes, publicity fees, and rights to produce the play. By supporting this project, you are giving a group of students the opportunity to establish ourselves as the next generation of theatremakers. 

Can't contribute money? That's okay! Help us out by spreading word about the show!

Follow us on twitter @PassionPlayGAP (https://twitter.com/passionplaygap). 

 

who we are

CREATIVE TEAM:

Director: Sarah Blush
Producer: Brídín Clements
Associate Producer: Frank Swann
Scenic Design: Joel Grossman
Lighting Design: Catie Davis
Costume Design: Alex Roffey
Sound Design: Michael Norton
Props Design: Taylor Edelhart
Dramaturgy: Bryn Herdrich
Stage Manager: Victoria Sumrall

CAST:

John...........................Patrick Daly
Village Idiot..................Ruthy Froch
Director.......................Julian Goza
Carpenter 1..................Jacob Jones
Queen/Hitler/Reagan......Rachel Music
Mary 2........................Bailey Nassetta
Mary 1........................Emily Radosevich
Pontius........................Andrew Raia
Visiting Friar.................Blake Sugarman
Carpenter 2..................Alex Tissiere
Machinist.....................Mac Wallach

 

performances 

November 5th-10th
in the Shop Theatre
721 Broadway, 2nd Floor

 

We hope to see you at the show!
