story:
DER UNTERMENSCH

 

La version française est disponible plus bas

 

What's all this fuss about??

This dance-video, depicting the treatment of homosexuals during World War II, is drawing a parallel between concentration camps and how physically constrained one can feel when self–expression is repressed. Dance-wise, the prisoners craving for freedom are symbolized by the organs trying to come out of the rib cage barrier. The dancer portrays growth, escape and rebirth of those incarcerated souls by embodying a gay Aryan during the Nazi era.

“Untermensch” means “under-man” or “sub-human” in German.
 
This project is a tribute to those who have suffered in prison or concentration camps, due to their sexual orientation, religious beliefs or cultural background. Furthermore, it is for anyone who has ever felt oppressed or ostracized.
 

Where is all the $$$ going?? And why we need your help!

So far, the money is entirely coming out of the artist’s pocket, but we need your help to raise at least $2,625 out of the total production costs.

Here is the breakdown of this amount:

Music composer: $500 (would normally cost $1500)

Location rental: $200 

Editor: $400

Promotional material: $300

Props: $250

Costumes: $150

Camera and lenses rental: $400

Make-up: $75

Lights: $150

Campaign fees: $200

Total: $2,625

This amount excludes the following fees: 
  • Core creative team salary (working for free unless money comes their way - Simon Vermeulen, Kays Mejri and Jessica Surendorff’s work is estimated to $700 each, for a total of $2,100)
  • Film crew salary (working for free unless money comes their way - the amount for 2 days of shooting for 4 crew members is $1,200)
  • Custom-made resin shoes ($2,400 paid by producer)
  • Set photographer salary (kindly offering his services free of charge, worth $150 for 2 days of shooting)
  • Poster photographer salary (kindly offering his services free of charge, worth $250)
  • Salary for 8 backup dancers (kindly offering their services free of charge, worth $600 for 1 day of shooting)
  • Salary for 2 extras (kindly offering their services free of charge, worth $300 for 2 days of shooting)


Meet our crew!

  • Producer, Co-Writer, Choreographer & Performer: Simon Vermeulen
  • Director & Co-Writer: Kays Mejri
  • Director of Photography: Simon Lamarre-Ledoux
  • Art Director & Production Coordinator: Jessica Surendorff
  • Administrative Assistants: Catherine Godin and Laura Bayle
  • Editor: Kays Mejri
  • Poster Photographer: Cody Caissie 

 

Where will this video go...

This video has a primary artistic purpose. It is meant to be watched by as many people as possible, and thus be available online with an exclusive link, to all funders of this campaign contributing at least $25.

We will send the final dance-video to Montreal but also international film-festivals, including Short Corner Festival de Cannes.
 

You can be a part of this!

We are deep into pre-production. We have the crew, the music is being finalized, we have researched the theme as well as created a narrative shot list for the choreography and the custom shoes are being hand-crafted. However, we still have a long to go!

Your support will make this a reality.

No matter how small your donation is, every dollar helps and is greatly appreciated! You can also help by spreading the word or posting the IndieGoGo Campaign link on your Facebook, Twitter, etc.

We have some cool gifts to show our appreciation! Check out the PERKS to the right of this page to see what you can get for your donation!


Thank you so much!! 

 

DER UNTERMENSCH

 

De quoi s’agit-il??

Cette vidéo-danse traduit le traitement fait aux homosexuels au cours de la deuxième guerre mondiale, en faisant un parallèle entre les camps de concentration et la sensation de cloître physique lorsque la libre-expression est réprimée. Le mouvement des organes essayant de franchir la cage thoracique symbolise la soif de liberté des prisonniers. En incarnant un arien homosexuel durant l’ère nazie, le danseur dépicte la croissance, la fuite et la renaissance de ces âmes captives.
 
“Untermensch’’ signifie “sous-homme” en allemand.
 
Cette danse est un hommage à tous ceux qui ont souffert en prison ou dans les camps de concentration, que ce soit à cause de leur orientation sexuelle, de leurs croyances religieuses ou de leur culture. De plus, elle est dédiée à tous ceux qui se sont déjà sentis réprimés ou ostracisés.


Où vont aller tous ces $$$?? Et pourquoi faisons-nous appel à vous!

Jusqu’à présent, toutes les dépenses ont été défrayées par un membre de l’équipe; nous avons besoin de votre aide pour assumer au moins 2,625$ des frais de production.

Voici la répartition de cette somme:
  • Compositeur: 500$ (coûterait normalement 1500$)
  • Location des lieux de tournage: 200$ 
  • Éditeur: 400$
  • Matériel promotionnel: 300$
  • Accessoires: 250$
  • Costumes: 150$
  • Location de caméras et lentilles: 400$
  • Maquillage: 75$
  • Éclairage: 150$
  • Frais inhérents à la campagne: 200$
Total: 2,625$

Ce montant ne tient pas compte des frais suivants:
  • Salaire de l’équipe de création (Simon Vermeulen, Kays Mejri et Jessica Surendorff ne sont actuellement pas rémunérés mais leur travail est estimé à 700$ chacun, pour un total de 2,100$)
  • Salaire de l’équipe de tournage (les 4 membres de l’équipe ne sont actuellement pas rémunérés mais leur travail total pour 2 jours de tournage équivaut à 1,200$)
  • Chaussures de résine sur mesure (2,400$ payés par le producteur)
  • Salaire du photographe de plateau (offre grâcieusement ses services, équivalant à 150$ pour 2 jours de tournage)
  • Salaire du photographe de l’affiche (offre grâcieusement ses services, équivalant à 250$)
  • Salaire des 8 danseurs figurants (offrent grâcieusement leurs services, équivalant à 600$ pour 1 journée de tournage)
  • Salaire des 2 figurants (offrent grâcieusement leurs services, équivalant à 300$ pour 2 jours de tournage)
 

Voici l’équipe!

  • Producteur, Co-Scénariste, Chorégraphe et Interprète: Simon Vermeulen
  • Réalisateur et Co-Scénariste: Kays Mejri
  • Directeur Photo: Simon Lamarre-Ledoux
  • Directrice Artistique & Coordonnatrice de Production: Jessica Surendorff
  • Assistante Administrative: Catherine Godin et Laura Bayle
  • Éditeur: Kays Mejri
  • Photographe de l’Affiche: Cody Caissie
 

Où ira cette vidéo…

Cette vidéo-danse a une intention purement artistique et se veut d'être visionnée par le plus de gens possible. Elle sera disponible en ligne, avec un lien exclusif à tous les donateurs de 25$ et plus.

Nous enverrons la version finale aux divers festivals de films de Montréal ainsi qu’à l’international, incluant le Short Corner Festival de Cannes.
 

Vous pouvez faire partie de ce projet!

Nous sommes en pleine pré-production. Nous avons l’équipe, la musique est au stade final de sa composition, toute la recherche autour de ce thème a été réalisée, la liste des plans de tournage jouxtés à la chorégraphie a été dressée, finalement les chaussures sur mesure sont en cours de fabrication. Cependant, il nous reste encore beaucoup de chemin à parcourir!

Votre aide permettra à ce projet de se réaliser.

Si petit soit votre don, chaque dollar nous aidera et sera grandement apprécié! Vous pouvez aussi nous aider en passant le mot, ou simplement en postant le lien de la campagne IndieGoGo sur votre page Facebook, Twitter, etc.
 
Nous avons de petits cadeaux en gage de notre gratitude! Jetez un coup d’oeil à droite de la page, pour savoir quels cadeaux (PERKS) vous pourriez recevoir en remerciement de votre don!


Merci infiniment!!
story_txt:
DER UNTERMENSCH
 
La version française est disponible plus bas
 
What's all this fuss about??
This dance-video, depicting the treatment of homosexuals during World War II, is drawing a parallel between concentration camps and how physically constrained one can feel when self–expression is repressed. Dance-wise, the prisoners craving for freedom are symbolized by the organs trying to come out of the rib cage barrier. The dancer portrays growth, escape and rebirth of those incarcerated souls by embodying a gay Aryan during the Nazi era. “Untermensch” means “under-man” or “sub-human” in German.
 
This project is a tribute to those who have suffered in prison or concentration camps, due to their sexual orientation, religious beliefs or cultural background. Furthermore, it is for anyone who has ever felt oppressed or ostracized.
 
Where is all the $$$ going?? And why we need your help!
So far, the money is entirely coming out of the artist’s pocket, but we need your help to raise at least $2,625 out of the total production costs.
Here is the breakdown of this amount:
Music composer: $500 (would normally cost $1500)
Location rental: $200 
Editor: $400
Promotional material: $300
Props: $250
Costumes: $150
Camera and lenses rental: $400
Make-up: $75
Lights: $150
Campaign fees: $200
Total: $2,625This amount excludes the following fees: 


Core creative team salary (working for free unless money comes their way - Simon Vermeulen, Kays Mejri and Jessica Surendorff’s work is estimated to $700 each, for a total of $2,100)
Film crew salary (working for free unless money comes their way - the amount for 2 days of shooting for 4 crew members is $1,200)
Custom-made resin shoes ($2,400 paid by producer)
Set photographer salary (kindly offering his services free of charge, worth $150 for 2 days of shooting)
Poster photographer salary (kindly offering his services free of charge, worth $250)
Salary for 8 backup dancers (kindly offering their services free of charge, worth $600 for 1 day of shooting)
Salary for 2 extras (kindly offering their services free of charge, worth $300 for 2 days of shooting)



Meet our crew!



Producer, Co-Writer, Choreographer & Performer: Simon Vermeulen

Director & Co-Writer: Kays Mejri

Director of Photography: Simon Lamarre-Ledoux

Art Director & Production Coordinator: Jessica Surendorff

Administrative Assistants: Catherine Godin and Laura Bayle

Editor: Kays Mejri

Poster Photographer: Cody Caissie 


 
Where will this video go...
This video has a primary artistic purpose. It is meant to be watched by as many people as possible, and thus be available online with an exclusive link, to all funders of this campaign contributing at least $25.We will send the final dance-video to Montreal but also international film-festivals, including Short Corner Festival de Cannes. 
You can be a part of this!
We are deep into pre-production. We have the crew, the music is being finalized, we have researched the theme as well as created a narrative shot list for the choreography and the custom shoes are being hand-crafted. However, we still have a long to go!

Your support will make this a reality.

No matter how small your donation is, every dollar helps and is greatly appreciated! You can also help by spreading the word or posting the IndieGoGo Campaign link on your Facebook, Twitter, etc. We have some cool gifts to show our appreciation! Check out the PERKS to the right of this page to see what you can get for your donation!

Thank you so much!! 
 
DER UNTERMENSCH
 
De quoi s’agit-il??
Cette vidéo-danse traduit le traitement fait aux homosexuels au cours de la deuxième guerre mondiale, en faisant un parallèle entre les camps de concentration et la sensation de cloître physique lorsque la libre-expression est réprimée. Le mouvement des organes essayant de franchir la cage thoracique symbolise la soif de liberté des prisonniers. En incarnant un arien homosexuel durant l’ère nazie, le danseur dépicte la croissance, la fuite et la renaissance de ces âmes captives.
 
“Untermensch’’ signifie “sous-homme” en allemand.
 
Cette danse est un hommage à tous ceux qui ont souffert en prison ou dans les camps de concentration, que ce soit à cause de leur orientation sexuelle, de leurs croyances religieuses ou de leur culture. De plus, elle est dédiée à tous ceux qui se sont déjà sentis réprimés ou ostracisés.

Où vont aller tous ces $$$?? Et pourquoi faisons-nous appel à vous!


Jusqu’à présent, toutes les dépenses ont été défrayées par un membre de l’équipe; nous avons besoin de votre aide pour assumer au moins 2,625$ des frais de production.Voici la répartition de cette somme:

Compositeur: 500$ (coûterait normalement 1500$)
Location des lieux de tournage: 200$ 
Éditeur: 400$
Matériel promotionnel: 300$
Accessoires: 250$
Costumes: 150$
Location de caméras et lentilles: 400$
Maquillage: 75$
Éclairage: 150$
Frais inhérents à la campagne: 200$

Total: 2,625$Ce montant ne tient pas compte des frais suivants:
Salaire de l’équipe de création (Simon Vermeulen, Kays Mejri et Jessica Surendorff ne sont actuellement pas rémunérés mais leur travail est estimé à 700$ chacun, pour un total de 2,100$)
Salaire de l’équipe de tournage (les 4 membres de l’équipe ne sont actuellement pas rémunérés mais leur travail total pour 2 jours de tournage équivaut à 1,200$)
Chaussures de résine sur mesure (2,400$ payés par le producteur)
Salaire du photographe de plateau (offre grâcieusement ses services, équivalant à 150$ pour 2 jours de tournage)
Salaire du photographe de l’affiche (offre grâcieusement ses services, équivalant à 250$)
Salaire des 8 danseurs figurants (offrent grâcieusement leurs services, équivalant à 600$ pour 1 journée de tournage)
Salaire des 2 figurants (offrent grâcieusement leurs services, équivalant à 300$ pour 2 jours de tournage)

 

Voici l’équipe!


Producteur, Co-Scénariste, Chorégraphe et Interprète: Simon Vermeulen
Réalisateur et Co-Scénariste: Kays Mejri
Directeur Photo: Simon Lamarre-Ledoux
Directrice Artistique & Coordonnatrice de Production: Jessica Surendorff
Assistante Administrative: Catherine Godin et Laura Bayle
Éditeur: Kays Mejri
Photographe de l’Affiche: Cody Caissie


 
Où ira cette vidéo…

Cette vidéo-danse a une intention purement artistique et se veut d'être visionnée par le plus de gens possible. Elle sera disponible en ligne, avec un lien exclusif à tous les donateurs de 25$ et plus.Nous enverrons la version finale aux divers festivals de films de Montréal ainsi qu’à l’international, incluant le Short Corner Festival de Cannes.

 
Vous pouvez faire partie de ce projet!
Nous sommes en pleine pré-production. Nous avons l’équipe, la musique est au stade final de sa composition, toute la recherche autour de ce thème a été réalisée, la liste des plans de tournage jouxtés à la chorégraphie a été dressée, finalement les chaussures sur mesure sont en cours de fabrication. Cependant, il nous reste encore beaucoup de chemin à parcourir!

Votre aide permettra à ce projet de se réaliser.


Si petit soit votre don, chaque dollar nous aidera et sera grandement apprécié! Vous pouvez aussi nous aider en passant le mot, ou simplement en postant le lien de la campagne IndieGoGo sur votre page Facebook, Twitter, etc.

 
Nous avons de petits cadeaux en gage de notre gratitude! Jetez un coup d’oeil à droite de la page, pour savoir quels cadeaux (PERKS) vous pourriez recevoir en remerciement de votre don!

Merci infiniment!!

story:
Short Summary

Summer Shakespeare is a series of free Shakespeare-themed events geared towards young people in Accra. The program is performance-based, the point being to give young people a chance to be on stage, and consists of two main events: an acting workshop, and a reading series. The acting workshop will focus on the comedy, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, a piece chosen for its ensemble nature. There is room for about twenty participants, no leads, and the whole group will be responsible for adapting the play to make it more Ghanaian, more “them”, and thus more relevant to their experience of theworkshop and of their lives. This workshop is currently supported by the Nubuke Foundation, and will take place at the Foundation’s premises at East Legon, a suburb of Accra. The reading series will focus on Shakespeare’s nondramatic poetry, meaning the sonnets and excerpts from his minor epic poems. These readings will be hosted at various informal locations throughout the city. Other events, such as film screenings, are also planned.

 The start date for the project is Monday, 18th June, 2012, coinciding opportunely with the 2012 World Shakespeare Festival, a remarkable celebration of “Shakespeare as the world’s playwright” in which 37 plays will be staged in 37 languages by the Royal Shakespeare Company and international collaborators. The acting workshop will continue for six weeks, and will culminate in a performance of A Midsummer Night’s Dream on Friday, July 27th 2012. The reading series is confirmed to happen at least once a week, starting Saturday 23rd June, 2012, for about the same time duration as the acting workshop. Other events, such as film screenings and sample classes for younger children, will occur when opportunity arises during this period.

What We Need & What You Get

It is extremely important that this program is created and kept free, in order to keep it accessible for the general population of youth in Accra. Of course, this means that we need other people to help us pay for necessities like scripts, costumes, props, production costs, and all the other things that come with running a project like this. We also need help getting one of our teaching staff, Nikaury Roman, who is a junior at DePauw University, across the Atlantic so she can help out with the program on the ground.

All donors will have access to special project updates and will be given a special "thank you" in the program for the final showcase. Donations of $100 or more will receive a DVD based on the acting workshop and other cool items such as show posters autographed by the cast of A Midsummer Night's Dream.

The Impact

There is a lot of talent in Accra, and not nearly enough platforms. For young people who are interested in the performing arts, particularly theatre, there are very few opportunities to experience the performance process as a professional. This is a unique opportunity to be involved in every aspect of the play making process from start to finish, to take ownership of the most powerful tool we have: language.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks for checking out our project!If you can't help directly with funding, you can still help by telling your friends, family and other contacts about us.
Please like our facebook page at: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Summer-Shakespear...
 
You can also use the sharing tools provided by IndieGoGo.com
 
Thanks again!

story:
Scandal Theatre at Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2012.

Produced by Shift for PBH's Free Fringe

2pm at The Fiddlers Elbow, 4th - 25th August (off Tuesdays)

 

The Show

Two sisters. One terrible secret. When one threatens to tell, can the other keep her quiet?

Scandal Theatre, in conjuction with Shift, are taking a new play, "My Sister" to the 2012 Edinburgh Festival Fringe. Following an incredibly successful and critically acclaimed appearance at the 2011 festival with The Translators Dilemma, which subsequently toured to the Theaterszene Europa Festival in Cologne, Germany in May, Scandal Theatre aim to build on their growing international reputation as daring, innovative theatre makers creating work which addresses and challenges social issues. 

Praise for The Translator's Dilemma:

“Quintessential Fringe and quintessential five star. I look back at my notes and think 'It's amazing that actually worked' and 'If only I were immoral enough to steal that idea for myself.' If Scandal Theatre returns to the Fringe, not going would be a fallacy. If Scandal Theatre restrains itself to the Free Fringe again, not going would be idiotic.” - EdFringeReview.com

* * * * * (EdFringeReview.com) , * * * *(Three Weeks)

 

Performances

The Fiddlers Elbow, 4 Picardy Place, Edinburgh, EH1 3JT (Venue #71)
2pm, August 4-25, except Tuesdays
 
Performed as part of PBH's Free Fringe, entry is FREE which is why we need YOUR SUPPORT!

 

Scandal Theatre

Scandal Theatre was founded by Jessica Phillippi and Dom Hastings in the belief that theatre should tell stories that change society for the better. It grew out of work together at the IETM Plenary Meeting in 2010.

They create narrative-based productions dealing with international issues. Their performances combine music, languages, comedy and multi-media to create pieces that provoke audiences, encouraging them to think about concrete things they can do to change the world when they walk out of the theatre. Their work attempts to spur small local movements of social justice, one play at a time.

 

Shift

A collaboration between Kim Simpson and Jana Robert, Shift work with a range of clients and independently producing and programming visual arts, performing arts, music, talent development and strategic cultural projects and events. Clients include Cardboardia, International Creative Entrepreneurs, Festivals Edinburgh, G.I. Festival, Arika, Ten Tracks, Sonica and IETM. 

Shift particularly enjoy international collaborations, cross artform working and art projects with a conscience. 

 

What can you do?

We need your help! Edinburgh Festival Fringe is about building international profile, but to get there, we need money.

Not a lot, mind you....enough to cover printing of posters and flyers, our travel expenses, and minimal props and costumes. For a peppercorn budget we can perform to 50 people a day, taking our exciting new production to an international audience and building on our international profile. 

Not only will you be secure in the knowledge that you have been instrumental in ensuring the future of an important new theatre company but you will be able to enjoy one of the wonderfully personal rewards listed to the right. 

And though we're fundraising in dollars, remember that all of our costs are in pounds sterling. Here's a quick conversion guide, so you can see how far your money will go:

$ 10:   £6

$ 25:   £16

$ 50:   £32

$ 100:   £64

$ 500:   £317

 

If you can't support us with cash....

....let other people know! Share the link on facebook, forward the email, tell your friends. Last year we raised funds from the UK, the US, Italy and beyond. The more people that see our page the more likely we are to get the pennies together to make it happen!  

The other obvious way you can help is to come see the show in August and spread the word! 

 

Questions?

Just ask. You can email info@scandaltheatre.com or kim@makeshifthappen.info, contact us on Twitter (@scandaltheatre), find us on Facebook, or via www.scandaltheatre.com

story:
Help us raise $5K in 30 days! Your tax-deductible donation will directly support the 2011-12 season of The Shelter, including the world premiere of FAIRY TALE.  


FAIRY TALE is a 90-minute evening of theatre comprised of five short plays inspired by classic fairy tales. Each play explores the fundamentals of fairy tales, diving into their exotic worlds and finding inspiration in their rich archetypes and shadowed psychologies. The playwrights have re-imagined these elements in a grown-up world, and in doing so, expose the fears and joys which have driven fairy tales to become deeply ingrained into global culture. Ranging in genre and style, the plays are funny, sad, gruesome, touching, strange and fantastical … everything a fairy tale should be.      

The Shelter, under the guidance of Artistic Directors Meghan Jones and Michael Kingsbaker and Executive Director Dave Lankford, is a family of writers, directors, and actors creating authentic theatre for the New York stage. All productions are written, directed, and acted by its members and are developed through the company's weekly Shelter Sunday workshop series. The heartbeat of The Shelter, Shelter Sunday provides a safe harbor where New York’s top emerging theatrical artists can collaboratively challenge themselves to explore their artistry and hone their respective crafts.  

Through its productions, The Shelter strives to connect with patrons seeking innovative, independently produced theatre with a focus on character-driven storytelling. Past productions include: NIGHT WINDOWS (2011), a trio of one-act plays inspired by Edward Hopper’s 1928 painting of the same name; F***ING CHRISTMAS (2010), an assortment of short plays, each providing a singular view of a joyful, sorrowful, ridiculous, and endlessly complex holiday; MOTEL (2010), eight short plays set in the same lone motel room, somewhere in Middle America; and 3:56 AM (2009), nine short plays set in an apartment building on the Lower East Side between the hours of 3 and 4 AM.


Please note that donors contributing $50 or more will be listed in the programs for both FAIRY TALE and our Spring production, as well as on The Shelter web site as a supporter of the 2011-12 season.

story:
Gran Lakou

Gran Lakou is a LGBTQ~inclusive drum & dance troupe in Jakmel, Haiti.  They are the only group in their area that is inclusive and creates a safe space for lesbian/gay/bi/trans/queer Haitians.  LGBTQ Haitians regularly face discrimination, harrassment, and violence with very few legal protections. 


Gran Lakou is seeking solidarity from other LGBTQ communities to offer financial support so that they can continue to perform, be a visible LGBTQ presence in their community, and stand up for their human rights.  


Currently they are fundraising to be able to participate in Karnival, which is coming up in February!

A Letter from Gran Lakou:

Dear friends and supporters of Gran Lakou, 

Happy New Year! Thanks to your support, we recently we have had the opportunity to perform at several local events held in Jacmel to celebrate the Christmas and New Year, including a show at a local orphanage for young boys. Sadly, we also recently had one of our founding members and supporters pass away. We held a memorial service and performance in our home at the FOSAJ art collective in their honor and in memorial of other friends of Gran Lakou and FOSAJ who have died over the years. Everyday we are working hard and loving every opportunity we have to perform, the costumes and make-up we recently bought, thanks to your fundraising efforts, have been a huge support. We are feeling stronger and stronger as a group as the days go by and more and more opportunities to perform continue to arise.  We are so happy to have more opportunities to carry our message of self love, acceptance and anti-discrimination of any kind into the greater community. 


Although Christmas and the New Year have come and gone, in Haiti we continue to celebrate. The second week of February is National Carnival and from now until then, we celebrate every weekend, building up to the climax of events in February. National Carnival in celebrated in various cities all over the country however, no city celebrates it with more enthusiasm than Jacmel. National Carnival is a tradition in Jacmel since 1992 which has evolved to celebrate the arts and culture of Jacmel namely the very colorful and elaborate papier mache maskarade. Every year the National Carnival in Jacmel is becoming more and more beautiful and people travel from all over the country and the world to participate. It's for this reason Gran Lakou would love to participate in this year's grand march, however, we are encountering some economic obstacles keeping us from participating.


The National Carnival requires an entry fee of approximately $40US which we are currently still looking to raise. Additionally, although we bought some beautiful costumes recently, carnival is a special occasion and requires a little more flamboyancy than we have been able to afford. We would like to be able to buy scarves and fabrics and to make large colorful skirts for our Carnival choreography as well as make-up for the event. We have approximately 15 women who would all like to participate in this choreography and each costume will cost us approximately $20US, and 8 men's costumes averaging about $8US a person. Any financial support you are able to offer would be greatly appreciated. 

We welcome you all to come and celebrate National Carnival in Jacmel with us. 

In gratitude and solidarity, 

Gran Lakou Folklorique

Carnival requires an entry fee of approximately $40US which we are currently 
still looking to raise. Additionally, although we bought some beautiful 
costumes recently, carnival is a special occasion and requires a little 
more flamboyancy than we have been able to afford. We would like to 
be able to buy scarves and fabrics and to make large colorful skirts 
for our Carnival choreography as well as make-up for the event. We have 
approximately 15 women who would all like to participate in this choreography 
and each costume will cost us approximately $20US, and 8 men's costumes 
averaging about $8US a person. Any financial support you are able to 
offer would be greatly appreciated. 
We welcome you all to come and celebrate 
National Carnival in Jacmel with us. 
In gratitude and solidarity, 
Gran Lakou Folklorique

story:
100 Proof's Tale

We are staging a new production of Igor Stravinsky's L'Histoire du soldat (or, The Soldier's Tale). Often performed as a concert suite for seven musicians, The Soldier's Tale was originally written "to be read, played, and danced." Our production will include reading, playing, dancing and more, as we present a new interpretation of C.F. Ramuz's libretto.

Though based on a Russian folk tale, our soldier, Joseph (Niall Powderly), is serving in the Iraq War. Through his story, we are exploring the difficulties soldiers face while readjusting to life at home: the disconnect, the isolation, the search for meaning, the physical toll on the body.

Throughout the show, Joseph struggles against a disguised Devil (William Vaughn), who threatens to derail his quest for inner peace. We see Joseph ache for a non-existent past while the present surges forward.

Our question for the ages: after war, what happens when you become the enemy?

It's Faust, but Not Really...

As a story that has been told and retold in various forms over centuries, it is important to give our production of The Soldier's Tale our own spin. Because our generation has seen a growing awareness of the effects of war, especially posttraumatic stress disorder, we want to bring that element to this work. For our debut performance, we are exploring an issue that remains largely unaddressed in the arts. 100 Proof isn't about making statements, but asking questions, the kind that sting a little in the back of your throat.


The Bottom Line

If you've ever tried to find an apartment in Manhattan, you know how expensive space is in this city. So here's what we need to make this production happen:

One week in Access Theater--$1675

Music Rental and Performance Rights--$970

Insurance for Actors and Musicians--$380

Set, Costumes and Other Costs--$475

Total--$3500


As you can see, we're actually asking for a little less than we actually need. That's because we will also have a couple of fundraiser parties in New York, where you can meet the producers and performers and have a couple of drinks! But anything you can pitch in here helps, so we can make sure most of our major expenses are covered.

Other Ways You Can Help

We only have so many Facebook friends and Twitter followers, so we need your help to spread our campaign to your social media circle. Keep checking out our Facebook and Twitter pages for news for fundraiser parties and other things we might need from time to time. And, whether you contribute or not, the best support you can give us is to come see the show!

This show goes up May 3, 4 and 5 at 8pm every night at Access Theater (380 Broadway, 4th floor). We have a beautiful space, now be a beautiful person and help us create something great!

story:
Our Story

Artists/dance professors Tiffany Fish and Rebecca Levy travel to SkagastrÃ¶nd, Iceland for the Nes Artist Residency in summer, 2012. Bridging cultural and geographical gaps, the duo will create an original work of provocative dance-film to be premiered in Iceland in June.


The Impact

Fish and Levy bring a deep understanding of dance, cinematography, and the power of movement to all of their collaboartions. With this new project, the duo will work within their mission of challenging the boundaries of dance-film as an art form, in both the creative and, more literally, geographic senses.

What We Need & What You Get

To fund this project there are some items we need help to cover the cost of, including:


Cost of travel

Cost of video editing equipment

Props & costumes

Transportation to and from Rekjavik

Feeding the artists


With your help raising $5000, we can achieve all of these things together and make this project a huge success!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!  Send to your friends, post on facebook.  We really appreciate your help and support!

story:
Our Story

One woman will do whatever it takes to make it in the world of high power finance...including dressing as a man


Co-Op Theatre East announces an exciting modern take on a Shakespeare classic. Twelfth Night: Wall Street, directed by COTE co-founder Casey Cleverly, will debut in New York City with performances from February 23rd through March 10th at Looking Glass Theatre in midtown Manhattan.


Set in the modern day financial sector, Twelfth Night: Wall Street highlights the current gender bias and power-play in the American work place. When the young Viola takes a job at the financial firm Orsino and Partners, she quickly finds that in order to move up the corporate ladder, she needs to dress as a man. Meanwhile her tough boss Orsino is intent on wooing the business of a major fashion client, Olivia and Co., at whatever cost. Their world turns topsy-turvy as the fashion heiress, Olivia, falls in love with the young analyst in disguise, and Olivia's pesky relatives come to Occupy Wall Street. Twelfth Night: Wall Street is a play full of camp, satire, and serious money.

 

Founded in Spring 2008 by three graduates of the Performance Studies graduate program at Tisch School of the Arts, NYU, Co-Op Theatre East produces socially minded performance that deals with the questions of today, the situations we find ourselves immersed in as New Yorkers, Americans, and world citizens at this moment. The staff & ensemble at COTE firmly believe that theatre can do something; not only do we hold Hamletâ€™s mirror up to nature, but we can use theatre as a means to make a positive impact in the world. Co-Op Theatre East is in resdince at Looking Glass Theatre for the 2011-2012 season.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our show is premiering at Looking Glass Theatre in midtown Manhattan. We need to raise exactly $2000 in order to cover the production costs: set, props, lights and costumes for this ambitious off-off-Broadway production. 

 

By supporting us, and helping us raise funds for our show, you are essentially pre-purchasing your ticket! (by giving $15+). Giving $60 or more secures you and a guest a spot to our opening night performance and exclusive reception with the cast and production team behind Twelfth Night Wall Street. And we've got some other goodies to thank you for your generosity check out the incentives to the right!  Best of all, your donation is fully tax-deductible (minus your thank-you gift)!
 
And of course you will have COTE's never-ending love and gratitude.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! We think this production is a lot of fun, and we know you will too â€” so share it, tweet about it, post it on Facebook, and invite all your friends to come to see a performance! Theatre is best shared with friends!

story:
CROSS-EYED BEAR PRODUCTIONS is pleased to present THE TAINT OF EQUALITY ~or~ I WANT YOUR SEX, written and directed by multi-award-winning playwright Duncan Pflaster, as part of the 4th Annual Planet Connections Theatre Festivity. The Festivity will take place May 30th through June 24th at

The Theatres at 45 Bleecker in New York City.

Adrian and Javier are a gay couple who don’t believe in marriage- but everyone assumes they’re married. When they realize they’ve never actually opened up their “open relationship”, they decide to each go out and get laid, with hilarious and erotic results.  The play is an entertaining send-up of modern Gay life and relationships, that tackles drug use, Dan Savage, racism, showtunes, porn, Grindr, public sex, and much much more. The show contains full-frontal nudity and is most definitely not for children. The play will benefit the LGBT Center.

 The production stars a large cast of 13 men:  Roberto Alexander, Juan Carlos Diaz*, Joe Fanelli (Winner, Best Featured Actor Spotlight On Award for Pflaster’s Eternity: Time Without End), Mark-Eugene Garcia, Colin Godwin, Derrick Bryant Marshall, Shawn McLaughlin, Alan McNaney*, Rehmat Qadir, Jon Rentler, Marvin Riggins, Jr.*, Adam Samtur, and David T. Zimmerman

* indicates member of Actors’ Equity Association

 

We need help to make this play be the best it can be!  Please donate generously, if you can.  And if you can't, please at least share our funding campaign with friends and family!

story:
My Story


 

Hi, my name is Jacqueline Naami Narnor and I will begin my fourth year at the College of Wooster in Ohio in the fall. I spent last fall at The Moscow Art Theater School (MXAT) in Russia. These months I spent at MXAT were without a doubt some of the best days of my life. It was the first time that I was given the opportunity to sleep, eat, and breathe theater. I spent six, sometimes seven days out of the week in acting class and I felt my heart flutter with joy through every moment of it. I fell in love with the concentrated curriculum. I also found renewed confidence when I saw the ease at which I tackled such a physically and emotionally demanding schedule. It felt like my time spent in Moscow ended much too quickly. 

 

Still, I was glad to return to Wooster and continue my studies. This spring, I took a course called Education in a Sociocultural Context. This course has truly taught me the value of education. Since taking this course I have seen my dreams grow from ones of personal satisfaction into dreams that are rooted in service to others. I hope that one day I will be able to use my skills in theater to educate young people like myself through art and performance as companies such as The Youth Ensemble of Atlanta has done for me. 


In order to be the best that I can be, I know that I must seek the best education that I can find and recognize it when I find it - which is what has led me to the Yale Summer Conservatory for Actors.    I am super excited because this is an AMAZING training program!! At Yale Summer Session, I will be able to work with leading professionals and Yale School of Drama faculty and staff.  The program is immersive and so so beneficial. 

 

You may even know of some people that have trained at Yale - Meryl Streep, Angela Bassett, and Law & Order's Chris Noth, to name a few.



I know that I am meant for the stage and I want nothing more than to compliment my talents with precision training.  Only now, I need your help in paying tuition so that I can take the next step in accomplishing my goals.

 



The Impact


 

I discovered early in life that I had been blessed with a powerful voice and that power is not limited to volume and fervor. I discovered that my voice radiates from within me. I saw that when I spoke, people listened and at first I did not know what to do with such a gift so I told outlandish stories with great conviction to entertain myself and anyone else that I could get to listen.

 

At 16 I made one of the best decisions in my life, I joined the Youth Ensemble of Atlanta (YEA). At YEA I learned how to funnel my voice down a focused path. I learned to love my voice and in turn to love ME. It was at YEA that I learned work ethics, I learned passion, I learned to smile even when it hurts. I began to develop a passion for education and for theater. 

 

Without opportunities like the one being offered to me now by Yale Summer Session I will not be able to offer the best of me to the world. I know that my voice is important and by training it I will be able to teach other young people, like myself, that their voices are also.

 

This Summer, I will be giving back some of myself and what you've already invested in me, by interning - without pay -  for a program called Higher Achievement Summer School, teaching self-esteem, through theater, to disadvantaged youth from the Black Belt of Alabama. 

One day I will teach acting and to teach I must become a master at my craft. I will begin this part 

of my journey this summer when I intern -without pay- at Higher Achievement Summer School. While there I will be teaching self-esteem, through theater, to disadvantaged youth from the Black Belt of Alabama. 


 What We Need & What You Get

 

The program costs $5, 800. That covers room, board, and tuition into the program. I have been able to save $1,300 dollars by working on campus as a resident assistant between January and May.  Therefore, my campaign goal is $4,500. I will pay for my way to and from New Haven at the start and end of the program. 

 

Also, I pledge to:

1.    Offer myself as a resource to anyone who needs my help, advice, or talents.

2.    I will continue to mentor young people and offer them the best of me selflessly.

3.    I will continue to strive for the dreams you are all supporting, even when it seems all odds (financially) are against me.

 

If I do not raise all of the money needed, I will not be able to attend the program but dreams do not die because of obstacles. Instead, they are empowered. If l am unable to reach my goal the money will remain untouched and will become part of what I will use to pay for graduate school in the fall of 2012. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you can't donate you can still help me out:

 

1. Pass this link to EVERY kind person you know and proudly put in a word for me! 

2. Pray, send me positive energy, good vibes, meditate, whatever it is that you do best.

3. Continue to believe in me. 

 

Thank you very much indeed!! I appreciate all of your time, care, support, effort, and love.

 

Stay Blessed,

 

Jacqueline 

E: jnarnor12@wooster.edu

story:
Fresh from sold out houses with Ballybeg at the Barrow Group Theatre and with terraNOVA Collective at the 9th Annual SoloNOVA Arts Festival, EMPANADA FOR A DREAM is a haunting love song to the Lower East Side. Juan Francisco Villa's return to the neighborhood of his childhood is a heartfelt and hilarious tale about family and home.

Bring EMPANADA FOR A DREAM
from Juan's hometown to your hometown...

The EMPANDADA FOR A DREAM creative team is asking for your support! Please help share the show with as big an audience as possible. Help fund this exciting, inspiring, and intimate play as it travels to Chicago, Los Angeles, and back to NYC.

Your contribution will cover costs like:

  • Travel expenses for the creative team,
  • Rehearsal space in each new city,
  • And applying to other festivals to take the show on tour.

Up next -- Collaboraction and Teatro Vista will be presenting EMPANDADA FOR A DREAM as part of their YO SOLO Festival of Latino Solo Shows.

ENTICING PERKS

To encourage fans to give as generously as possible, EMPANADA FOR A DREAM has partnered with several great local companies to offer terrific perks for early contributors. Any donation – no matter the size – is hugely appreciated and will go directly towards expanding the reach of Juan’s Cumbia-inflected urban self-portrait.

FRIEND US! LIKE US!

Connect to EMPANADA FOR A DREAM updates with these sites

  • Empanada For A Dream FB Page: https://www.facebook.com/EmpanadaForADream
  • Juan's Website: http://www.juanfranciscovilla.com/empanada-for-a-dream.html
  • Alex's Website: http://www.alexlevy.weebly.com

ARTIST BIOS

Juan Francisco Villa* (Playwright/Performer) grew up on the Lower East Side the son of first generation immigrants from Columbia. He is a recovering Catholic after 8 years at Our Lady of Sorrows Elementary, 4 years at the Jesuit All Boys High School La Salle Academy,  and 4 ½ years at Le Moyne College in Syracuse, NY (that’s 8 years of Jesuits).  Like a good native New Yorker, he left town -- for Chicago -- where he honed his skills at Improv Olympic, Second City, The Goodman Theater, Steppenwolf Theater, Lookingglass Theater and American Theater Company. He has had the honor of working with esteemed playwrights Laura Eason and Ifa Bayeza and has acted in El Grito del Bronx by Migdalia Cruz and Massacre or Sing to Your Children by Jose Rivera, both for the Goodman Theatre.  His Chicago Steppenwolf credits include Elliot: A Soldier’s Fugue by Quiara Alegria-Hudes and Take Me Out by Richard Greenberg.  Juan moved back to NYC and graduated from Maggie Flanigan’s Meisner Conservatory.  He has performed Off and Off Off Broadway at Rattlestick, Mabou Mines/SUITE, INTAR, terraNOVA, Rising Circle, Monarch, HERO Theater, Lark Play Development, Collaboration Town, BAX and 59E59. Juan has worked as a Teaching Artist with Manhattan Theater Club, and in Chicago, Pegasus Players, Salsation and Teatro Vista.  Through the Peoples Theater Project, he completed a school year teaching English skills through Acting Shakespeare to Harbor Heights 8th graders in Washington Heights. He has been an ensemble member of SALSATION, Chicago's first Latino Sketch/Improv Group and is a current ensemble member of InViolet Theater Company in NYC and Teatro Vista, Chicago’s largest, non–profit–equity, Latino theater company producing full scale, Latino oriented, theatrical productions in English. He will be doing a full production of Empanada for a Dream this summer in Chicago as a co-production with Teatro Vista and Collaberaction. He is also a playwright with plays “el dragon del village”, “gen-tried”, “he will rise” and “don chipotle” being currently being developed. Juan is a proud member of AEA/SAG/AFTRA. To stay up to date with him you can visit his website juanfranciscovilla.com.

Alex Levy’s work has been seen throughout the United States and around the world. He recently directed Empanada For a Dream in New York for Ballybeg (where he was recently appointed Artistic Director) and again for the soloNOVA Arts Festival.

His production of My Soul is a Witness was featured in the Hindu Metro-Plus International Theatre Festival in Chennai, India and toured several cities throughout India.  Alex twice led international tours through Jordan, Egyot, Turkey and Morocco sponsored by The U.S. State Department.  In 2010, Alex was selected to participate in Dah Theatre’s Internatial Research Center for Actors and Directors in Belgrade, Serbia.

His directing credits include the national tour of America Amerique (World Premiere) for Jena Productions.  In Los Angeles he directed the world premiere of In the Red for the ARK Theatre. Copenhagen and Dead Man’s Cellphone for UCLA.  Also for UCLA, he conceived, adapted and directed Home Front, a one-act play based on interviews with combat veterans in Southern California and A Dark Sun, a full-length ensemble based work based on the writings of Carl Jung.

Before moving to Los Angeles, Alex served as Artistic Director of Pegasus Players in Chicago. While at Pegasus, the theatre won seventeen Joseph Jefferson Citations, seven After Dark Awards.

For Pegasus, he directed several productions including Continental Divide, Golda’s Balcony (Jeff Award for “Outstanding Solo Performance), The Upper Room (Jeff Citation for “Best New Work”),  Black Caesar (Three Black Excellence Nominations), Still Life, Broadway Bound (Jeff nominated for four citations including “Best Production” and winner of the After Dark Award for “Best Ensemble”) and The One-Eyed Man is King as well as nine productions for the Chicago Young Playwrights Festival.

Alex holds a BA in Political Science from the University of Rochester and an MFA in Directing from The University of California-Los Angeles.
story_txt:
Fresh from sold out houses with Ballybeg at the Barrow Group Theatre and with terraNOVA Collective at the 9th Annual SoloNOVA Arts Festival, EMPANADA FOR A DREAM is a haunting love song to the Lower East Side. Juan Francisco Villa's return to the neighborhood of his childhood is a heartfelt and hilarious tale about family and home.
Bring EMPANADA FOR A DREAM from Juan's hometown to your hometown...
The EMPANDADA FOR A DREAM creative team is asking for your support! Please help share the show with as big an audience as possible. Help fund this exciting, inspiring, and intimate play as it travels to Chicago, Los Angeles, and back to NYC.
Your contribution will cover costs like:

Travel expenses for the creative team,
Rehearsal space in each new city,
And applying to other festivals to take the show on tour.
Up next -- Collaboraction and Teatro Vista will be presenting EMPANDADA FOR A DREAM as part of their YO SOLO Festival of Latino Solo Shows.
ENTICING PERKS
To encourage fans to give as generously as possible, EMPANADA FOR A DREAM has partnered with several great local companies to offer terrific perks for early contributors. Any donation – no matter the size – is hugely appreciated and will go directly towards expanding the reach of Juan’s Cumbia-inflected urban self-portrait.
FRIEND US! LIKE US!
Connect to EMPANADA FOR A DREAM updates with these sites


Empanada For A Dream FB Page: https://www.facebook.com/EmpanadaForADream


Juan's Website: http://www.juanfranciscovilla.com/empanada-for-a-dream.html


Alex's Website: http://www.alexlevy.weebly.com

ARTIST BIOS
Juan Francisco Villa* (Playwright/Performer) grew up on the Lower East Side the son of first generation immigrants from Columbia. He is a recovering Catholic after 8 years at Our Lady of Sorrows Elementary, 4 years at the Jesuit All Boys High School La Salle Academy,  and 4 ½ years at Le Moyne College in Syracuse, NY (that’s 8 years of Jesuits).  Like a good native New Yorker, he left town -- for Chicago -- where he honed his skills at Improv Olympic, Second City, The Goodman Theater, Steppenwolf Theater, Lookingglass Theater and American Theater Company. He has had the honor of working with esteemed playwrights Laura Eason and Ifa Bayeza and has acted in El Grito del Bronx by Migdalia Cruz and Massacre or Sing to Your Children by Jose Rivera, both for the Goodman Theatre.  His Chicago Steppenwolf credits include Elliot: A Soldier’s Fugue by Quiara Alegria-Hudes and Take Me Out by Richard Greenberg.  Juan moved back to NYC and graduated from Maggie Flanigan’s Meisner Conservatory.  He has performed Off and Off Off Broadway at Rattlestick, Mabou Mines/SUITE, INTAR, terraNOVA, Rising Circle, Monarch, HERO Theater, Lark Play Development, Collaboration Town, BAX and 59E59. Juan has worked as a Teaching Artist with Manhattan Theater Club, and in Chicago, Pegasus Players, Salsation and Teatro Vista.  Through the Peoples Theater Project, he completed a school year teaching English skills through Acting Shakespeare to Harbor Heights 8th graders in Washington Heights. He has been an ensemble member of SALSATION, Chicago's first Latino Sketch/Improv Group and is a current ensemble member of InViolet Theater Company in NYC and Teatro Vista, Chicago’s largest, non–profit–equity, Latino theater company producing full scale, Latino oriented, theatrical productions in English. He will be doing a full production of Empanada for a Dream this summer in Chicago as a co-production with Teatro Vista and Collaberaction. He is also a playwright with plays “el dragon del village”, “gen-tried”, “he will rise” and “don chipotle” being currently being developed. Juan is a proud member of AEA/SAG/AFTRA. To stay up to date with him you can visit his website juanfranciscovilla.com.
Alex Levy’s work has been seen throughout the United States and around the world. He recently directed Empanada For a Dream in New York for Ballybeg (where he was recently appointed Artistic Director) and again for the soloNOVA Arts Festival.
His production of My Soul is a Witness was featured in the Hindu Metro-Plus International Theatre Festival in Chennai, India and toured several cities throughout India.  Alex twice led international tours through Jordan, Egyot, Turkey and Morocco sponsored by The U.S. State Department.  In 2010, Alex was selected to participate in Dah Theatre’s Internatial Research Center for Actors and Directors in Belgrade, Serbia.
His directing credits include the national tour of America Amerique (World Premiere) for Jena Productions.  In Los Angeles he directed the world premiere of In the Red for the ARK Theatre. Copenhagen and Dead Man’s Cellphone for UCLA.  Also for UCLA, he conceived, adapted and directed Home Front, a one-act play based on interviews with combat veterans in Southern California and A Dark Sun, a full-length ensemble based work based on the writings of Carl Jung.
Before moving to Los Angeles, Alex served as Artistic Director of Pegasus Players in Chicago. While at Pegasus, the theatre won seventeen Joseph Jefferson Citations, seven After Dark Awards.
For Pegasus, he directed several productions including Continental Divide, Golda’s Balcony (Jeff Award for “Outstanding Solo Performance), The Upper Room (Jeff Citation for “Best New Work”),  Black Caesar (Three Black Excellence Nominations), Still Life, Broadway Bound (Jeff nominated for four citations including “Best Production” and winner of the After Dark Award for “Best Ensemble”) and The One-Eyed Man is King as well as nine productions for the Chicago Young Playwrights Festival.
Alex holds a BA in Political Science from the University of Rochester and an MFA in Directing from The University of California-Los Angeles.

story:
Our Story

The Many Women of Troy is a postmodern adaptation of Euripides’ Greek tragedy - this musical collage of war and suffering throughout history is seen through the eyes of five strong women wrestling with loss: Cassandra, the bitter prophetess; Andromache, the naive mother; Polyxena, the lost child; Hecuba, the vengeful queen; and Helen, the face that launched a thousand ships. They journey from Ancient Troy to modern times and back again, witnessing the causes and ramifications of human anger, ignorance, apathy, and hate. As they struggle though immeasurable grief and rail against the horrors of violence, they finally come to understand the improbable yet absolutely necessary need to rise above and move beyond repeating the mistakes of the past.


This groundbreaking work is being presented by the Pallas Theatre Collective, and we are thrilled to announce that it will be a part of both the Hollywood and Capital Fringe Festivals this coming summer! Check back for dates!


The Pallas Theatre Collective is a newly founded company that exists to develop and workshop new, original plays and musicals as well as to offer new interpretations of canonical works. We strive to serve as the vanguard of the neo-avantgarde theatre movement, skillfully combining fun and substance, broad audience appeal with profound and powerful productions.


The Impact

The Many Women of Troy has been workshopped at several different universities since 2003, and we believe that it is time to give the greater community a full production. This piece is beautifully and originally character driven. It asks questions and brings up issues rarely discussed on the musical theatre stage. With our acceptance at both the Hollywood and Capital Fringe Festivals, we will be able to bring this important show to both ends of the country, but we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $2500 by mid-June. The money that we raise will go towards flying actors and production staff coast to coast; printing programs, postcards, and other marketing necessities; and also just printing copies of the script and score. Every little bit helps! Please check out our perks, too; in addition to the perks listed, you will also receive eternal love and gratitude from the whole Pallas Theatre Collective family and a lot of free hugs.

Performance Dates

Hollywood Fringe (@ Open Fist Theatre)
June 17 @ 10pm
June 19 @ 6:30pm
June 20 @ 8pm
June 22 @ 10:30pm
June 25 @ 10:30pm

Tickets available at http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/347


Capital Fringe (@ Studio Theatre - Mead Theatre)
July 13 @ 9pm
July 14 @ 6pm
July 16 @ 2:30pm
July 19 @ 6:30pm

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Please check out and share our Facebook page, our Twitter, our YouTube channel, and also our website! We are also selling t-shirts off our website, and we get a commission for each shirt we sell. We appreciate and value any and all efforts to spread the word about Pallas Theatre and The Many Women of Troy.

story:
What is Pangaea: A Folk Opera?

Alone on fractured continents, six people must find a way to connect. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, Pangaea: A Folk Opera is told through devised songs and an ensemble cast. This show reimagines modern theatre by paying tribute to American folk and folk-rock musicians like
Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan and Dar Williams.

Anna Michael, a Philadelphia-native and founder of the Hum'n'Bards, has been heavily influenced by Philadelphia's independent theatre scene. In its inaugural show, Pangaea: A Folk Opera, Hum'n'Bards will share a collective theatrical experience with the local community in the 2016 Philadelphia FringeArts Festival.

Why do we need your support?

By donating to the campaign, you will be supporting the grassroots Philadelphia arts community. Pangaea: A Folk Opera, is independently funded with a budget of $2000 that breaks down as follows:

$1000 - Space (The Swing at the Adrienne Theatre in Rittenhouse Square)

$100 - Costumes

$100 - Makeup

$500 - Lights

$300 - Advertising and Festival Fees

Any additional funding will be used to compensate travel & cast/crew.

Where can I see the show?

The performance runs September 9 at 8pm and 10pm, September 10 at 10pm and 11:59pm, September 11 at 8pm and 10pm, September 15 at 8pm and 10pm, September 16 at 7pm and 9pm at the Swing located at the Adrienne Theater, 2030 Sansom Street, Philadelphia. Tickets for each performance are 15 dollars and are available in cash at the door, from the FringeArts website or www.humnbards.com.

To celebrate the inclusive nature of the Hum’n’Bards, the show has partnered with ReAnimator Coffee to provide free coffee at the 10pm and 11:59pm shows. Matt Scottoline, Head Roaster and a Director at ReAnimator Coffee says: “We love what FringeArts does for Philly and how they support artists who might not have other outlets. Almost everyone that works for us is involved in some kind of artistic pursuit, whether it’s music, visual art, writing or design.” In addition to free coffee, all late night performances include glowsticks and an underground art show featuring local Philadelphia talent. “We hope these late night shows will be a cross between a folk music gig and traditional theatre,” said Anna Michael, founder of the Hum’n’Bards.

Anna Michael, lead artist of Pangaea: A Folk Opera, is a Philadelphia-Native who graduated from Temple University with a degree in musical theatre. She is inspired by her fellow collaborators and says, “I had an idea for a Fringe show, but I knew my original story would be even stronger if I collaborated with some of the best upcoming talent in the Philadelphia theatre community.”

story:
The Best Kind of Weird.

Kicking off its landmark tenth season in Chicago, Tympanic is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit theatre company dedicated to producing new and developed work that contains both weird and fantastical subject matter. We create immersive, visceral worlds that provoke, inspire, and entertain. Through our Pay-What-You-Can Initiative, we strive to engage diverse audiences without the barrier of a high ticket price.

 

Ten Years of Weird.

Over the past ten years, Tympanic Theatre Company has transported audiences from Chicago to a Spanish bullfighting ring, the lonely cornfields of Nebraska, the farthest reaches of outer space - just to name a few. Fresh off our World Premiere of SWEET ANALYTICS, Hayes Borkowski's feminist dissection of "The Tragical History of Doctor Faustus", Season 10 continues with the absurdist classic WAITING FOR GODOT  by Samuel Beckett, set at the US-Mexico border and ruminating on the Latinx immigrant experience in pursuit of the elusive American Dream. The season will conclude with a third iteration of our nationally-recognized, album-inspired play festival. 

Season 10, as well as the launch of our new Pay-What-You-Can ticket initiative, reflects Tympanic's commitment to representation and inclusion within our storytelling and our audience engagement. 

 

Why Give?

We want to celebrate our tenth anniversary season by producing our most ambitious, provocative season yet - and we aim for art on our stages to serve as a catalyst for community conversations while remaining weird in spirit. 

As a small not-for-profit theatre company, we rely on donations such as yours for over half of our funding.  In return, you'll know that you are directly responsible for delivering daring, diverse and interesting new theatre to the Chicago community and beyond!  100% of all raised funds are used for production expenses, including but not limited to scenic construction, costumes, theater space, and online delivery.  That means your contribution becomes a tangible part of the next weird and provocative production we bring to the stage or directly to your home!

story:
Lincoln and Roosevelt High Schools are part of the Portland Public School District; schools do not budget money to help pay for theater. 

This year while Roosevelt is under construction, the students lack an auditorium. So, for the first time, East and West meet at Lincoln High School to perform the amazing musical classic, GREASE.

With 150 students GREASE will cost approx. $51,000
We need to raise $30,000, approximately 60% of the total budget.
Estimates include $12K for licensing rights, $8K for professional theatrical support, $8K for set construction, $6K for costumes/props, $4K for student scholarships, $4K Online ticketing, credit card fees, fundraising site fee, $2K for sound hardware and support, $2K for lighting hardware and support, $2K for cast/crew meals (doesn't include donations), $1K advertising/marketing, $2K PPS district building use charges
Your sponsorship is KEY to our students and their success.

PLEASE help us out!

story:
I have been awarded a bursary for the Bill Evans Dance Teacher Intensive (BETI) and International Conference on Somatics-based Dance Education in Franklin, Massachusetts 6th-18th July 2015. This campaign is to help me cover the accommodation and board costs so that I can attend.

*I have now reached my target thanks to all these wonderful people. Any further contributions exceeding this (still some time left!) will go towards travel costs (internal trains/buses, flights, insurance, visa) and accommodation immediately before and after the event.*


Who am I?

I am an Edinburgh based freelance dance artist and teacher/facilitator. I graduated in 2007 from the Northern School of Contemporary Dance in Leeds and have since worked with various choreographers and have developed a successful freelance career.

A few years ago  I suffered a serious hip ligament injury that left me unable to dance. I was told by doctors that I would most likely not be able to dance professionally again. However, I was lucky enough to come across somatic movement (specifically Laban/Bartenieff Fundamentals) and over I time I learned how to cope with my injury and returned to dancing.

I now work full time teaching and dancing. I teach dance classes for adults, primary aged children, young people, mums and babies and dancers with additional support needs in a variety of dance styles all over Edinburgh.

You can find more information, photos and videos on my website and Facebook page.


What is a somatics-based approach to dance education?

Somatic practices, such as Laban/Bartenieff Fundamentals, focus on connecting mind and body through movement and a deep level of self-awareness. In a dance context these approaches encourage self-acceptance, personal exploration/understanding and an intelligent way of moving that is more beneficial for the dancer’s body than traditional training methods. Somatics-based approaches to dance do this through developing an understanding of how the body organises, of personal habits and movement patterns. It then provides opportunities for re-organisation and finding new possibilities;

“Instead of striving to perform the "right” or “correct” movement, the dancer learns to move from an embodied source – fully receptive and responsive to the moment of movement. Such training is designed to free the dancer from rigid holding patterns or other constraints that bind thought, feeling, and action. More time is given to opening a space for pausing and reflecting.” (Glenna Batson, ‘Somatic Studies and Dance’, 2009, http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.iadms.org/resource/resmgr/resource_papers/somatic_studies.pdf). 


Why is this important?

My experience with injury is a fantastic example of how important this work is and can be. I am so grateful that I am able to continue dancing and really believe that this approach can help others. By attending the BETI and conference, I will gain more knowledge of somatic approaches and learn various ways of incorporating them into my teaching and creative practice so that I can help others with injuries and also help to prevent them.


What I need & What you get

The bursary I received covers the costs of attending the BETI and conference (value of $1,200). The remaining costs, such as flights, other travel expenses and costs outside this time will be covered by me (I will fly into Boston and fly back from NYC, spending 2 days in each city).

The £600 I hope to raise will help me to cover the 13 days/nights accommodation and board costs at Dean College for the duration of the BETI and conference.

*I have now reached my target thanks to all these wonderful people. Any further contributions exceeding this (still some time left!) will go towards travel costs (internal trains/buses, flights, insurance, visa) and accommodation immediately before and after the event.*

In exchange for your valued contributions you will receive one or a combination of the following rewards:

  • A big public thank you on my Facebook page and Twitter
  • A personal thank you postcard from the USA
  • Your name on a list of project sponsors on my website
  • A video of me improvising a dance performance in a tourist/public location in either Boston or NYC, which will be posted to Facebook
  • A 45 min 1-1 dance or movement coaching session, or a 1 hr group dance class (for up to 7 people) in Edinburgh.

What is the BETI and Conference about?

The Bill Evans Dance Teachers Intensive is a series of workshops for dance teachers, giving them practical experience of incorporating somatics-based approaches into their teaching practice. The workshop runs 10 days (6th – 15th July), 9am – 9pm each day with breaks, except Sunday (9am – 12pm).

Classes include:

· Laban-based Contemporary dance technique with pedagogy (x9)

· Anatomy Lab and Ballet pedagogy (x3)

· Choreography (x3)

· Creative dance for children (x3)

· Improvisation and dance-making (x3)

· Bartenieff Fundamentals (x3)

· Feldenkrais (x3)

The internationally renowned faculty includes Bill Evans, Don Halquist, Peggy Hackney, Kitty Daniels, Debra Knapp and Claire Porter; all experts in dance and somatic movement.

The conference runs 4 days (16th-19th July) and includes:

· 3 live dance performances

· keynote presentations by Bill Evans and Peggy Hackney

· 18 sessions (1 hour each) of presentations/workshops from practising dance artists on somatics-based approaches to dance education.

This is a unique opportunity to attend an intensive and diverse professional development event on using somatic-based approaches in dance with a strong focus on pedagogical practices. I aim to experience these approaches and incorporate them into my own creative and teaching practice in Scotland.

More information can be found here: http://www.dean.edu/Bill_Evans_Intensives.aspx

The £600 I hope to raise will help me to cover the 13 days/nights accommodation and board costs at Dean College for the duration of the BETI and conference.
*I have now reached my target thanks to all these wonderful people. Any further contributions exceeding this (still some time left!) will go towards travel costs (internal trains/buses, flights, insurance, visa) and accommodation immediately before and after the event.*
In exchange for your valued contributions you will receive one or a combination of the following rewards:


A big public thank you on my Facebook page and Twitter
A personal thank you postcard from the USA
Your name on a list of project sponsors on my website
A video of me improvising a dance performance in a tourist/public location in either Boston or NYC, which will be posted to Facebook
A 45 min 1-1 dance or movement coaching session, or a 1 hr group dance class (for up to 7 people) in Edinburgh.



What is the BETI and Conference about?
The Bill Evans Dance Teachers Intensive is a series of workshops for dance teachers, giving them practical experience of incorporating somatics-based approaches into their teaching practice. The workshop runs 10 days (6th – 15th July), 9am – 9pm each day with breaks, except Sunday (9am – 12pm).
Classes include:
· Laban-based Contemporary dance technique with pedagogy (x9)
· Anatomy Lab and Ballet pedagogy (x3)
· Choreography (x3)
· Creative dance for children (x3)
· Improvisation and dance-making (x3)
· Bartenieff Fundamentals (x3)
· Feldenkrais (x3)
The internationally renowned faculty includes Bill Evans, Don Halquist, Peggy Hackney, Kitty Daniels, Debra Knapp and Claire Porter; all experts in dance and somatic movement.

The conference runs 4 days (16th-19th July) and includes:
· 3 live dance performances
· keynote presentations by Bill Evans and Peggy Hackney
· 18 sessions (1 hour each) of presentations/workshops from practising dance artists on somatics-based approaches to dance education.
This is a unique opportunity to attend an intensive and diverse professional development event on using somatic-based approaches in dance with a strong focus on pedagogical practices. I aim to experience these approaches and incorporate them into my own creative and teaching practice in Scotland.
More information can be found here: http://www.dean.edu/Bill_Evans_Intensives.aspx

story:
Who is G.L.O.R.Y.?

We are The Glorious Ladies of Rasslin, Y'All! The only all-female theatrical wrestling league that is run entirely and performed entirely by women in Austin, TX. We are excited to crush our inaugural show in April! 

No Guts (or funds), No Glory

In the spirit of DIY, we're going to unleash a gritty, powerful, in-your-face explosion of feminist energy hell-bent on subjugating the male gaze in the most comedic and merciless way imaginable. 

We are working class women, students, actors, fighters, comedians, and artists who can transform trash into backdrops, used spandex into costumes, and car tires into a dang ring to throw ourselves on for your viewing entertainment.   

Unfortunately, this kind of talent doesn't materialize start-up capital from thin air. 

That's where you come in.

^ GLORY Shirt ^

With your contributions we can keep this movement running. It will allow us to book a venue, create props, construct a ring, implement proper audio/video, hire security, and produce merchandise in the hopes of being a self-sustaining organization in the future. 

Not only will you get some really great swag as rewards for your generosity, you will also be funding an incredible art project whose brutal, beating heart holds the hopes of the marginalized.

^ Donor Shirt ^

Why is G.L.O.R.Y. important?

Many of us are self-admitted wrestling nerds and are former/current wrestlers in various organizations including other female leagues. We have seen some of the worst aspects of the sport, including but not limited to: sexism, homophobia, transphobia, racism, and rampant, unchecked male privilege. 

We've also seen some of the best things: unbridled, joyful entertainment, the thrill of performance, the raw power of the slam, the energy from the crowd, and absurdly brilliant storylines.

We strive to be a safe space, free from harassment, a place where people can be their best selves in and out of the ring. 

G.L.O.R.Y. is modeled after many other successful leagues that have emerged in recent years, whose numbers are only growing. We want to be pioneers on the forefront of this new chapter in wrestling history and positive role models in the community.

Risks & Challenges

We have received overwhelmingly positive feedback thus far, but in our effort to include those who have perhaps been turned off by wrestling in the past due to some of the issues listed above, we may lose some of the more traditional fans associated with wrestling. Which is inherently risky, but a risk we are willing to take.

In our mission to include all types of women in performance and logistical positions in G.L.O.R.Y., we aren't able to include self-identified males on our roster. Our ultimate goal is to be a production 100% staffed by self-identified women and non-binary folks. Which is kind of a bummer for all of the incredibly talented men who have been, and continue to be, very supportive of our cause. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not all of us have extra scratch to support all the things we want to. Simply coming out to the show and seeing the triumph of G.L.O.R.Y. and telling your friends is a good way to support us. 

Men: We don't hate men! Some of our most vocal supporters are men. We want to create a product that is completely run by women, which is a rare thing in this world. Please, come to the show. Enjoy it. Feminism is a very broad (no pun) ideology. Many of us hold very different beliefs on what that means, but one thing we can all agree on is: watching women pummel each other in the squared circle is super dope. 

Women and non-binary friends: Come to the show! Please! We're doing this for you! And if you feel extra inspired about G.L.O.R.Y. and want to get involved in our next show or volunteer, please contact us at gloryatx@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

" Using your body as vehicle for the character, puppet or mask, is to understand that movement is not about moving but existing in a liminal space."

My name is Aisha Bentham and I am creator. 

I use my body to tell and re-tell stories through movement.

I have worked very hard to get to this point in my life where I know what I want. Where everything begins to fit into place and all that I didn't know I was asking for, falls at my feet.

#Getmetoberlin! Campaign is to help fund my dream of completing a post graduate program called 'Devising Theatre and Performance'. The Program uses physical exploration as a tool of creation. 

I couldn't imagine doing anything else.

I love theatre. I dedicated years of my life to this craft, and believe that it's mastery not only engages people but brings them closer to themselves.  

The time is now. I believe in my skills, my passion, my focus, my drive. This is the most important moment in my life and I want nothing but to be doing what I love most; creating theatre. 

I hope that you will see how through your contribution, you are on this journey with me.


A.

What We Need & What You Get

I'll keep it simple, I need to raise $27,000
Where the funds will go:
$14,000- Is for Tuition. 
$2,000- That is for school material, books, space fees, extended workshops/classes.
$3,000- Is for flight to and from Berlin
$8,000- Is for room and board for 7 months, along with food and transportation.
Its a piece of cake!
Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution, no problem!

All I ask is that you tell friends, family and spread my campaign via social media. To get updates on workshops, events and my fundraiser that I will be holding leading up to my departure, please follow me on Twitter (@missbentham) and Facebook (www.facebook.com/aishabentham)

Thank you in advance for your contribution and Support! It means everything to me!
