story:
Theatre You'll Love, Whether You Like It Or Not

Hamlet Isn't Dead is a young theater company making it's way through New York City, looking for fame, fortune, and favor amongst the world's elite Shakespeare companies. We’re big on our F-words.

We have an important mission -- to perform the plays of William Shakespeare in chronological order! Why on earth would anyone do this, you ask? (And if not, we’ll ask it for you - you’re welcome). Because while Shakespeare is revered as the best writer of the Western world, even he had to start from somewhere and develop his craft, like any artist.

As we get further into his chronology, he gets better as a playwright – and then our shows continue to get even better than what they have been so far – all of which have been great, if we say so ourselves. Shakespeare helps us, we help you be further entertained, and you, our entertained audiences, tell others and help keep the love of Shakespeare alive... which helps him. Even though he’s dead. It’s a wonderful cycle, isn’t it? We think so!

With help from our first successful crowdfunding campaign, we've produced the following, starting with Shakespeare's earliest work:

Two Gentlemen of Verona
Taming of the Shrew
Henry VI (Parts 1, 2, AND 3!)
Titus Andronicus
Richard III
Love's Labour's Lost

We're not resting on our laurels, though.  Currently, we're working on no less than FOUR different projects!  Our Repertory performances of Romeo and Juliet/Richard II are part of our main mission, but we're also producing a gender-swapped cabaret (HEDWIG ISN'T DEAD), and our first ever film, The Comedy of Errors!

We know what you're thinking -- and if not, we’ll think it for you (you’re welcome):  how could so many ambitious projects be fulfilling and high-quality both for us and you, the viewer?  The answer is: WITH YOUR HELP.

Our first campaign gave us a fantastic base upon which to spring forward.  Now, we have spent two years learning where best to send our next funding.

THE MAIN GOAL: more shows!  It may seem redundant, but the major limiting factor for us has been waiting to receive ticket sales before booking our next venue!  We'd much prefer bringing more theater to more people, more often.

That's where you come in! How can you help, you ask? (And if you didn’t, well...are you noticing a trend?) Our $3500 goal is the average cost of a HID show -- discovered and honed by hard-won experience.  This includes any space rental, marketing materials, outside personnel and other costs.  With a crowdsourced fund of this size, we'd be able to start producing our next show right away, bringing YOU more Hamlet Isn't Dead-y goodness all year round.

BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE -- If, by some happenstance, our base goal is already reached, you can still help!  We have some stretch goals that you could help achieve.  

FIRSTLY, we're looking for our very own Lights and Lighting board. We're a journey-man company, and the ability to transform any space into a theater is one we're sure to need.

SECONDARILY, we've gotten pretty good at marketing our own shows, but our experience pales in the light of professional publicists'.  At some point in the future, we'd like to hire a publicist, so that we can pay more attention to the artistic vision of our shows!

AND TO CONCLUDE, although we're fond of our apartments, they do leave something to be desired, clerically speaking.  Our ultimate dream is to have a dedicated office and theater space, but in the meantime, we'll rent a shared office to work from in the city.

Remember - with Hamlet Isn't Dead, it's Theater You'll Love, whether you like it or not.

story:
Durham based student theatre company Raving Mask returns to the Edinburgh Fringe with their latest production: Ozymandias.


Raving Mask is a theatre company that focuses on theatre of the absurd and new writing. It has enjoyed a meteoric rise since being founded in 2013, receiving widespread admiration and a clutch of awards. Productions of Samuel Beckett’s Waiting For Godot and Willy Russell’s Educating Rita in 2014 received extensive acclaim and five star reviews. At the Edinburgh Fringe 2014, their production of The Noctambulist, an original piece of writing, received sell-out audiences at Paradise in the Vault and a five-star review from Broadway Baby.


Ozymandias, is a piece of original writing from Company Director and Performer Hugh Train. The play was first staged at the 2015 Durham Drama Festival where it won the award for ‘Best Play’ and was then selected to be performed at the North East Drama Festival in Newcastle in May 2015, at which it received a phenomenal reception.


Ozymandias is a comic, one-man, absurdist piece, during which the audience meets and interacts with an interpretation of the titular character of Percy Shelley’s poem ‘Ozymandias’. Prepare to be transported to a surreal world of rudimentary biology lessons, Egyptian trivia, existential angst, 12A levels of nudity and The Bangles. As Ramesses the Great (Ozymandias to his friends), invites all passing travellers to an unsurpassable evening of wit, charm, profundity, music, storytelling and career advice. 


WHAT WE NEED

We hope to raise enough money to cover some of the production costs. As a student theatre company we have limited sources from which to acquire capital to fund this project. We would like to minimise the financial risk for members of the Raving  Mask team.  Your generous financial support  will go towards the following:

-Venue hire

-Marketing and PR

-Show budget (set, costumes, props etc)

-Renumeration of the production team


WHAT YOU GET

We're incredibly grateful for all of your help in getting Ozymandias  to the Fringe. And so, to say thank you, we are offering a selection of goodies in return for your kind donations:

- Personal thanks across social media

- Posters signed by cast

- A signed photo from Ozymandias

- Personal thanks on the programme and across social media

- Large donations will receive all of the above along with a gift basket containing a selection of items including a signed copy of The Bangles 'Walk Like an Egyptian' and a Toy dust mite.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that not everybody is capable of making a financial, however, there are other ways you can support the project:

- By sharing the campaign on social media

- By spreading the word about the show 

- By coming to watch the show at the 2015 Edinburgh Fringe 

-  Or by using the share tools that Indiegogo has to offer

story:
'Rebel Angel' is a theatrical play giving you the insight into John Keats' early life. Whilst the performance itself is set in the early 1800s, our modernistic approach allows for the piece itself to be accessible to everyone, everywhere to ensure that theatre continues to have a voice throughout future generations. 

Previously heard on BBC Radio 4, director/writer Angus Graham-Campbell takes his viewers on a journey of John Keats and his pursuit of self-discovery.

Our Indiegogo project, 'Rebel Angel', calls upon audiences across the globe to take part in our mission of launching our 3 week run at The Old Operating Theatre Museum in London. The museum is now fully accessible, reopening their doors this Autumn after being closed for refurbishment to put in a new lift.

Your support will help us on two crucial fronts: 

We will nurture a new generation of young talents, creative people and performers. 

We will seek collaborations with great artists and organisations from a wide range of genres, pushing the boundaries of what theatre can be, where it is going and who it is for.

 

WHAT WILL THIS INDIEGOGO FUND? 

With the raising of £2,500, the 'Rebel Angel' project will take off and allow anyone to be able to enjoy a 3 week run of performances programmed at the The Old Operating Theatre in London.

Modernity and tradition will come together in this unique setting. The play has been expressly created to be experienced in the evocative and atmospheric ambience of the Old Operating Theatre at St Thomas's Hospital, London. This is an extraordinary opportunity to share in the events of almost exactly 200 years ago in a unique and engaging setting identical to one in which Keats himself worked and operated in!

 

OUR GOALS

The funds raised will allow our message of innovation to be spread across the world. We will take full advantage of new talents to reach a broad and diversified audience, beyond the physical boundaries of our venue.

Thanks to your support, 'Rebel Angel' will be able to transmit our values to emerging artists, producers, costume designers and actors. We are nurturing the future generations to develop their artistry for the future opportunities that lie ahead!

This Indiegogo campaign is a first step towards our ambitious dream of creating more opportunities for emerging artists.            

The play explores the circumstances that led the young John Keats to abandon a promising career in medicine and surgery to become one of the most loved and acclaimed of English poets.

Perfect for everyone from English Romantics, literature fanatics, children, adults to your local poetry club. Rebel Angel takes its viewers on a journey of John Keats and his pursuit of self-discovery!

The play is presented in the well of the old theatre where the operations were performed while the audience will stand or sit on the tiers originally occupied by the watching (and frequently fainting) medical students.

 

 

The Old Operating Theatre Museum is the oldest in Europe and found in a unique space in the Herb Garret of St Thomas Church, which was once part of old St Thomas Hospital.

The building itself remained in use for many years and was known as ‘The Operating Theatre of Old St Thomas’ Hospital’. Following the departure of the hospital, the theatre remained in tack, however was 15 feet below ground level. After it’s current refurbishment, The Old Operating Theatre will reopen its doors to the public in Autumn 2017.

 

WHO ARE WE

Angus Graham-Campbell is a playwright, director, academic and teacher of English,Creative Writing and Drama. He is an English graduate of Trinity College, Cambridge, and he has taught at Repton, Sevenoaks, Eton, St Paul's School, New Hampshire, USA and Shore School, Australia. He is a Trustee of the Keats House and Museum in Rome, and of Keats' and Shelley's graves, and he edited The Keats-Shelley Review for twelve years and he has written widely on the Romantic poets. Two of his plays about the poets have been given site-specific productions in Rome and Hampstead and recently he produced a candlelit celebration of the Romantic poets in the Soane Museum, London. 'Rebel Angel' in its original format was commissioned for radio by the BBC to celebrate the bicentenary of Keats' birth and was directed by Richard Wortley and featured Julian Rhind Tutt as the poet. Angus has written about 30 plays, many of which have been produced on BBC radio.

Previously heard on BBC Radio 4 with Kim Wall, Jane Whittenshaw, David Timson, Geoffrey Whitehead, Gavin Muir, Paul Jenkins, Jonathan Newman, Melanie Hudson, Ian Masters and Alison Reid. Director Richard Wortley.

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Our project is ambitious and challenging, because:

We aim to recreate this once radio broadcasted play to The Old Operating Theatre which offers a beautiful yet compact space;
We aim to discover new talent in the world of theatre and production and offer them an endless amount of support.

We believe that the future of theatre is in the hands of the new generation and we aim to seek out the audience that knows no boundaries and accessible for all.

 

OUR SUPPORTERS

Rebel Angel has been commissioned by the Keats Shelley Memorial Association and developed with support from Arts Council England and The Old Operating Theatre Museum in London.

OUR GOALS
The funds raised will allow our message of innovation to be spread across the world. We will take full advantage of new talents to reach a broad and diversified audience, beyond the physical boundaries of our venue.
Thanks to your support, 'Rebel Angel' will be able to transmit our values to emerging artists, producers, costume designers and actors. We are nurturing the future generations to develop their artistry for the future opportunities that lie ahead!
This Indiegogo campaign is a first step towards our ambitious dream of creating more opportunities for emerging artists.            
The play explores the circumstances that led the young John Keats to abandon a promising career in medicine and surgery to become one of the most loved and acclaimed of English poets.
Perfect for everyone from English Romantics, literature fanatics, children, adults to your local poetry club. Rebel Angel takes its viewers on a journey of John Keats and his pursuit of self-discovery!
The play is presented in the well of the old theatre where the operations were performed while the audience will stand or sit on the tiers originally occupied by the watching (and frequently fainting) medical students.
 

 
The Old Operating Theatre Museum is the oldest in Europe and found in a unique space in the Herb Garret of St Thomas Church, which was once part of old St Thomas Hospital.
The building itself remained in use for many years and was known as ‘The Operating Theatre of Old St Thomas’ Hospital’. Following the departure of the hospital, the theatre remained in tack, however was 15 feet below ground level. After it’s current refurbishment, The Old Operating Theatre will reopen its doors to the public in Autumn 2017.
 
WHO ARE WE
Angus Graham-Campbell is a playwright, director, academic and teacher of English,Creative Writing and Drama. He is an English graduate of Trinity College, Cambridge, and he has taught at Repton, Sevenoaks, Eton, St Paul's School, New Hampshire, USA and Shore School, Australia. He is a Trustee of the Keats House and Museum in Rome, and of Keats' and Shelley's graves, and he edited The Keats-Shelley Review for twelve years and he has written widely on the Romantic poets. Two of his plays about the poets have been given site-specific productions in Rome and Hampstead and recently he produced a candlelit celebration of the Romantic poets in the Soane Museum, London. 'Rebel Angel' in its original format was commissioned for radio by the BBC to celebrate the bicentenary of Keats' birth and was directed by Richard Wortley and featured Julian Rhind Tutt as the poet. Angus has written about 30 plays, many of which have been produced on BBC radio.
Previously heard on BBC Radio 4 with Kim Wall, Jane Whittenshaw, David Timson, Geoffrey Whitehead, Gavin Muir, Paul Jenkins, Jonathan Newman, Melanie Hudson, Ian Masters and Alison Reid. Director Richard Wortley.
 
RISKS AND CHALLENGES
Our project is ambitious and challenging, because:
We aim to recreate this once radio broadcasted play to The Old Operating Theatre which offers a beautiful yet compact space;We aim to discover new talent in the world of theatre and production and offer them an endless amount of support.
We believe that the future of theatre is in the hands of the new generation and we aim to seek out the audience that knows no boundaries and accessible for all.
 
OUR SUPPORTERS
Rebel Angel has been commissioned by the Keats Shelley Memorial Association and developed with support from Arts Council England and The Old Operating Theatre Museum in London.

story:
Short Summary

Matthew McConaughey vs. The Devil is a Faustian comedy that dares to ask the question, “How the hell did Matthew McConaughey win an Academy Award?”

This show recounts how the RomCom starring stoner became an A-list award winner. Matthew has a loyal agent, his best friend Woody, and his beloved bongos. Now all he needs is to be taken seriously as an actor. Enter a demon with a deal from the Devil himself. Friendship, love and loyalty are all tested in this hell-raising adventure to win Matthew the Oscar...and save his soul.

Matthew McConaughey vs. The Devil was performed as a staged reading at Lakewood Theatre Company, in Lake Oswego, OR, as part of the 2016 Fertile Ground Festival. The reading was directed by Emilie Landmann, and music directed by Jon Quesenberry.

 

What We Need & What You Get

feature Matthew McConaughey vs. the Devil  in the Next Link Project. A typical production may cost anywhere from $35,000-$80,000 to fund a Next Link production. We are setting our target budget to a minimum of $80K, hoped to be raised by May, 2017.

Our costs include

  • Hiring=
    • Cast of 12 (Paid minimum wages according to NY laws)
    • Band of 5
    • Stage Manager (At AEA Union rate)
    • Lighting, Sound, Set and Props designers
    • Director
    • General Manager
    • Production Assistants
  • Renting rehearsal space
  • Renting wireless microphones for performances ($30/actor per performance)
  • Marketing and publicity material
  • Venue rental fees
  • Costumes
  • Properties 

Risks & Challenges

While this is only one step in creating this new musical, this is not the end-game. There are no guarantees where our musical will go after the festival. However, with the rights funds, we will be able to produce the best product, and get the right agents, producers and industry people interested.

IMPACT

The Festival provides theater lovers and industry scouts the opportunity to sample an unprecedented array of work, take risks on new artists, and to see some of the hottest musical theater talent tackling new roles in an intimate, affordable setting. Representing the diversity of the art form, the Festival's shows range from the serious to the ridiculous, from conventional musical comedies to avant-garde works, from operetta to punk rock, and everything in between.

With roughly 1,000 artists taking part in the Festival each summer, NYMF provides a fertile creative community that brings together both talented newcomers and some of New York's most established artists. The Festival provides writers, directors, actors, producers, choreographers, and designers at all stages of their careers valuable opportunities to take creative risks, hone their crafts, and expand their horizons.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this new musical with all of your friends and family! 

WHO WE ARE

Emilie Landmann (Book) is a theatre artist based in Portland, OR. She has worked on and off stage with companies such as  Profile Theatre, Post5 Theatre Company, Portland Actor’s Ensemble, Action/Adventure Theatre,  Nutz-n-Boltz and Original Practice Shakespeare. Additionally, she was a member of the 2013-14 Portland Playhouse Apprentice Company, where she wrote and performed the solo show “A Study on Outdoor Catholicism”. She received her BA in Theatre Arts from Western Washington University.

 

Carrie Morgan (Book, Lyrics) is a theatre artist and educator living in Portland, OR. Some of her favorite credits include: American Idiot (Triangle Productions),  Carrie the Musical (Stumptown Stages), Young Frankenstein (Lakewood Theatre Company), The Light in the Piazza, A Christmas Carol (Portland Playhouse), and A Chorus Line (Berkshire Theatre Group). She wrote and performed the solo show “Party[girl]” as an apprentice at Portland Playhouse in 2014. She received her BFA from Samford University where she studied Musical Theatre.

 

Jon Quesenberry  (Lyrics, Composer) is a musical director, composer, and actor in Portland, OR. He received his BA in Music from Warner Pacific College and spent some time in New York learning the craft of musical theatre writing from composer/lyricists Kirsten Childs and Joel Derfner through NYU’s Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program. In Portland he has worked with companies such as Portland Center Stage, Broadway Rose Theatre Company, Triangle Productions, Oregon Children’s Theatre, and more. Jon has received many local accolades and nominations for his work as a theatre artist.

ABOUT THE FESTIVAL

The New York Musical Festival nurtures the creation, production, and public presentation of stylistically, thematically, and culturally diverse new musicals to ensure the future vitality of musical theater.

 

Now in its fourteenth year, the Festival is the premier musical theater event in the world. The preeminent site for launching new musicals and discovering new talent, the Festival provides an affordable platform for artists to mount professional productions that reach their peers, industry leaders, and musical theater fans. More than 90 Festival shows have gone on to productions on and Off-Broadway, in regional theaters in all 50 states, and in more than 24 countries worldwide. Festival alumni have received a wide array of awards including the Tony Award® and the Pulitzer Prize. In 2013, NYMF received a special Drama Desk Award in recognition of its work "creating and nurturing new musical theater, ensuring the future of this essential art form."
 

NYMF is the flagship program of National Music Theater Network, Inc., a 501(c) (3) not-for-profit organization. 2017 NYMF is sponsored by The City of New York Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment, Fuzzrocket, PRG, TheaterMania, and Clear Channel Outdoor, and is supported, in part, in part, by an award from the National Endowment for the Arts, and by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs.
 

The NYMF PASS is a great way to experience The New York Musical Festival. With a NYMF PASS, you can get into the theater before individual ticket holders. Passes also offer the exclusive ability to book tickets before they go on sale to the public. Individual tickets are now on sale!

For more information, please visit: www.nymf.org

story:
Hello! We are The Outbound Project! 


We're an Award Winning Physical Theatre Company with an aim to create exciting, visually dynamic theatre that explores the human condition
'12 Million Volts' 


Close your eyes. Now, imagine a man…


Actually – don’t! Let The Outbound Project imagine him for you using award winning visual and physical theatre and storytelling. The company bring the story of Nikola Tesla to life in a dynamic performance using holograms, pigeons with lasers coming out of their eyes, and lighting wizardry.
We are asking you to support our new show and help us bring our vision to life!

'12 Million Volts' is a co-production with Marine Theatre in the heart of Lyme Regis as part of their R&D by the Sea programme. Our collaboration has ensured that '12 Million Volts' has a platform to reach a wider audience and has given us the opportunity to begin our initial devising process. 
http://www.marinetheatre.com/12-million-volts-w...


We have also been programmed at two London venues; New Diorama Theatre and The Space and are so excited to share our production in these three exceptional venues.

 

However, we need your help to help get us there and create the most visually exciting and engaging theatre we know we are capable of doing. There are some essential costs which need covering to make this project a reality. With your support we will be able to raise the £1,500 needed to finish the show. 
Here is a breakdown of the costs:

£ Set, Props, and Costume – Our style of theatre is heavily dependent on the actors using lights on stage rather than completely relying on a conventional lighting rig. To do this we need to buy lights and batteries; a lot of batteries. To go along with this to make the best possible show we need costumes that will be made our designer and that will help with our storytelling on stage. 


£ Accommodation - We have secured accommodation at a great price using home stays which are the cheapest form of accommodation in the Lyme Regis Area.


£ Marketing costs – All shows require some level of marketing and we want to make an extra push to help promote the show to as large an audience as possible both in Lyme Regis and in London. We are receiving some marketing support from the venues we are performing at but would want to extend our marketing beyond our organic reach.


£ Travel - To get the company of five (4 actors and 1 director) as well as the props for the show to all the venues. We have a car that has been transporting us to and from Lyme Regis. Which has saved us on travel costs already. But with this initial saving we need to be able to afford insurance and petrol.


£ - Contingency - It is ALWAYS important to have contingency in case anything goes wrong. If we need extra marketing materials, emergency travel, broken props or hidden costs, this would cover it all.


Without your support we will not be able to make the a show that meets our high standards that we hold for ourselves as a company. Your help is very important to us and we have got some wonderful rewards to offer you for your generous contributions.


If you would like to see the show it debuts June 21st and 22nd at Marine Theatre in Lyme Regis. Followed quickly by a two-night stand at New Diorama Theatre in London on June 24th and 25th. We will also be performing the show at The Space in London on August 1st-5th.

Marine Theatre, Lyme Regis, 21st-22nd June
New Diorama, London, 23-24th June
The Space, London, 1st-5th August

Any amount you can donate will get us one step closer to creating a show that will be inspiring and breathtaking for our audiences. We will be incredibly grateful for anything you can give! Thank you for taking the time to look at our page, please share it if you can and we hope to see you at a showing of “12 Million Volts”.

Risks and challenges 

Creating theatre as an independent theatre company always has its own range of risks. However, we have already managed to reduce many of these thanks to the support we have received from various arts organisations. With '12 Million Volts' being co-produced by the Marine Theatre we are immediately engaged with the local theatre communities and through our advertising will be able to reach out further. In London our relationship with New Diorama Theatre has created a net of support that will help the show during its time there. The Outbound Project has already developed a strong reputation from its previous show The Mission which created a following for the company. We have already secured accommodation at an affordable rate and we have a strict budget to ensure every penny we raise is spent wisely. Support from the Marine Theatre will ensure its debut will not disappointing to our new audience, along with mentorship from New Diorama we are able to excite our current London base.

story:
A Quest For Treasure (in the form of digital funds)

Hello! My name is Sarah Fiete, and I have written the book, music, and lyrics for "PYM: A New Musical." I've been putting my Masters Degree in Musical Theatre Writing (NYU Tisch '15) to use by lovingly creating this full-length show for the past three years. Despite being one of his lesser-known works, Poe's "The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket" felt very familiar to me the first time I read it. The young (and reckless) best friends, the trials they stumble into, the descent into a surreal world... There are elements of his novel that feel indelible, not firmly planted within the context of 1838. And the sea, well, it sings.

A little over a year ago, I was fortunate enough to have director Marella Martin Koch join this project, and she has remained an integral part of its creation. "PYM" was first presented at Hudson Theatre's Dress Circle Lobby in April 2018 to a standing-room-only crowd. Since then, we have spent the last year diving deeper into the story and drumming up support for this work.

Recently, "PYM" was accepted into Dixon Place's programming. We are thrilled that this premiere venue for new and experimental work would lend us its stage. This performance will occur on  April 22, 2019, at 7:30pm. It is an Equity Showcase, bigger in scale than anything we've done with this project yet.

This Showcase will feature an incredibly talented group of individuals whose careers I am proud to support. And the work itself? We truly believe we've built something with an honest, unique voice, something that will make you laugh and cry and want to know these characters as friends. I am producing it because I believe in it; and from the feedback we've garnered so far, it's sparking interest, and others are believing in it, too.

But producing takes a great deal of time, effort, and money. And though the first two don't feel like a chore at all because I love this project so much, my love alone can't feed these artists.

 

What We Need & What You Get

So what does this mean?

  • The majority of the funding goes to paying these eleven artists (actors, directors, designers). They are the heart and soul of this production. We could have a bare stage and I would still be excited to show you our work because they are a part of it.
  • For supporting us, you can get custom gear for all your ocean (or beach) adventures, created by artists who have volunteered their time. (Don't forget to SELECT the Perk of choice when making your contribution!)
  • Funds will additionally be used for marketing, rehearsal space rental, set, and props.

The Impact

The purpose of a Showcase is to, well, show off the work, to encourage a subsequent production. This show will not die at this stage. A few points of note:

  • This is an opportunity to get on the ground level of a new musical. Being a contributor here means building a personal relationship with this team, one we won't forget the next time "Pym" is produced.
  • I have previously used IndieGogo to fund my song cycle, "Hyperlink." This song cycle's successful funding and presentation are directly responsible for where "Pym" is today.
  • Even if you aren't so sure about "Pym" itself, your contributions will support my ten fellow artists and their careers in the theatre industry.

Risks & Challenges

If we don't reach our funding, "PYM" will still happen. When we received this opportunity, I made sure I was prepared to pay out of pocket if it came to that. However, the risk for paying out of pocket is two-fold:

  • The layered experience of the presentation would likely suffer, since we would be in Essentials Mode
  • It could diminish the chance of "Pym" being presented in the future

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are financially unable to contribute, there are other ways you can help us with this campaign!

  • LIKE the "PYM: A New Musical" Facebook page for updates about this project
  • ENCOURAGE folks to buy tickets: https://dixonplace.org/performances/pym-a-new-m...
  • SHARE this campaign! IndieGoGo has a great set of Share tools that makes it easy to post the campaign to social media.

 

THANK YOU!

With love and gratitude,

Sarah Fiete

www.sarahfiete.com

story:
Taming of the Shrew

The idea of this project came when contemplating a season of shows that lift up empowered female voices. We knew we wanted to do a Shakespeare show with all female players, but in true Rising Tide fashion, we wanted to put our own twist on it. So, with the help of our friend/local playwright Natalie Liccardello, we turned Shakespeare's most notoriously chauvinistic play into an original piece about a group of women going through some serious therapy. We have cut Shakespeare's original script down to its bare bones and are bulking it up with improvisational comedy and modernized text, featuring some of KC's funniest female talent.

TotS Team

Producers: Casey Jane and Bob Linebarger

Board of Directors: Mark Mattison, Christie Kennard and Sarah Aptilon

Playwright: Natalie Liccardello

Director: Shawnna Journagan

Stage Manager: Becky Ochoa

Cast: Nicole Hall, Casey Jane, Briana Van Deusen, Charmaine Merriweather, Markeyta L. Young, Madilynn Mansur, Kathleen Mitchell, Margaret Shelby, Elizabeth A. Hillman, Emmy Panzica, and Lilly Meier 

How Your Donations Will Help

We are working to raise the money for this show in multiple ways, but your Indiegogo contribution will go a long way. Here's what your contribution will go to:

- Compensation for the time and talent of our actors, tech crew, and stage manager

- Cost of venue

- Set, props, and costumes for the show

- Marketing materials

Rising Tide Productions

Rising Tide Productions is a new theatre company based out of Kansas City, MO. Formerly known as Different Choices, RTP is dedicated to highlighting fresh perspective, bringing new ideas and woke interpretations of old ideas to the forefront, while raising awareness and funds for local non-profits and enriching untapped KC markets with grassroots theatrical productions. RTP is run by Bob Linebarger and Casey Jane, two passionate artists who thrive on how differences and collaboration bring power to expression. So far, RTP has six full productions under its belt: The Bottom of Everything, at KC Fringe 2012; Danny and the Deep Blue Sea in 2014, Matt and Ben in 2015, Silly Animals: A Comedy of the Human Drama in 2016, Elephant by Lewis Morrow in 2018, and The Summer House by Christie Kennard in 2019.

We know that the privileged can and must learn to listen to the oppressed, and by truly understanding these stories, progress will be made toward the empathetic existence we are all capable of. Through communication and collaboration we can rise above the ways in which we hold ourselves back, and we believe it is stories like ones we have produced and will continue to produce that help push us forward and up toward that goal.

story:
Le projet de Compagnie

La Compagnie Vadé, c'est d'abord la rencontre entre 6 comédiens formés à l'Ecole Internationale de Théâtre Lassaâd à Bruxelles... et puis, de cette rencontre l'envie de créer des projets, des spectacles, des chansons. L'envie de s'attaquer à un univers, qui joue avec les mots et les images. Ensemble, nous souhaitons travailler sur une humanité sans fars : l'Homme aussi beau que laid. A travers un humour noir, qui rit de ce qui dérange, et qui s'amuse des conventions.

Actuellement, nous sommes en création d'un spectacle de chants polyphonique : Bestiaire Musical. Il se jouera dans un premier temps aux mois de Mars, Avril et Mai entre la France et la Belgique.

Pour créer ce Bestiaire, nous travaillons régulièrement sous forme de résidences, dans différents lieux de la belle Bruxelles, mais aussi dans le Nord de la France. Nous investissons avec nos propres fonds sur les costumes, la scénographie, les déplacements, les lieux de résidences et tous les frais qui en découlent.

Par la suite, nous voudrions voir ce Bestiaire Musical grandir et se transformer en véritable spectacle modulable selon les lieux et évènements (théâtre, cabarets, bars, performance, lieux insolites...).

C'est pourquoi nous avons décidé de faire appel à vous, à vos dons, afin de mener à bien ce premier projet, et lancer efficacement ceux à venir !


A quoi servira la collecte ?

Vos dons nous permettrons, très simplement, de mener à bien toute cette aventure, de partir sur de bonnes bases pour cette compagnie naissante. Nous devons investir notamment dans la création de costumes, de maquillages, mais aussi la location de matériel pour les représentations à venir.

Ce fond servira également à financer nos futures séances de répétitions, car les lieux ont un prix, mais aussi les déplacements qui se joignent à tout ça.

Nous avons également fait appel à un réalisateur pour tourner notre premier clip, qui nous suivra tout au long de nos aventures théâtrales.

Votre contribution nous permettra d'inviter et de collaborer avec d'autres artistes musiciens, chanteurs, comédiens, costumiers, danseurs... dans notre souhait de créer un spectacle pluridisciplinaire.

Pour finir, ces dons nous servirons à communiquer efficacement sur la diffusion de ce spectacle à travers flyers et affiches.

Avec votre soutien financier, vous contribuerez à la création et la diffusion de nos spectacles et vous permettrez ainsi l'essor de cette jeune compagnie pleine d'envie ! Avec votre aide, nous pourrons continuer avec une grande joie à développer nos projets et à rendre réelles nos idées les plus folles !


Le Bestiaire Musical

Mise en scène et chef de chœur - Sophie Lavallée

Avec Pauline Caraglio, Viki Kesmaecker, Sophie Lavallée, Lisa Lecoq, Eva Schumacher et Emre Yildizlar.


Le spectacle

La Compagnie Vadé propose un spectacle de Théâtre Musical. Six personnages décalés, issus de différents horizons décident de mêler leurs univers dans des chants communs. Leur répertoire est des plus éclectiques. Allant de chants traditionnels (tsiganes, russes...) à des morceaux de jazz en passant par le slam et le cabaret, ces six énergumènes nous emmènent dans un univers décalé plein d'humour et de charme. En s'appropriant ces chants, ils vous emmèneront dans un voyage à travers les émotions.


Note d'intention

En février 2015, nous avons découvert le dadaïsme, en travaillant sur la Ursonate de Kurt Schwitters, et ce que ce mouvement offre comme liberté de création.

Nous avons été très touchés par les sonorités qu’offraient des mots dépourvus de sens et leur musicalité. C’est à ce moment-là que l’envie de monter un spectacle de chant polyphonique nous est venue.

Bestiaire Musical, est le résultat de plusieurs recherches, de plusieurs rencontres avec des styles musicaux tout à fait différents. Nous nous sommes nourris d'univers tels que les chants grégoriens, chants des balkans et des groupes comme les Dakh Daughters, La Mal Coiffée, Double 6.

Dans ce spectacle, nous travaillons la matière vocale, nous nous amusons avec les instruments que nos six voix offrent et en faisons une partition. Nous avons commencé par des reprises et puis par improvisations nous avons débuté nos propres compositions. Par nos différents timbres de voix des personnages se sont dessinés. S’en est suivi un travail sur les costumes et les maquillages très poussés, afin de mettre en exergue l’histoire de chacun et que l’image parle d’elle-même. Ainsi nous avons mêlé mouvements et voix. C’est un vrai patchwork musical.


L'équipe


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pauline Caraglio – Région Montpelliéraine

Après la découverte du théâtre dans une compagnie amateur, Pauline entre à l’Université de Montpellier pour suivre une licence d’Arts du Spectacle.

Pendant ses trois années, elle joue le monologue 4.48 Psychose de Sarah Kane, Roman-Dit de Daniel Danis, participe à la création de la compagnie Roulotte et Bergamot et créer La marchande de sable, pièce interactive se jouant lors de repas dans un restaurant.

Parallèlement, elle se forme à la jonglerie en autodidacte et découvre l’univers du cirque et du clown.

Elle décide en 2013 de poursuivre son apprentissage du jeu théâtral à l’Ecole Internationale de Théâtre LASSAÂD.

Aujourd’hui, elle est co-fondatrice de la Compagnie Vadé et continue sa formation en acrobatie.

-------------------------------

Viki Kesmaecker – Région Lilloise

Viki découvre le théâtre à l’âge de 13 ans avec Bernard Pamart.

En 2008, elle s’envole pour l’Ontario pendant un an, le temps de voir du pays et de développer plusieurs compétences artistiques, telles que le chant, la musique (guitare et saxophone), la danse (claquette, comédie musicale, modern jazz) et le théâtre.

En 2009, elle décide de continuer l’aventure théâtrale et fait une licence d’Arts du Spectacle. Pendant ses trois années, elle suit plusieurs stages de masque, d’acrobatie et découvre le clown avec Stéphanie Constantin de la Compagnie l’Etourdie. Cette dernière rencontre sera une véritable révélation théâtrale.

En 2012, Viki part à Paris et intervient en milieu carcéral avec le GENEPI (Groupement Etudiant National de l’Enseignement aux Personnes Incarcérées).

L’année suivante, elle intègre l’Ecole Internationale de Théâtre LASSAÂD à Bruxelles.

Aujourd’hui, elle est co-fondatrice de la Compagnie Vadé. Elle fait également partie de la Ligue d’Improvisation de Marcq-en-Baroeul et met en scène Roméo et Juliette pour la Compagnie Le Bus. Elle continue également sa recherche sur le jeu clownesque et a pour projet de mettre en place des ateliers de théâtre de mouvements en milieu carcéral.

-------------------------------

Sophie Lavallée – Lyon

Sophie commence le théâtre à 8 ans et y trouve un beau moyen d’exprimer ses rêves et d’exploiter son imagination débordante.

Le bac en poche, elle décide de partir à la grande aventure du voyage. Elle arpente les routes de France, les chemins de Cuba, d'Israël et d'Italie, dort sous tipis, yourtes et cabanes. Pendant ses périples, elle rencontre entre autre le théâtre de rue, le théâtre forum et, surtout, le clown.

En 2013, elle pose ses valises à Bruxelles et entre à l’Ecole Internationale de Théâtre LASSAÂD. Elle y découvre une véritable vocation de chef de cœur et de chanteuse, grâce à la Méthode Feldenkreis enseignée dans cette école.

De cette découverte, elle entraîne la Compagnie Vadé à approfondir le chant polyphonique.

Aujourd’hui, Sophie compose et arrange de multiples morceaux, notamment avec la Compagnie Vadé dont elle est co-fondatrice et chef de cœur.

Elle rencontre également par le biais du chœur de chants du monde Kimia la chanteuse et chef de chœur Valérie Gardou, qui intervient sur la première création de la Compagnie Vadé: Bestiaire Musical.

Depuis 2014, Sophie fait également partie de La Compagnie du Galetas, compagnie de théâtre du mouvement. Elle participe aux différentes créations de la compagnie, passant du spectacle de rue à l'adaptation de L'Histoire du Soldat (Igor Stravinsky, Louis-Ferdinand Ramuz) où elle y interprète le Diable.

-------------------------------

Lisa Lecoq – Le Havre

Lisa débute le théâtre à l’âge de 8ans et cette passion ne la lâchera pas jusqu’à en faire son métier.

Parallèlement à une licence d’Arts du Spectacle à Caen, elle intègre les ateliers de la compagnie Papillon Noir Théâtre (théâtre de corps, Eugenio Barba, Grotowsky) de 2007 à 2009 puis y reviendra comme comédienne professionnelle sous la direction du metteur en scène Charly Venturini en 2012.

Elle suivra également les ateliers proposés par la compagnie Frappe Tête Théâtre (théâtre de mouvement, chant, cabaret) de 2011 à 2013.

Elle multiplie les expériences d’année en année. Comédienne dans plusieurs courts métrages, workshops d’effeuillage burlesque auprès des Kisses Cause Trouble à Paris, stages axés sur le théâtre et le handicap, etc…

Elle se forme également comme maquilleuse beauté, théâtre et effets spéciaux en autodidacte.

Passionnée de danse (formation classique et contemporaine puis danses latines et flamenco) et de chant (formation chant jazz), elle décide en 2013 de partir à Bruxelles pour suivre la formation de l’Ecole Internationale de Théâtre LASSAÂD dont elle sortira en 2015.

C’est après cette expérience riche et intense qu’elle fonde la Compagnie Vadé avec 5 autres compagnons de voyage et continue sa formation personnelle en Art-Thérapie.

-------------------------------

Eva Schumacher – Strasbourg

Après l’obtention d’un baccalauréat théâtre, Eva se lance dans les études de philosophie à l’Université de Strasbourg. Parallèlement, elle suit des cours au Conservatoire de théâtre et crée sa première compagnie Le Théâtre Sauve qui Peut.

En 2010, elle met en scène Ivanov de Tchekov puis un texte co-écrit avec l’un des membres de sa compagnie : Première Nuit, texte repris au Festival Theatralis en 2012.

Au-delà de la mise en scène, Eva est passionnée par l’univers du cabaret, mêlant corps, esthétisme et voix.

C’est pourquoi elle suit également un enseignement d’effeuillage burlesque à l’Ecole des Filles de Joie et prends des cours de chant lyrique.

En 2013, elle intègre l’Ecole Internationale de Théâtre LASSAÂD à Bruxelles où elle rencontrera ses cinq compagnons de voyage avec lesquels elle fonde la Compagnie Vadé en 2015.

-------------------------------

Emre Yildizlar - Turquie

En 2013, il termine ses études de « Linguistique Comparée et Langues étrangères appliquées » à l’Université de Galatasaray d’Istanbul.

Depuis 2007, il fait partie de la troupe de théâtre de son université où il anime des ateliers sur le mouvement et le jeu corporel. Il joue également dans plusieurs spectacles en turque et en français avec lesquels il part en tournée dans plusieurs villes de Turquie et à Paris.

Curieux de développer ses compétences, il part à Bruxelles en 2013 pour entrer à l’école Internationale de théâtre LASSAÂD.

Aujourd’hui, Emre est co-fondateur de la Compagnie Vadé. Il a également un duo de danse théâtre Hayali avec Mélissa Guex et donne des workshops de théâtre de mouvement.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

l’obtention d’un baccalauréat théâtre, Eva se lance dans les études de
philosophie à l’Université de Strasbourg. Parallèlement, elle suit des cours au
Conservatoire de théâtre et crée sa première compagnie Le Théâtre Sauve qui
Peut.
En 2010,
elle met en scène Ivanov de Tchekov puis un texte co-écrit avec l’un des
membres de sa compagnie : Première Nuit, texte repris au Festival
Theatralis en 2012.
Au-delà
de la mise en scène, Eva est passionnée par l’univers du cabaret, mêlant corps,
esthétisme et voix.
C’est
pourquoi elle suit également un enseignement d’effeuillage burlesque à l’Ecole
des Filles de Joie et prends des cours de chant lyrique.
En
2013, elle intègre l’Ecole Internationale de Théâtre LASSAÂD à Bruxelles où
elle rencontrera ses cinq compagnons de voyage avec lesquels elle fonde la
Compagnie Vadé en 2015.-------------------------------Emre
Yildizlar - Turquie
En
2013, il termine ses études de « Linguistique Comparée et Langues étrangères
appliquées » à l’Université de Galatasaray d’Istanbul.
Depuis
2007, il fait partie de la troupe de théâtre de son université où il anime des
ateliers sur le mouvement et le jeu corporel. Il joue également dans plusieurs
spectacles en turque et en français avec lesquels il part en tournée dans
plusieurs villes de Turquie et à Paris.
Curieux
de développer ses compétences, il part à Bruxelles en 2013 pour entrer à
l’école Internationale de théâtre LASSAÂD.
Aujourd’hui,
Emre est co-fondateur de la Compagnie Vadé. Il a également un duo de danse
théâtre Hayali avec Mélissa Guex et donne des workshops de théâtre de
mouvement.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

story:
Help us get our show on the road!

 

Last year, we staged the first-ever English translation of MAKLENA in the UK; this year, we have the incredible opportunity to share our production in a theatre festival celebrating the work of MAKLENA’s playwright (Mykola Kulish), its 1933 director (Les Kurbas), and the Ukrainian cultural renaissance from which MAKLENA emerged. We would love the chance to be part of this project (click here for more details; it’s super exciting if we do say so ourselves!). This will be the first time that Night Train will get to travel outside of the UK to share and make work — and our first chance to truly enact our mission of bridging borders through international theatre.

For the past few months, we’ve been planning this festival from the ground up with our partners in Ukraine. We need your help to give us the final push so that we can be there in person!

 

Why is bringing MAKLENA to the festival important?

Our first-ever English-language production of MAKLENA will be staged and seen in Kharkiv, the very city of MAKLENA’s premiere production in 1933, making a strong statement about the play's enduring contemporary and international relevance.

Listen to feedback from our audiences during the 2018 UK run.

“Captivating, heart-wrenching and genuinely funny.”
- ★★★★★ Theatre Bubble

“Startlingly well directed, with performances of fierce commitment and great clarity”
- Dominic Dromgoole, Artistic Director of Shakespeare's Globe 2006-2016

“One of the rare occasions where you see West End quality on the fringe, just ready to burst out onto bigger and better” things.”
- The Prickle

 

The Journey: Moving Forward.

So far, thanks to a number of generous folks and organizations (including the International Renaissance Foundation and SigmaBleyzer), we have raised £11k of our £20k budget, with funds earmarked to cover the cost of Night Train’s travel to and from Kharkiv and the running costs of the festival for our Kharkiv partners.

This means that we're still seeking:

  • £2,000 additional private sponsorship
  • £2,000 from a crowdfunding campaign in Ukraine (to cover accommodation costs & miscellaneous other festival costs), led by Teatr Na Zhukakh
  • £5,000 from crowdfunding in the UK (to cover artist salaries) — and this is where you come in!

 

Full Steam Ahead!

Even if you can’t contribute at this time, there are still ways to show your support and keep our Night Train on track.

Sharing this campaign on Facebook or Twitter dramatically increases the visibility of our project and our likelihood of reaching our goal — and Kharkiv!

From Night Train and our collaborators: THANK YOU! Let the journey begin!

 

Still curious? Read on to learn more about our upcoming festival, MAKLENA, and Night Train.

 

Kharkiv International Theatre Festival: “1919-2019: Kulish. Kurbas. Shakespeare.”

In 1919, groundbreaking director Les Kurbas began work on Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet.

In the 1920s, Kurbas and playwright Mykola Kulish were at the cutting edge of theatrical innovation across Europe.

In 2019, 100 years later, Ukrainian and British theatre companies will come together in Kharkiv to celebrate the creative conversation between Kulish, Kurbas and Ukrainian-language Shakespeare.

The 5-day festival in June 2019 will feature:

PERFORMANCES inspired by the theatre of the ‘Garrotted Renaissance’ will re-explore the work of Kulish and Kurbas, who is well-known for his avant-garde productions of Shakespeare:

Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet | Teatr Na Zhukakh, Teatr Arabesky (Kharkiv)

Mykola Kulish’s Maklena | Night Train Theatre Company (UK), Luhansk Drama Theatre (Luhansk / now displaced to Severodonetsk due to conflict in Eastern Ukraine)

Mykola Kulish’s And That’s How Huska Died | Kimnata T (Kharkiv)

Kulish: Dialogue Across Space and Time | Teatr Inakshe (Kharkiv)

Tastes of Renaissance Short Performances | 5 additional Kharkiv-based companies

EDUCATIONAL AND PUBLIC OUTREACH

• Free workshops and masterclasses will be held by British artists from Night Train for local students interested in theatre. Two types of workshops will be offered: puppetry and movement master classes, and English-through-theatre workshops. The festival will also include professional master classes between Ukrainian and British companies for in-person exchange of ideas and techniques in order to foster ties for future collaboration.

• Public talks and discussions will bring knowledge about the Garrotted Renaissance from academic ‘ivory towers’ into the public sphere.

• Portable mini-exhibition at the Kharkiv literature museum with information about Kulish, Kurbas and avant-garde Shakespeare in 1920s Ukraine.

• Outdoor performances in central Kharkiv will ensure that news of the festival reaches the broadest possible audiences. Festival highlights will be performed in central Kharkiv.

• Street art competition will bring together local artists to paint murals of Kulish, Kurbas and Shakespeare in the courtyard of Teatr Arabesky.

 

What’s MAKLENA all about?

Our production of MAKLENA is an adaptation of Mykola Kulish’s poetic tragicomedy, written in 1933 during the Stalinist period. After Kulish was executed by the Soviet authorities, his works were banned and MAKLENA was lost to the world for decades.

Our production incorporates original music, puppetry, and physical theatre to depict the rich fantasy world of the play and highlight its sharp contemporary resonance. The play tackles questions that remain globally immediate: the place of ideology in society and the dangers of taking it to the extreme.

 

All Aboard: Who Is Night Train?

Night Train is an emerging ensemble theatre company dedicated to sharing vibrant and compelling stories from around the world.

We will work with a range of collaborators to bring MAKLENA to life, including:

  • Night Train founding members Maria Montague (Director, Translator), Oliver Vibrans (Composer), Léa des Garets (Actor), and Alona Bach (Actor)
  • Movement Director Lana Biba
  • Set, Puppets, and Costume Designer Nikki Charlesworth
  • Actors Eden Harbud, Adam Mirsky, Matthew Coulton, Andreea Tudose
  • Co-Tour Managers Bohdan Tokarsky, Danielle Craig
  • Associate Producer Saskia Baylis

story:
In Limbo

I couldn't talk about it when I was alive, so why should I start now?

When James finds himself in Limbo after taking his own life, he is met by a guide who helps him to confront his past. Together the pair revisit key moments of his life. What brought him here? What has he left behind?

In Limbo explores the pressures we face in modern society in a relatable, touching and poignantly funny way. Inspired by real experiences, the play focuses on mental health and the power of human connection. This project, and its subject matter, is something we believe needs urgently addressing.

 

Who are we?

SevenArc Productions is an emerging theatre company made up of East 15 graduates. Our aim is to open up dialogues about sensitive subjects, such as mental health, using imaginative frameworks. We are passionate about the work we create and can't wait to share our debut show In Limbo. 

 

Meet the cast

   

Devised by the company

Directed by Georgie Staight

We are working in collaboration with Central London Samaritans who are an essential part of our research and development process. We will be providing collection buckets at each of our performances to support Samaritans and the crucial work they do.

 

Where will my money go?

Without any formal funding, we are crowdfunding to make up the deficit in our budget to help pay the team and cover some technical costs for the show.

Your funding will contribute towards: 

  • Venue deposit (£500)
  • Costume, set and props (£80)
  • Venue technician (£250)
  • Online marketing (£50)
  • Printing- flyers and posters (£70)
  • Graphic design and photographer (£75)
  • PRS music licensing (£40)
  • Once costs are covered, any remaining funds will go towards covering the creative team and taking the show forward to other venues. 

 

Other ways to help

We appreciate that not everyone can contribute financially, but please do spread the word and get following us on our various platforms! 

Instagram- @sevenarcproductions

Twitter- @sevenarc_

Facebook- @sevenarc 

Website- www.sevenarcproductions.co.uk

Tickets to In Limbo are available here: https://www.tristanbatestheatre.co.uk/whats-on/...

story:
Introduction

“The biggest challenge was people believing that we were actually writing a full-scale, original Musical or that we could have it ready in 9 months”, says Bechtel who is now rehearsing with a 50+ member cast and crew in preparations for its debut May 23rd -25th. “We are unbelievably excited to see this begin to come to life!” After his initial concept work was complete, the book and songs began to take shape last summer when he solicited two young, talented collaborators Makayla Allen to help with lyrics and David Heras as co-writer. What developed was a unique story set in an rich, ancient world with a musical mix that taps from not only its cultural traditions but also more modern styles such as blues and Jazz to deliver the message. Bechtel, who is also working on the final costume and set designs is gearing up for the ambitious musical production. However he finds himself blown-away by it’s evolution and what this young cast and crew are building together from ground zero. “We feel audiences who see this will be amazed at what a group of young artists can achieve”.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your donations to fund the various costs of producing this production, and make sure we have everything we need to make this the best show it can be. Here are some of the places your donations will be going:

  • Set Construction
  • Set Dressing
  • Props
  • Costumes & Makeup
  • Lighting and Sound Systems
  • Marketing & Advertising
  • Repairs, Replacements, Food & Other Miscellaneous Costs

So as you can see your contributions are being put to good use! But you also are entitled to benefits as well, so here are the perks you can claim by donating:

$25 - Civilian: A donation of $25 will get you your name in the playbill and on our website as a backer!

$50 - Artisan: With a $50 donation you will be invited to come see the show on one of its three showings in Temecula, California. If you don't live close, don't worry! You also have the choice of us sending you a copy of the taping for you to enjoy the show from wherever you are! This also includes everything from the previous perks.

$100 - Warrior: Your donation is strong as the jaguar! With a donation of $100, you will receive two tickets to a showing of your choosing in Temecula, California or a copy of the taping. You will also receive an official King of Azteca poster. This also includes everything from the previous perks.

$300 - Noble: High society suits you well! A $300 donation will get you a immortalized as a backer in the show's playbill and on our website, two tickets to the show or access to the recording, an official King of Azteca poster, and an official T-shirt.

$500 - High Priest: The gods speak through you with this donation of $500! This donation gets you immortalized as a backer in the show's playbill and on our website, two tickets to the show or access to the recording, an official King of Azteca poster signed by the creators, and a CD copy of the Official King of Azteca Soundtrack.

$1,000 - Emperor: We bow before you oh, great one! Your outstanding contribution of $1,000 to this production will get you an associate producer credit in the playbill, two tickets to the show or access to the recording, a signed official soundtrack CD, and a signed copy of the script with a custom cover done by creator Joshua Bechtel!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't put in a donation here, that is perfectly okay! If you love this project and want to support it but don't have the money to back us you can follow us on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat, and on our website! Share posts with your friends and family, and get the word out that this is happening!

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/thekingofazteca/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/The-King-of-Azteca-125...

Twitter: https://twitter.com/thekingofazteca

Snapchat: @thekingofazteca

Use the hashtag #thekingofazteca in posts about us on your various social media accounts to get people excited! Thank you so much for supporting The King of Azteca!

story:
For 2013, MOVEiUS is hard at work preparing Big River (and Other Wayfaring Ballets) for the Capital Fringe Festival. This mixed repertory program walks the line between classical and contemporary, bringing works from capital region choreographers Diana Movius, Kimberly Parmer, Florian Rouiller, and Katya Vasilaky to new audiences.  Headlining the program is Big River, a journey of emotional development through country music.  Known for innovative choreographic concepts, MOVEiUS won the 2012 Fringe Audience Award for dance & physical theater for our steampunk ballet Flight of Fancy.

But we need your help.

At this point, all the pieces on our program are in rehearsal. Kim has finished choreographing and setting the first 10 (out of 25 minutes) of our headlining ballet Big River, but in order to get these ballets performance-ready, we need more rehearsal time! On top of that, MOVEiUS is known for our high quality, fully produced performances. But like most arts organizations, bringing back our cast of 13 dancers, along with paying for costumes, lighting design and pointe shoes (which cost $75 per pair!), costs more than we take in through ticket sales. 

Our $2000 goal is the amount we need to pay for shoes, 20 more hours of paid studio time (in addition to the many hours graciously donated by various studios in the Bethesda and Rockville area), lighting design, and costumes.

About MOVEiUS:

MOVEiUS Contemporary Ballet (formerly MOVEiUS Dance) was founded in 2010 to catalyze the creation and public presentation of innovative, accessible, and thoughtful contemporary ballet. MOVEiUS responded to an urgent need in the arts community to promote local ballet choreography, opportunities for professional ballet dancers, and affordable community ballet performances and officially became Montgomery County's only contemporary ballet company in 2013. MOVEiUS is committed to bringing diverse ballet-based choreography to DC metro audiences. Big River (and Other Wayfaring Ballets) will premiere in July 2013. This production is presented as a part of the 2013 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe.

In the three years since the company's inception, MOVEiUS has received critical acclaim for its performances throughout the DC Metro area, appearing at venues such as Dance Place, the Atlas Performing Arts Center, and the Woolly Mammoth.

story:
About the show:

We are looking for your help to enable the completion of our exciting new work ‘That Is All You Need To Know’. This stunning piece of visual theatre, devised by the company, will tell the story of Bletchley Park and the untold secrets of the remarkable men and women who cracked the enigma code. Total Theatre Award nominated Idle Motion will take you back to 1940s England, to the eccentric country house whose grounds, filled with chess champions, Oxbridge graduates and young debutantes, was the melting pot of Britain’s greatest minds. Among these were the visionary Alan Turing, the exceptional Gordon Welchman and the thousands of dynamic women whose work was the hidden heroism of the war.

With our trademark inventive staging and captivating storytelling we will create a textured landscape of personal testimony and multimedia on a stage busy with filing cabinets and typewriters. Developed in association with The Lowry, Jacksons Lane, Greenwich Theatre and Redbridge Drama Centre, this piece will be a celebration of humanities ability to solve the impossible, to crack the most complex of problems, and of the extraordinary people whose quiet work changed the course of our history.

So far...

We have completed 8 weeks of Arts Council supported Research and Development, however we still need to find match funding to enable the project to reach its full development. ‘That Is All You Need To Know’ has enabled us to collaborate with an array of fantastic and talented designers, co-creators, artists and looks to be our most compelling and beautiful show yet. It will premier at The Lowry in May 2013, followed by a UK National tour and a month of Fringe excitement at Edinburgh Festival.

Without additional support of Idle Motion from lovely people like yourselves we would not have been able to create or develop some of the work we’ve made over the past few years. We are passionate about creating engaging and beautiful new theatre for everyone. We wouldn’t be able to do this without the constant support from friends, family, benefactors and all of you out there. We are always massively grateful for any support we receive, whether that’s when you come to watch our shows, offer us a potential prop, or, hopefully in this case, some funds to keep us going.

Thank you very much IM x

‘That Is All You Need To Know’ involves the work and commitment of...

Jan Avery-Harris
Bish Cebula
Greg Cebula
Grace Chapman
Sophie Cullen
Charlie Donegan
Joel Gatehouse
Freda Johnson
Nicholas Pitt
Tash Pryne
Ellie Simpson
Paul Slater
Kate Stanley

About Us:

We create highly visual theatre that places human stories at the heart of our work. Integrating creative and playful stagecraft with innovative video projection and beautiful physicality, our productions are humorous, evocative and sensitive pieces of theatre which leave a lasting impression on their audiences. From small beginnings, having met at school, we have grown rapidly as a company over the last six years, producing five shows that have toured extensively both nationally and internationally. Our collaborative relationship is at the centre of all that we do and we are proud to be an Associate Company at the New Diorama Theatre and the Oxford Playhouse. Idle Motion are a young company with big ideas and a huge passion for creating exciting, beautiful new work.


Nice Words about Idle Motion:

“A brilliant emerging company, inventive work with strong storytelling at its heart... this physical theatre ensemble have a bright future.”  Lyn Gardner, The Guardian 

“Their creativity is boundless, and there’s nowhere to go but up.”
TimeOut Beijing

“Everything this company does is innovative, articulate and beautifully conceived.”  The Scotsman 

“A poetic and visual feast... deeply powerful... a true ensemble piece.”  The Stage

“An astonishingly accomplished young company.”  The List

“A masterclass in staging, narrative and theatrical imagination.”  Whats On Stage

“Inventive staging that stretches the boundary of theatre.”  The Skinny

“Emotionally resonant, multi layered theatre with highly innovative staging... a theatrical force to be reckoned with.”  Edinburgh Spotlight

“A compelling rhapsody on language, vision and the imagination... Idle Motion’s optimisim takes the possibilities of language beyond physical constraint; its potential is transcendent.”  Exeunt Magazine

“At the heart of all theatre lies the concept of ensemble. Idle Motion have taken this idea as their inspiration, and are forging theatre performances that explore and celebrate it with imagination, skill and a fertile creativity. It's fantastic to see a company of young theatre practitioners emerging with such originality, passion and inventiveness.”  Juliet Stevenson, Patron of Idle Motion

Why We Need Your Help:
Arts Council England have generously granted Idle Motion 71% of the costs of this show. However we need to match-fundraise the remanding 29% of the cost of this project. Part of our determined effort to achieve this is through yourselves and indigogo.
story_txt: About the show:We are looking for your help to enable the completion of our exciting new work ‘That Is All You Need To Know’. This stunning piece of visual theatre, devised by the company, will tell the story of Bletchley Park and the untold secrets of the remarkable men and women who cracked the enigma code. Total Theatre Award nominated Idle Motion will take you back to 1940s England, to the eccentric country house whose grounds, filled with chess champions, Oxbridge graduates and young debutantes, was the melting pot of Britain’s greatest minds. Among these were the visionary Alan Turing, the exceptional Gordon Welchman and the thousands of dynamic women whose work was the hidden heroism of the war. With our trademark inventive staging and captivating storytelling we will create a textured landscape of personal testimony and multimedia on a stage busy with filing cabinets and typewriters. Developed in association with The Lowry, Jacksons Lane, Greenwich Theatre and Redbridge Drama Centre, this piece will be a celebration of humanities ability to solve the impossible, to crack the most complex of problems, and of the extraordinary people whose quiet work changed the course of our history.So far...We have completed 8 weeks of Arts Council supported Research and Development, however we still need to find match funding to enable the project to reach its full development. ‘That Is All You Need To Know’ has enabled us to collaborate with an array of fantastic and talented designers, co-creators, artists and looks to be our most compelling and beautiful show yet. story:
Update: We are know operating at 19 Main Street, Topsham, Maine Dance & Fitness.
Let's get dancing!

We're passionate about community, music and dance fitness.

  • Providing excellent adult fitness programing.
  • Quality child and teen dance classes. 
  • Promoting positive and healthy body image.
Thanks for your support!  To hear more about this campaign, check out our YouTube video.

Renovation costs

This one-time capital campaign will provide this center with the following:

  • Light construction projects that will bring our amazing space up to speed.
  • Safe entrances that will keep our classes from being distracted.
  • Any additional funds will go to our scholarship campaign, making sure anyone that wants to dance will dance, regardless of financial status.

The Impact

Making our community healthier and happier:

  • We want to be a part of creating more of a "Main Street" feel in Topsham.
  • Providing more recreation for all ages in the Mid-Coast area.
  • Making it easier to find space for events and special functions.

Risks & Challenges

Dance isn't just for ballerinas.

  • Educating the community and bringing Mid-Coast Maine into the 21st century - men can dance too!
  • Community outreach and working with as many groups as possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, however you can still help us:

  • Please tell others about our capital campaign, and our amazing dance and fitness classes.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word of Maine Dance & Fitness.

Thank you so much for considering us.

Betsy Haskell
Creative Director

story:
Actors Ensemble's Play Development Program

Actors Ensemble of Berkeley (visit AE's Facebook group) is an all volunteer, 501c3 non-profit corporation, now amidst our 58th season.  Our New Play Development Program, AEdiPlay, is designed to work closely with playwrights on the nurturing of their plays, taking promising scripts through a series of readings, workshops, and productions.  We are especially interested in producing plays that don't come out of the  "Theatre/Drama/MFA" system - plays that come from the heart, and as an outgrowth of people's lives - and if they're funny, even better!  Our first play in the program is Madame Gufay's Free Speech Lovelutionaries , by Norah Foster,just in time for the 50th anniversary of the Free Speech Movement itself!  We hope to produce AEDiPlay productions annually.

About The Author

Norah Foster, the enticing, engaging and eager retired manager of graduate services at the UC Berkeley Library and new late blooming playwright, wrote Madame Gufay over a period of years, incorporating many events that she personally experienced, as well as plot twists that emanated directly from her vivid imagination.  She began working as a volunteer at Actors Ensemble, and as an experiment on our part we produced her play originally as a workshop/staged reading.  It showed enough promise (and Norah enough enthusiasm in helping to get to the next step) that we have taken it upon ourselves to produce it as a full play, performed over two weekends in December.

Madame Gufay is our little holiday gift to Berkeley from Norah, the director Alan Barkan, and AE, something to brighten up your life as you busily prepare for the holidays.

Performance Information

Madame Gufay's Free Speech Lovelutionaries, produced by Actor’s Ensemble of Berkeley and directed by Alan Barkan, will be performed at 8 p.m. on Dec.12-13, 19-20th, 2014 at the Live Oak Theater 1301 Shattuck Ave, in Berkeley.

We have a great cast already in rehearsals: Simone Bloch, Sarang Cho Lee, Chris Habash, Scott Alexander Ayres, Edward Kimak, Tom Westlake, Alicia Barela, Vicki Zabarte, Patrick Glenn, Martha Luehrmann, Chris Cruz, CJ Gross, Cai Shaotian, Caoi Shaotian, and Andrea Granera.

And a crew all excited to make magic happen: Carmen Yu, Juliet Pfafker, Harriet Hache.

Morer to come! 

Play Synopsis

Growing up in the French provinces, Madame Gufay was fascinated by news reports of the Free Speech Movement (the FSM) which fermented on the campus of U.C. Berkeley and resonated worldwide.  Now, having returned to school late in life, she has arranged to finish her last semester studying at her own personal mecca, U.C. Berkeley.  Madame Gufay is a force of nature, and her wacky, goofy efforts to experience Free Speech in the present day involve most campus life: the administration and academics, the classroom, the library, Sproul Plaza demonstrations and, of course graduation.

Madame Gufay overcomes language challenges, academic arrogance, uncontrollable urges, public drunkenness, lewd and lascivious behavior, to the fulfillment of innocent wacky, goofy dreams. To be sure, Madame Gufay and her activist Lovelutionaries do care passionately about social justice and they advocate for world peace, justice, not to mention lowering tuition for public universities! Madame Gufay's character is based loosely on the famous director Jacques Tati's Mr. Hulot who also had hilarious adventures.

Program Budget Information

In order to sustain this new program and cover the production costs it is necessary to raise $2500 in addition to the projected ticket sales of $3000.00.  A budget summary follows:

  • Rehearsal Space Rental - $1,200.00
  • Theatre Space Rental - $1,000.00
  • Directors & Crew Stipends - $900.00
  • Advertising & Promotion - $800.00
  • Props / Costumes / Set - $400.00
  • Share of Actors Ensemble overhead (Insurance, etc.) - $700.00
  • Rewards/Indiegogo Fees - $500.00

If we EXCEED our goal, all such funds will be used to support future AE projects.  No theatre company supports itself entirely with ticket sales - and we are no exception. 

And .. if this Indiegogo campaign is successful (especially if it is a little more than successful) we will have the wherewithal to begin planning to make the AEdiPlay series an annual occurrence.

In Closing - Thank You For Your Support

Please watch the attached video for some short clips of an earlier staged version or just cut to the chase and pledge as generously as you can.

Please watch the attached video for some short clips of an earlier staged version or just cut to the chase and pledge as generously as you can.

story:
Summary

Acting Unlimited, Inc. opened Theatre 810 in late 2011. Since then, it has received a 2013 Downtown Award for being Downtown Lafayette’s Best Kept Secret and become a home to many other local theatre companies, such as Acadiana Repertory Theatre, The Tea Sippers, Silverbacks Improv Theatre, Wanderlust Theatre Company, and many more. AUI also hosts many workshops and children’s classes within the space.

This year, AUI purchased a new, modern lighting setup for Theatre 810. Since installing the new lights, the company has begun to update its facilities to meet the ever-evolving needs of the theatre community.

AUI is a 501(c)(3) non-profit arts organization.

AUI, founded by Gloria Breaux in 1989, has a mission that is two-fold: to present innovative theatrical experiences to audiences who may never have enjoyed a live theatrical performance, and to train actors, directors, designers and technicians to create theatre for the company, and enable them, in the future, to create theatre for other companies or for their own companies. AUI recruits children, teens and adults from all walks of life and all ethnic groups. More information about AUI can be found at actingunlimited.org.

What We Need & What You Get

Running a theatre space takes more than enthusiastic volunteers and shows in the space. The money we take in from rentals barely puts a dent in our monthly bills. As we support various theatre companies in the community, giving them an affordable place to produce their art is important to us.

  • We need donations to help us keep the space maintained and up to date.
  • It will take about $30,000 to pay all of the bills for Theatre 810 for the year 2015.
  • We are asking you to help us raise at least $5,000 of that amount.
  • When you donate to Theatre 810, not only are you helping us keep the arts alive on our end of Downtown Lafayette, you will also receive recognition and benefits related the the amount you are able to give.
  • If we are unable to reach our final goal, funds raised will go towards our general fund for Acting Unlimited, Inc, which will go toward bills and utilities.

This fundraiser is running in conjunction with our Gala "Acting Unlimited, Inc. presents A Black Box Affair to benefit Theatre 810." For more information on the November 23rd Gala, visit ablackboxaffair.eventbrite.com. Our goal between the two fundraisers is to raise at least $10,000.

    The Impact

    Theatre 810 has become a home for many other performers and companies:

    • Theatre 810 hosts various workshops for all ages, as well as regular children's theatre classes, from script writing, to acting and improv, to stage makeup and effects.
    • Silverbacks Improv Theatre formed due to the availability of this affordable, versatile space in Downtown Lafayette.
    • Acadiana Repertory Theatre has found a home within the walls of Theatre 810, and brings exciting New Works Premieres to our community, as well as an annual New Works Festival.
    • Local high schools and the University of Louisiana at Lafayette utilize the space for their students' shows so they can experience theatre outside their own auditoriums.
    • ...and MANY more.

    Without help from our community, we will be unable to maintain our affordable rental prices, which will cause financial strain on many of our tenants, who may be forced to seek new venues for their productions, or, worse, may be unable to produce their shows at all.

      Risks & Challenges

      We are currently undergoing a change in management. While this process is still incredibly fresh, we are taking this opportunity to rework our infrastructure and goals.

      • Our new team is made up of experienced managers, volunteer coordinators, dedicated volunteers, and hard-working artists.
      • Although we are facing many of the the challenges of a new administration, we are surrounded by a supportive community of knowledgeable, helpful friends and partners in arts.
      • With your donations, we will be able to implement a new budget, solely devoted to Theatre 810, so that AUI can maintain this space without having to sacrifice the quality of its own theatrical productions.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you cannot contribute financially at this time, that's okay! Thankfully, theatre is an animal that benefits from Word of Mouth!

      • Share events and updates from Theatre 810's Facebook page, Twitter account, and blog.
      • Share events and updates from Acting Unlimited's Facebook page, Twitter account, and Google+ account.
      • Invite your friends to attend A Black Box Affair on November 23rd. There will be food, drinks, dessert, a silent auction, and performances by many local theatre companies
      • Attend shows at Theatre 810! Check our facebook page or theatre810.blogspot.com for upcoming dates and times.
      • Share this campaign with your friends, family, and networks!

      By spreading the word about events and shows happening at Theatre 810, you'll help us go from "Downtown Lafayette's Best Kept Secret" to Downtown Lafayette's Best Black Box Theatre Space.

Share events and updates from Theatre 810's Facebook page, Twitter account, and blog.
Share events and updates from Acting Unlimited's Facebook page, Twitter account, and Google+ account.

Invite your friends to attend A Black Box Affair on November 23rd. There will be food, drinks, dessert, a silent auction, and performances by many local theatre companies
