 By spreading the word about events and shows happening at Theatre 810, you'll help us go from "Downtown Lafayette's Best Kept Secret" to Downtown Lafayette's Best Black Box Theatre Space.

story:
THE SHOW

Special Relativity is a full-length, contemporary circus show of original material conceptualized by Stacey Kigner and Allison McDermott, and created in partnership with Air Temple Arts. It will debut in New Haven, Connecticut in January 2015, with plans to adapt it for touring.

In Special Relativity a steel magnate from the 1890s finds both his mettle and the depth of his devotion tested when a space/time accident separates him from his betrothed. If he’s going to have any chance of seeing her again he has no choice but to follow her path through the time vortex.

We’ll travel from the Stone Age to a dystopian future, telling the story of Special Relativity through Chinese pole, aerial dance, acrobatics, contortion, Spanish web and more.

Beyond creating an inventive, and entertaining show that we can’t wait to perform for you, we’re hoping to continue to widen the audience for circus in Connecticut and greater New England. Now we want to create a touring show that has a home base in New Haven—something that’s never been done before.

THE TEAM

Special Relativity features a cast of eight performers, all of whom are coaches and/or students at Air Temple Arts. They are: Allison (trapeze, aerial silks, juggling, acrobatics), Brianna (contortion), Elaine (aerial silks), Elsa (aerial straps), Lauren (duo lyra, aerial silks, acrobatics), Lee (hula hooping), Nick (Chinese pole, juggling, acrobatics), Stacey (Spanish web, aerial silks, duo lyra, juggling, acrobatics).


THE FUNDS

In order to produce this ambitious show we need to raise a bare minimum of $5,500. That money will cover the cost of renting the theater for performances and rehearsal, tech for the show (including lights, sound, and projection), and a small stipend for our eight performers.

If we can raise more than that though, we can cover the cost of props, costumes, promotional material, and start laying the groundwork to bring Special Relativity on the road.

It’s a lot of money to ask for, but we’re confident in our ability to produce this amazing show. This isn’t our first time in the (circus) ring.

In 2012 we produced Missed Connections—a small ensemble show about the personals section of Craigslist.

In 2013 Stacey opened Air Temple Arts—Connecticut’s first aerial dance and circus studio, which had to undergo expansion less than a year after opening. Both endeavors have been highly successful, and we have a dedicated community backing us.

The curtains will go up on Special Relativity in January whether or not we reach our funding goal. We’ve put far too much into the show so far, both creatively and financially to not see our vision through to the end (even if it means we live off ramen for the next eight months), but we hope you’ll help us take Special Relativity beyond our January dates, and hopefully into a theater near you!

THE REWARDS

We have tons of fabulous rewards—both physical and physically demanding—in exchange for your generosity!

In the physical realm we have a number of wonderful rewards. In addition to stickers and show swag, we decided this was the perfect time to make Air Temple gear available to the public, since our students there have been asking for it for over a year. Below you’ll see examples of some of our favorite gear offerings:


In the physically demanding realm—most of our performers in Special Relativity are also coaches at Air Temple—what better way to let us show you our appreciation than by kicking your butt in the studio? At various reward levels we’re offering Open Studio* time, classes and private lessons at Air Temple.

Beyond donating, you can help by sharing our campaign, checking out our show and studio pages, and spreading the word about all of the above on facebook, and whatever other social media platform you use!

 

*Open Studio time is only open to practicing circus students and performers.

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
THE
SHOW
Special Relativity is a full-length, contemporary circus show of original material
conceptualized by Stacey Kigner and Allison McDermott, and created in
partnership with Air Temple Arts. It will debut in New Haven, Connecticut in
January 2015, with plans to adapt it for touring. 
In Special Relativity a steel
magnate from the 1890s finds both his mettle and the depth of his devotion
tested when a space/time accident separates him from his betrothed. If he’s going
to have any chance of seeing her again he has no choice but to follow her path
through the time vortex. 
We’ll travel from the Stone Age to a dystopian future, telling the story
of Special Relativity through Chinese
pole, aerial dance, acrobatics, contortion, Spanish web and more. 
Beyond creating an inventive, and entertaining show that we can’t wait to
perform for you, we’re hoping to continue to widen the audience for circus in
Connecticut and greater New England. Now we want to create a touring show that
has a home base in New Haven—something that’s never been done before.
THE TEAM
Special Relativity features a cast of eight performers, all of whom are coaches and/or
students at Air Temple Arts. They are: Allison (trapeze, aerial silks, juggling,
acrobatics), Brianna (contortion), Elaine (aerial silks), Elsa
(aerial straps), Lauren (duo lyra, aerial silks, acrobatics), Lee
(hula hooping), Nick (Chinese pole, juggling, acrobatics), Stacey
(Spanish web, aerial silks, duo lyra, juggling, acrobatics).
THE FUNDS
In order to produce this ambitious show we need to raise a bare minimum
of $5,500. That money will cover the cost of renting the theater for
performances and rehearsal, tech for the show (including lights, sound, and
projection), and a small stipend for our eight performers. 
If we can raise more than that though, we can cover the cost of props,
costumes, promotional material, and start laying the groundwork to bring Special
Relativity on the road.
It’s a lot of money to ask for, but we’re confident in our ability to
produce this amazing show. This isn’t our first time in the (circus) ring.
In 2012 we produced Missed Connections—a small ensemble show about the personals section of
Craigslist. 
In 2013 Stacey opened Air Temple Arts—Connecticut’s first aerial dance
and circus studio, which had to undergo expansion less than a year after
opening. Both endeavors have been highly successful, and we have a dedicated
community backing us. 
The curtains will go up on Special
Relativity in January whether or not we reach our funding goal. We’ve put
far too much into the show so far, both creatively and financially to
not see our vision through to the end (even if it means we live off ramen for
the next eight months), but we hope you’ll help us take Special Relativity beyond our January dates, and hopefully into a
theater near you!
THE REWARDS
We have tons of fabulous rewards—both physical and physically
demanding—in exchange for your generosity! 
In the physical realm we have a number of wonderful rewards. In addition
to stickers and show swag, we decided this was the perfect time to make Air
Temple gear available to the public, since our students there have been asking
for it for over a year. Below you’ll see examples of some of our favorite gear
offerings:In the physically demanding realm—most of our performers in Special Relativity are also coaches at
Air Temple—what better way to let us show you our appreciation than by kicking
your butt in the studio? At various reward levels we’re offering Open Studio*
time, classes and private lessons at Air Temple.
Beyond donating, you can help by sharing our campaign, checking out our
show and studio pages, and spreading the word about all of the above on
facebook, and whatever other social media platform you use!
 
*Open Studio time is only open to practicing circus students and
performers.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
About Field Trip Theatre

Field Trip Theatre is committed to supporting emerging artists through development and production of new plays that engage diverse audiences and reflect the perspectives and identities of The District. We value innovative storytelling and uncensored artistry that serves the diverse community of Washington, DC.

About Giant Box of Porn by Patrick Flynn

Young couple Ron and Kate come home one day to find a giant box of porn in their living room. This comedy explores life’s most important questions: What kind of burglar breaks in and leaves porn? Is it okay to buy baby paraphernalia just because it’s on sale? And, most importantly, who still has a VHS player? 

The play is directed by Maureen Monterubio with dramaturgy by Megan Westman. This production will feature Grant Cloyd as Ron, Anna Jackson as Kate, Morganne Davies* as Vanessa, and Will Hayes as Sherlock. Designers Adrian Rooney (scenic), Jennifer Salter (costumes), Colin Dieck (lighting), and Kenny Neal (sound) round out the team. 

Behind the Scenes

We'll be documenting the goings on of Giant Box of Porn on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and, of course, our website. Want more? Feel free to send us an email at fieldtriptheatre@gmail.com. 

Giant Box of Porn will be presented as part of the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival July 10 to 27 in Washington, DC. We'd love it if you joined us.


*Member of Actors' Equity Association

story:
What's Project Shimmy?

Torque, the professional belly dance troupe at Twisted Dance Studios began Project Shimmy in 2008 as a way to help Triad Health Project, a Greensboro-based 501(c)-3 non-profit organization, meet the needs of individuals living with HIV / AIDS and their loved ones.

This year, the show is being hosted by Twisted Dance Collective, a group of dancers from the former Twisted Dance Studios that has decided to continue their dance relationships, even after the studio closing.  2014 will be the 6th Annual benefit show, and Twisted Dance Collective would like to raise even more funds for Triad Health Project.  And to do that, we need help to pay for the expenses of producing Project Shimmy.  If the Collective can raise $1150, any and all money raised by the benefit show will go directly to Triad Health Project.

What We Need & What You Get

Twisted Dance Collective needs $1150 to cover expenses of producing and promoting Project Shimmy.  Here's where the money goes:

  • Theater Rental:  FREE
  • Sound and Light Operators:  $600
  • Security Guard during the Show:  $100
  • Cleaning Fee for Theater:  $75
  • Graphic Designer for Poster/Program:  $150
  • Posters/Flyers (Printing):  $125
  • Programs (Printing): $100

If you donate to our campaign, here's what we can offer you!

$20 donation:  One Project Shimmy Ticket and a mention in the program as a Contributor.

$50 donation:  Pair of Project Shimmy tickets, one FREE class with a Twisted Collective instructor, and a mention in our program as a Partner to our campaign.

$100 donation:  Pair of Project Shimmy tickets--reserved seats at our gala show, two Project Shimmy t-shirts and a mention as a Sponsor in our program

$500 donation:  Four Project Shimmy tickets--reserved seats at our gala show,  four Project Shimmy t-shirts, a mention as an Angel in our program and 3 free lessons from a Twisted Dance Collective instructor.

All money raised will go to cover expenses for the show.  Any additional funds will go to Triad Health Project as additional donations for their services.  No monies will be utilized by Twisted Dance Collective for any purpose other than the benefit show.

About Triad Health Project Client Services:

Triad Health Project is committed to tailoring their services to meet the ever-changing needs of clients. Following the development over the past few years of newer, more effective treatments for HIV and AIDS, clients are living long and healthy lives, enjoying relationships, family and careers in a way never imagined when the disease was discovered.

Unfortunately, accessing adequate medical care and medications to ensure good health can be a challenge for many people living with HIV. A diagnosis of HIV also often brings fear, sadness, anger, stress, isolation, and anxiety--a stigma of fear and disgrace that can prevent treatment.

In response to these concerns, Triad Health Project provides intensive, individualized case management services, which are provided by professionals specifically trained and experienced in the field of HIV. THP fights against the stigma that continues to be a barrier to those diagnosed with HIV. Triad Health Project provides support, counseling and therapeutic groups to individuals and families who are learning to cope with HIV.

Triad Health Project is committed to educating the entire community about HIV and other sexually transmitted infections. Prevention is still the only cure for HIV and knowing one's status is the first step in protecting yourself and others. THP offers free and confidential testing and counseling every Monday night from 5:00 - 7:00 PM at their Greensboro office, and throughout the community at various outreach events.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to donate...you can still help!  Please share this campaign with your family and friends! Or email us at twistedcollectivenc@gmail.com and let us know that you would be interested in volunteering for Project Shimmy.

You can also help us if you are a business!  We need raffle prizes to help raise additional funds for THP.  If you would like to donate, please contact us at twistedcollectivenc@gmail.com.

story:
Hello Future Contributors, 

My name is Shanice Bullock and I am a 3rd year, 6th-12th grade, public school dance teacher in Winston-Salem Forsyth County. I am currently a traveling educator and I work to inspire students at Winston-Salem Preparatory Academy and Walkertown High School.
For the past year and half I have been at Winston-Salem Preparatory Academy piloting the dance program. In 2012, I only had 6 hopeful young ladies and an old science lab. Now, at Winston-Salem Preparatory Academy, there are over 90 students enrolled for the 2014-2015 academic school year and we will be using the auditorium. 
Winston Salem Preparatory Academy is considered a Title One School. For those of you who don't know what that means, Title One schools are schools with a high-percentage of low income families. 
Winston-Salem Preparatory Academy is a historical site. So due to historical site construction renovation restrictions, we are unable to reconstruct a studio. However, we are able to add to the building if needed. 
So as you can image, with the growing program, and the desiring students, I would love to have an actual studio; with mirrors and bars. Due to recent budget cuts, that I am sure you have seen all over the news, we need help! That's where you come in! 
With your donation, you will help me in my goal of inspiring less fortunate students in gaining self-confidence and self-worth! They are constantly commenting on how they wish they could have what the students at the other schools have! Help me help then.
Click on the link below to see more about the program and school! 
http://wsfcs.k12.nc.us/Domain/8203
Thank you in advance, 
Shanice Bullock
Dance Educator

What We Need 

We currently need $2,000. 

A nearby studio is closing down. Due to the need of immediate evacuation of their premises, I have to go get the mirrors by Monday (July 7, 2014). Studio Mirrors are not cheap. We will get six mirrors! 

The goal will cover, the cost of the mirrors, the cost for the moving truck and the cost for gas to and from the studio. 

    The Impact

    Short Term: The studio mirrors will be a major instructional tool for the growth of these future artists. They will be able to learn more efficiently with the presence of the mirrors. Also, we will be able to have our own space! 

    Long Term: 100s of students will be reminded of your kindness to the program! It will forever change it! 

      Risks & Challenges

      The biggest challenge for this campaign is TIME! However, we will be able to overcome this with your help! Once you donate, you can share with everyone you know! With your help, this challenge will be non-existent. 

      If we don't make the goal (Which I am sure you will help with): I will find a different vendor for the mirrors and still purchase a few. (Everyone still wins!)

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Don't have the funds to help out now? Simply SHARE this campaign and help me push to make this goal!

story:
*Meet J. Doe Theater Company

Formed on the first Monday in June 2012, we are a group of actors, artists and writers who have banded together to create new works, live entertainment, and theater. We meet every Monday to discuss matters of business, pleasure and art. We challenge each other creatively whether we are discussing future projects or rehearsing scene-work. We are a nurturing group of artistic people who feel compelled to bring stories and feelings to life with the intention of sharing them with you.  

Past John Doe Productions/Collaborations - 

Love At Home by Mary Matoula Webb (John Doe Member)

Serenade in C by Suzanne Mernyk (Current Guest of J. Doe)

The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window by Lorraine Hansberry

Almost, Maine by John Cariani

Yess, Texas by Desira Pesta (Original John Doe Theater Company Member)

  

   Follow us on Facebook! 


 Loose Knit 

                                              

                      

by Theresa Rebeck

 Directed by Suzanne Mernyk *

In conjunction with The Actors Theatre of Sacramento


Cast

Liz - Tygar Hicks ~

Lily - Lauren A. Kennedy

Paula - Bliss Griffin * ~

Gina - Natalie Roy *

Margie - Delaney Smeal

Bob - Anthony Franqui 

Miles - Rob Ceriello *

Stage Manager - Ally Fairchild *

Additional members/producers of John Doe Theater Company -  

Eddy Cara, Mary Matoula Webb & Cat Cabral


      *  Guests of J. Doe Theater Company

      ~ Members of Actors' Equity Association


When & Where

Weist-Barron Studios

35 West 45 Street, 6 Floor
New York, NY  10036

-April 23 - Wednesday, 7:30 pm 

-April 24 - Thursday, 7:30 pm  

-April 25 - Friday, 7:30 pm

-April 26 - Saturday, 6:00 & 8:00 

                               


Tickets will be $15 each, cash only at the door. OR save $5 when you purchase 2 or more tickets using our indiegogo campaign. 

As freelance artists ourselves, it is our goal and our joy to provide fellow performers and struggling artists with an affordable theatrical escape. We aren't here to make a profit - we are here to make a difference by keeping ticket costs low and performances captivating. 


~Reserving Tickets~

We are taking all ticket orders/reservations through indiegogo. It's simple- 

  • Click the "contribute now" button that has the number of tickets you're interested in and enter your credit card information when prompted.                 
  • Find the "perk" that has the number of desired tickets you would like to order, click that box, and then click "continue." (If you would like more than 5 tickets, just multiply the amount of tickets you want by 15 and subtract 5 so you get your discount [i.e. you want 7 tickets- 7 x 15 = 105 - 5 = $100])
  • An automated message will be sent directly to us. 
  • From there, a member of the company will reach out to you in regards to reserving performance dates. 

That's it - click, pay, and wait for an email. We take care of the rest.




Why are we using indiegogo?

Most ticketing websites add on an additional fee for their services. We don't want you to have to pay that. Indiegogo will take a percentage of our fundraising. We would prefer to pay a fee, not to make you. Our goal is to provide you with affordable, enjoyable theater. 

In addition to saving our patrons being charged a fee, using indiegogo also helps us build a strong web presence as a company. It helps us show up in google searches and displays proof of our pro-active approach to producing shows. It's also a community building platform in the sense that we can provide our backers with special updates not accessible to the general public. It provides a place for you to check in on updates and see how the show is progressing.

*Donations/Out-of-Town Backers*

Want to support John Doe Theater Company but are unable to attend our show? That's ok! Build some good vibes with a "Karma Perk." Donate however much you want and we will add the number of tickets from your donation into a pay-it-forward list. From this list we will distribute tickets to our industry guests and to any people who may not otherwise be able to afford them.

Our main goal in all of this is to provide New York City audiences with affordable and engaging theater. We just want to tell our story, and we want to tell it to anyone who wants to take the time to listen.



~The Play & Playwright~ 

Loose Knit

Once a week in the heart of New York City five women gather to knit. As the sweaters pile up, their lives fall apart. Liz is having an affair with Bob (her sister Lily's husband), Gina's lost her job, Paula is having an identity crisis, and Margie just wants a date. Into their lives steps Miles, a cool businessman who made his first million before he was thirty and is now looking for a wife. On a series of hilarious blind dates in a sushi restaurant, Miles and the women go head to head in an attempt to define what it is men and women want these days. As in her previous comedy, Spike Heels, the author outlines the battle between the sexes with wit, ferocity and insight in a contemporary comedy of manners. (SamuelFrench,Inc)


Theresa Rebeck - Playwright 

Theresa Rebeck is a widely produced playwright throughout the United States and abroad. New York productions of her work include Dead Accounts at the Music Box Theatre; Seminar at the Golden Theatre; Mauritius at the Biltmore Theatre in a Manhattan Theater Club Production; The Scene, The Water’s Edge, Loose Knit, The Family of Mann and Spike Heels at Second Stage; Bad Dates, The Butterfly Collection and Our House at Playwrights Horizons; The Understudy at the Laura Pels Theater in a Roundabout Theatre Company production; and View of the Dome at New York Theatre Workshop. Omnium Gatherum (co-written, finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in 2003) was featured at the Humana Festival, and had a commercial run at the Variety Arts Theatre. Her newest work, Poor Behavior premiered at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles in 2011. Dead Accounts, commissioned by the Cincinnati Playhouse, premiered January 2012. Seminar continues to run on Broadway. (http://theresarebeck.com/)



~Risks & Challenges~ 

Putting up a show in New York City is tough work- It takes a lot of time, money and patience. You need a support system consisting of equal parts business, friendship and creativity. We have managed to find that balance, the time for the work, and the money from our pockets. Now we want to expand.


Here is a breakdown of our expenses:

Theater Rental : $1400

Rights: $500

Props: $100

Transportation of the set: $100


Aside from a generous loan provided by The Actors Theatre of Sacramento, this project has been solely funded by John Doe Theater company members. 

To help reduce spending, we have all made it part of our character research to discover and purchase our own costumes. To save money on the set, we modified the blocking of several scenes so we can use the same furniture for each location. With this adjustment, we have only had to purchase supplies and find/build set pieces for one environment.

The money you donate will not only help us with this production, but it will guarantee you amazing perks such as tickets and behind-the-curtain updates. The gesture behind a donation of any amount will not be lost. Even a $1 donation will show us that you took the time to check us out and see what we are about. For that, thank you. If you cannot donate (we understand!), share the link. We don't want to miss this awesome opportunity to introduce ourselves to not only the people we know and love, but the people you know and love as well!

Jet on back to New York City in the early 90's and jump from apartment to apartment as we knit, date and try to keep men from ruining the world!

Find the "perk" that has the number of desired tickets you would like to order, click that box, and then click "continue." (If you would like more than 5 tickets, just multiply the amount of tickets you want by 15 and subtract 5 so you get your discount [i.e. you want 7 tickets- 7 x 15 = 105 - 5 = $100])

An automated message will be sent directly to us. From there, a member of the company will reach out to you in regards to reserving performance dates. That's it - click, pay, and wait for an email. We take care of the rest.Why are we using indiegogo?Most ticketing websites add on an additional fee for their services. We don't want you to have to pay that. Indiegogo will take a percentage of our fundraising. We would prefer to pay a fee, not to make you. Our goal is to provide you with affordable, enjoyable theater. In addition to saving our patrons being charged a fee, using indiegogo also helps us build a strong web presence as a company. It helps us show up in google searches and displays proof of our pro-active approach to producing shows. It's also a community building platform in the sense that we can provide our backers with special updates not accessible to the general public. It provides a place for you to check in on updates and see how the show is progressing.*Donations/Out-of-Town Backers*Want to support John Doe Theater Company but are unable to attend our show? That's ok! Build some good vibes with a "Karma Perk." Donate however much you want and we will add the number of tickets from your donation into a pay-it-forward list. From this list we will distribute tickets to our industry guests and to any people who may not otherwise be able to afford them.Our main goal in all of this is to provide New York City audiences with affordable and engaging theater. We just want to tell our story, and we want to tell it to anyone who wants to take the time to listen.~The Play & Playwright~ Loose KnitOnce a week in the heart of New York City five women gather to knit. As the sweaters pile up, their lives fall apart. Liz is having an affair with Bob (her sister Lily's husband), Gina's lost her job, Paula is having an identity crisis, and Margie just wants a date. Into their lives steps Miles, a cool businessman who made his first million before he was thirty and is now looking for a wife. On a series of hilarious blind dates in a sushi restaurant, Miles and the women go head to head in an attempt to define what it is men and women want these days. As in her previous comedy, Spike Heels, the author outlines the battle between the sexes with wit, ferocity and insight in a contemporary comedy of manners. (SamuelFrench,Inc)Theresa Rebeck - Playwright Theresa Rebeck is a widely produced playwright throughout the United States and abroad. New York productions of her work include Dead Accounts at the Music Box Theatre; Seminar at the Golden Theatre; Mauritius at the Biltmore Theatre in a Manhattan Theater Club Production; The Scene, The Water’s Edge, Loose Knit, The Family of Mann and Spike Heels at Second Stage; Bad Dates, The Butterfly Collection and Our House at Playwrights Horizons; The Understudy at the Laura Pels Theater in a Roundabout Theatre Company production; and View of the Dome at New York Theatre Workshop. Omnium Gatherum (co-written, finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in 2003) was featured at the Humana Festival, and had a commercial run at the Variety Arts Theatre. Her newest work, Poor Behavior premiered at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles in 2011. Dead Accounts, commissioned by the Cincinnati Playhouse, premiered January 2012. Seminar continues to run on Broadway. (http://theresarebeck.com/)~Risks & Challenges~ Putting up a show in New York City is tough work- It takes a lot of time, money and patience. You need a support system consisting of equal parts business, friendship and creativity. We have managed to find that balance, the time for the work, and the money from our pockets. Now we want to expand.Here is a breakdown of our expenses:Theater Rental : $1400Rights: $500Props: $100Transportation of the set: $100Aside from a generous loan provided by The Actors Theatre of Sacramento, this project has been solely funded by John Doe Theater company members. To help reduce spending, we have all made it part of our character research to discover and purchase our own costumes. To save money on the set, we modified the blocking of several scenes so we can use the same furniture for each location. With this adjustment, we have only had to purchase supplies and find/build set pieces for one environment.The money you donate will not only help us with this production, but it will guarantee you amazing perks such as tickets and behind-the-curtain updates. The gesture behind a donation of any amount will not be lost. Even a $1 donation will show us that you took the time to check us out and see what we are about. For that, thank you. If you cannot donate (we understand!), share the link. We don't want to miss this awesome opportunity to introduce ourselves to not only the people we know and love, but the people you know and love as well!Jet on back to New York City in the early 90's and jump from apartment to apartment as we knit, date and try to keep men from ruining the world!

story:
Hello - We are 6 dancers from Eugene, Oregon. 

We have affectionately been called the Texas 6  because we have been working these past few months to raise money to go to Dance Ad Deum's Summer Dance Intensive 2014  in Texas. We all have danced together for many years at Hosanna Dance Studio. We believe that in order to get there we needed to set tangible and achievable goals and then work really hard. That is what we have done these past months and continue to do. We have collected cans by the hundreds, we are doing fundraising on a local level - garage sales, car washes, and various other endeavors. We will work to continue to raise money and let people know when and how we are working to do so. 

However, we need your help to meet our goals.

Specially we are working to raise over a $1,000 each to cover the cost of travel, accommodations, the dance intensive fees, and food for a total of $6,500. Any amount helps. We have been working nickel by nickel in our CAN drive but we need more to get there. 

We ask if you would kindly spread the word of our campaign - every bit of encouragement means so much to us. Also, we ask you to pray for us as we continue to work towards our goal. For some of us it will be our first big adventure. All money donated will go directly to fund our efforts. 

Impact: personally and to our community

There are so many good things to donate to and we understand the value of your support. We have all studied dance for over 10 years. This is not a light goal for us. This dream has been in the making for a few years now and this is the season it has all seemed to come together.

As dancers at a studio with a wide age range we have each worked to help as aides in classes with younger dancers. We also participate in the Hosanna Youth Performers entourage [HYPe] and perform throughout the community year round and also work as a team to grow in leadership and faith through our art. Our studio emphasizes "the art of dance with the heart of worship"

As a group we hope that through our experience at Dance Ad Deum we will learn to improve our technique, to grow in faith, and to deepen our friendships. We all want to bring back our experience of Dance Ad Deum and share it with our dance community. We have all been blessed by good instruction and support over the years - we see this as an opportunity to learn more and to give back by sharing and modeling what we learn. Here are a few thoughts from the Texas 6 on why they want to go on this trip so you can hear it in their own words.

Alexis Elliott - I would like to go to this intensive not only to improve my technique but also to meet more dancers of faith. Also, since I will be graduating next year, it will be an opportunity for me to explore my options for a possible career in dance.

Kelsey Winter - I want to go to Dance Ad Deum because it is a new experience and will make me a well rounded dancer. Also, I feel like Dance Ad Deum is the perfect dance experience because you get to be with people who love to dance and also worshiping God at the same time.

Isabel Swanson - I am super excited to have the opportunity to go to Dance Ad Deum Summer Intensive because it will be a new experience for me. This will be my first summer intensive outside of my home town. I am really hoping to grow in my dancing as I want to pursue dance as my career when I am older. Any support in helping us get there will be so appreciated. 

Lily Teague - I want to go to Dance Ad Deum because I believe it will be a good opportunity to grow not only as a dancer in technique and experience but also in my faith. I believe as dancers and Christians God intends us to become stronger in our abilities so that we can share our faith in all that we do. This is a big dream for me and I am willing to work hard and I appreciate all your prayers and support, 

Isabel Jaquette - I really want to go to Dance Ad Deum because it would be a really good learning experience seeing different styles of teaching and dance, it will be nice to meet other dancers of my age from across the country, and it will bring me and my group closer to each other and God. 

Caitlyn Sims - I really want to attend Dance Ad Deum because of the exceptional training and passionate heart for Christ. I couldn't imagine a better place to spend my senior summer before I need to start thinking about adult things. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute with money that does not mean you can’t still help:

  • Please get the word out - share our link on your facebook walls, via email, via phone, via twitter - whatever works we would so love your help. 
  • We are doing our CAN fundraiser all throughout this campaign. Please let us know if you need us to come pick up your CAN donations.
  • Please feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Again, THANK YOU so much for visiting our page and supporting us. We have been so encouraged by all that has happened so far - we are reaching for the stars! - Alexis, Caitlyn, Isabel, Kelsey, Isabel and Lily

story:
Who we are

Lehenda Ukrainian Dance Company is a newly formed Ukrainian Dance organisation, based in Melbourne, Victoria under the Artistic Direction of Merited Artist of Ukraine, Melanie Moravski Dechnicz.

For the past 9 years Melania has been working with Verchovyna Ukrainian Dance Ensemble, Ukrainian Youth Association Melbourne as a volunteer in the position of Artistic Director. In February 2014 she announced this new company Lehenda!

Lehenda Ukrainian Dance Company is currently made up of 43 dancers who perform with pride, passion and embody the true soul of Ukrainian culture. The strength, beauty and grace of Ukrainian Cossack dancers, combine to give you the contagious energy, spectacle, colour and spirit that is, Ukrainian dance!

What we need?

Lehenda are eager to get on stage and perform! We have been lucky enough to borrow a small number of costumes to perform over the last few months, however the full company will be performing at a huge Ukrainian Dance event, Hopak in the Park at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in Melbourne on 26 April 2014. We need to make a large number of costumes to dress our wonderful dancers!

By donating to our costume fund you will enable Lehenda to share the Ukrainian Dance Culture and give Australian dancers the opportunity and privilege to perform Ukrainian Dance.

How will the money be used?

Lehenda is starting from scratch. Ukrainian national costumes are intricate and have many different pieces. It is very important to us that we create authentic costumes to accurately represent the rich Ukrainian Culture.  

Ukrainian dance has different costumes for different regions. As we grow, we will need to create costumes for these various regions. However our initial goal is to create Central Ukrainian Costumes for our performance at Hopak in the Park.

Funds raised will go towards buying fabric, trims, beads, flowers, ribbons, elastic, threads and everything else required to create the Central Ukrainian Costume.

You will be helping us create the Lehenda legacy. The costumes we create will be worn for many years to come by generations of Ukrainian Dancers!

What will you get?

By helping us get onstage you will be part of our history! You will help us get on our way and become a Company!

Lehenda Artists and dancers will be forever grateful.  You will become part of our Lehenda family!

Our short shared history

Lehenda is a new company staffed by experienced people who have achieved countless individual successes.

Our costume department have between them successfully designed and sewn costumes for Ukrainian Dance Touring productions, Schools and Ballet Productions.

With your help this terrific team can create a wonderful product, providing opportunities to dancers and audiences in Australia and world wide.

How else can I help?

Follow us on Facebook, twitter and come along and support us at our performances!

Spread the word about Lehenda Ukrainian Dance Company, School of Dance, our work, performances and this campaign!

Please feel free to contact Lehenda staff at info@lehenda.com.au if you feel you would like to contribute in another way.

story:
That Kind of Girl at Capital Fringe

That Kind of Girl uses the stories and experiences of its cast members and a number of interviewees as a jumping-off point to irreverently explore the lives of young women from different backgrounds in the DC area.  The show takes a multifaceted approach to its subject matter, examining body image, pop music, consent, street harassment, sex, and a range of other topics in a way that invites the audience to be a part of the continuing conversation.  Alternately raunchy, sweet, poetic, and sad, That Kind of Girl offers a welcoming discussion of the issues being dealt with by young women today.

That Kind of Girl began its life as a workshop production at the University of Maryland in the fall of 2013, where it was met with overwhelming praise from audiences and a five star review from Maryland Theatre Guide.  Almost a year later, we're thrilled to be able to bring a new revised and expanded version of the show to the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival, and we need your help to get it there!

What We Need & What You Get

To bring our show to the Capital Fringe Festival, we need to raise a minimum of $3,000.  This money will provide us with the ability to pay all of our festival fees, refurbish our set pieces, and pay our performers a small stipend for travel.  Most importantly, it gives us a budget to market our show and bring this transformative piece of theatre to as much of the community as possible.

Every dollar matters, and even a small donation goes a long way:

  • $5 buys us 100 postcards to help spread the word to a wider audience.
  • $25 provides the supplies to refurbish one of our set pieces.
  • $100 provides a travel stipend for a performer to defray the cost of commuting to rehearsals and shows.
  • $1000 pays all of our various festival and fundraising fees.

To thank you for donating as little as a few dollars, we have some incredible gifts for our backers including posters, behind-the-scenes content, and a number of unique rewards provided by cast members including clothing, accessories, and private yoga lessons.

Spread the Word!

If you're not in a position to contribute financially, please help us get our message out:

  • Share our call for help with Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Pinterest, random Tinder chats, whoever.
  • Tell your friends about the show!

Any help you can give us in getting the word out is very much appreciated.


Pussy R.E.P., short for Pussy Radically Eradicating Patriarchy, is a new theatre troupe dedicated to producing proudly feminist art for contemporary audiences.  Formed by a group of University of Maryland students in the Winter of 2013, That Kind of Girl at Capitol Fringe 2014 will be our first full production.

story:
Short Summary

Riptide Dance Company has been producing fluid and athletic dance for six years.  Choreographer Cherise Richards combines the spiraling gymnastics of Capoeira with Contemporary dance to express human emotion in a totally new and innovative way.  This time our work is exploring the dichotomy between being closed off, insecure, and defensive with openness, confidence and joyous vulnerability while using the black box theater of the Electric Lodge in a site specific way. 

With the crowds funding we will be able to hire a set designer, pay for our venue and most importantly, give the dancers compensation for their hard work and sweat.  Not a penny will be taken for granted and this piece of living art will be able to be shared with you and the dance going community at large.  

What We Need & What You Get

Breaking it down in more detail:

  • Our goal is $2,500, the bare minimum for this production.  First and foremost Cherise is determined to give the majority of the funds to the dancers- professionals who rarely get due compensation for their work.  Without them this visual specticle would not be possible.  Dancers are usually the last item on a dance companies budget but Cherise has pledged to make them first and to give them as much as possible. 
  • Also on the budget is rehearsal space, performance space, a set designer, set costs, PR costs, costuming, lighting design and a videographer. As you can see $2,500 will barely cover our costs and any small donation is greatly appreciated!  
  • Donating can qualify you for a show poster, a ticket to the show, or celebratory drinks with the cast!

The Impact

Dance is one of the most undervalued arts in the country.  It expresses the human expirience in the most in-the-moment, visceral and human way.  This is your chance to help foster the cultural underdog.  Please help us reach our goal as we prepare a performance that we know will touch you with its personality and poignancy.
